PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully submit that:
The High Court's Mabo decision has caused division and dissension, uncertainty, resentment and economic damage in Australia.
Mabo will not solve the social, educational, housing and other problems of Aboriginal people.
Mabo is an attack on our Federal system of government, under which the absolute control of Crown lands and management of land titles have always rested with the States.

The only solution to Mabo is a referendum of the Australian people for a law to overrule the High Court and re-establish equal land rights for all Australians, under the normal procedures of State and Territory laws.
And we strongly urge the Senate to reject any other proposed solution.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Knowles (from 169 citizens) and Senator Panizza (from 21 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Asylum Seekers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
the Australian Government's policy of detaining people seeking asylum has caused enormous hardship and misery for those detained;
the policy has contravened international obligations undertaken by Australia;
as a result of the detention of asylum seekers the Australian community has borne a considerable financial burden;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:

PETITION.PARA: to end the policy of detaining asylum seekers, and
to release those asylum seekers still being held in Department of Immigration Processing Centres.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies and has led the world in many democratic reforms.
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: maintained national unity in a federation

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel: Ethanol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to establish the necessary rules, regulations and practices which encourage and facilitate the use of ethanol as a fuel additive in place of lead as an octane enhancer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before us today, the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993, is certainly the most significant piece of industrial legislation that this parliament has seen in the last 10 years. It focuses on four or five important developments in industrial relations. I think the most important principle in this legislation is that dealing with enterprise bargaining. The government's concept of enterprise bargaining includes the principles that no-one should be worse off in totality than the award provisions, which the enterprise bargaining is replacing. Central to this is also the concept that the award system continues in tandem with the enterprise bargain and that, from time to time, the award system is adjusted through national wage deliberations. The latest of those is the current $8 round.

PARA.TAB: The award system is to remain as a safety net to ensure that those people who are participating in enterprise bargaining are no worse off. Those not protected by the no disadvantage test in the federal act will enjoy a series of minimum standards based on the ILO conventions of the United Nations. They will include a fair minimum wage, equal pay, protection against unfair dismissals and 12 months unpaid parental leave. To those opposite who seem to believe that we should not be embodying those principles based on the various conventions of the United Nations International Labour Organisation, I say that they are what I think are the very basic minimum standards—they are certainly nothing startling—that all workers in Australia should be covered by. But, unfortunately, because of recent changes in industrial legislation, particularly in Victoria and Western Australia and some aspects of the legislation in Tasmania, some workers do not enjoy these minimum standards. The legislation also includes provisions for the right to strike and amends the sanctions under the current Trade Practices Act, known as sections 45D and E. There has been extensive consultation on these variations.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the unions.

—I note the interjection and remind honourable senators opposite of the lack of consultation that occurred in Victoria and Tasmania when the legislation was being put together in those states. The legislation was presented in the dead of night and rushed through the parliament with minimal time for consultation, yet we have those opposite complaining about the alleged lack of consultation by this government. In fact, this government has spent some six months since the election, when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a speech before a business forum, consulting with all groups in the community. I think that stands in stark contrast to the behaviour of state governments, particularly in Victoria and Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal particularly with the direct bargaining processes that are contained in the legislation. The making of agreements between groups of workers and employees at the enterprise level with management will be encouraged. To encourage this, a new division of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is to be established. There will be two types of industrial agreements—a certified agreement and an enterprise flexibility agreement—which, as I referred to earlier, will ensure that the no disadvantage test applies too. On expiry of the certified agreements, it will continue; so the wages and conditions in a certified agreement covering workers will not disappear overnight.

The corporations power is being used in this area in order to remove the requirement of an interstate dispute. There are significant protections to workers through these two types of agreements: a no disadvantage test; a right to union representation for union members; consent by a majority of employees; protection of unionists from discrimination; the right of unions to be heard—the non-unionised enjoy further protections—and refusal to register the agreements on public interest grounds. The commission can make orders that a party take actions consistent with bargaining in good faith—that is a particularly important aspect—and there is guidance in the act as to what constitutes good faith, such as attendance at agreed meetings, disclosure of relevant information, compliance with agreed commitments, not withdrawing or adding terms capriciously and not refusing to bargain with an organisation. So this issue of enterprise bargaining is a very important matter.

There are a number of principles that I want to deal with on the issue of enterprise bargaining. It is interesting to note that Justice Higgins, as he then was, said in 1915 in a very famous judgment:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the process of conciliation, with arbitration in the background, is substituted for the rude and barbarous process of strike and lockout. Reason is to displace force; the might of the State is to enhance peace between industrial combatants as well as between other combatants; and all in the interests of the public.

This is a very important quotation because I believe it underlines one of the important principles we have in industrial relations in this country. There are two propositions contained in this quote. The first is an empirical proposition that industrial tribunals will bring about an end to strikes and lockouts. The second proposition, which is more conceptual, is that the power of the state can and should be employed in industrial relations in the public interest. That is a particularly important principle.

PARA.TAB: Arising from this debate over the last 10 years particularly is the fact that enterprise bargaining has been seen as a structural fix which has been part of the industrial relations debate but the move towards decentralisation and the focus on the enterprise have been important principles of discussion in industrial relations. However, there are a number of quite dramatically different interpretations particularly between the government and the Liberal and National parties as to how we define and implement enterprise bargaining.

The opposition's argument, which is central to most of the debate that it has put forward, involves much more of an economic focus. Its theme includes the notions that industrial relations performance can be improved. This will lead to increases in the productivity of Australian firms and industries which will then be able to compete on international markets. This will overcome the balance of payments and—whoopee!—investment will result and our unemployment will go down dramatically. That is the central proposition of those opposite.

That proposition is based on a number of assumptions that I want to deal with very briefly in this debate. Firstly, it assumes that the labour market is the source of the current economic problems of this country and, indeed, of the world. It is not correct to assume that labour market problems are the source of our economic recession and associated problems. The problems of the economy are much more complex than what happens in the labour market. We have to look only at the international evidence in this regard. If we compare the economic indicators with the industrial relations systems in a number of overseas countries, we see that, at best, the evidence is very mixed and that industrial relations has a great deal to do with economic performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I will read the figures out to Senator McGauran. I glanced down the economic and financial indicators of the Economist of last week. Let us look at unemployment in particular countries that have so-called free and flexible labour markets, such as the United Kingdom, which has an unemployment figure of 10.3 per cent. The United Kingdom has what would be defined as a totally free labour market in the sense that it now has no awards whatsoever to provide any safety mechanism for workers. Indeed, there is a range of rigorous repressive measures against the trade union movement in the United Kingdom, but it still has a 10.3 per cent unemployment rate. Why? If the vigorous reforms of the Thatcher era were so impressive and were to lead to such economic buoyancy, why have they not resulted in lower unemployment? This continuing argument that there is a link between unemployment and the labour market is largely a nonsense and a fiction.

PARA.TAB: The continual focus on enterprise bargaining is nothing new. Those people who have some knowledge of industrial relations would be aware that, over the last 90 years, while we have had a federal industrial relations system, there has always been very extensive focus on the enterprise. There are very significant over-award payments right through the economy. This issue of enterprise bargaining is nothing new. One of the arguments from the opposition and from employers is that enterprise bargaining will produce significant changes in attitude which will enhance common goals and interests. It is interesting to note the argument of the Business Council of Australia. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Shared interests are more likely to blossom where employees bargain as one unit and with a workplace focus.

The opposition shares that attitude. However, even the Business Council of Australia's publications tend to refute this argument that common goals and interests will blossom as a result of enterprise bargaining. The Business Council of Australia commissioned the National Institute of Labour Studies to conduct research into a small number of paired Australian and overseas—mainly American—companies. It did so in order to analyse the attitudes of the work forces when covered by multiple union and non-union managements. The National Institute of Labour Studies found:

. . . a curious anomaly in the data. American managers seem more innovative in terms of motivating employees through pay and incentives and participative management. Yet Australian employees are more satisfied and committed to their organisations. The Australian industrial relations system seems to provide an atmosphere where both high job satisfaction and commitment to organisations and peers flourish. The system may also act to protect employees from poor styles of supervision.

That quotation is particularly important because it was sourced and commissioned by the Business Council and directly refutes the arguments of those opposite and the Business Council that, somehow, moving to enterprise bargaining will create a flourishing and blossoming of relationships at the enterprise level.

PARA.TAB: The fourth matter is an element that is often overlooked in the debate on industrial relations; that is, that there may be important transition costs which will need to be considered between employers, unions, employees and other interested parties. They will need to devote considerably more resources to this notion of enterprise bargaining. While larger companies and unions may have the expertise and personnel to manage such a movement—if they have not already moved in that direction, and many firms have not—many smaller to medium sized firms may not be so well placed.

When Senator Peter Cook was the responsible minister he tabled a labour studies report which indicated that only seven per cent of small firms in this country were interested in moving towards enterprise bargaining. Why? I contend that most small employers are not skilled or interested in direct negotiation with their employees.

This brings me to the next point, which is a central and critical element in one of the failings of businesses today—that they may not have the managerial expertise, personnel or financial wherewithal. There is no doubt that, in attempting to improve our economy, we have become preoccupied in our industrial relations focus, to the neglect of other issues—one of which is the lack of management expertise in many firms.

The fifth issue, which is unclear but certainly has to be dealt with, is the reduction in the level of industrial conflict. It is correct to say that over the last 10 years, under this government, there has been a significant reduction in industrial disputes. The total abolition of the role of tribunals and unions in the negotiating process is championed by the more extreme members of the opposition, who advocate the so-called New Right position of the H.R. Nicholls Society. They say that unions and arbitration have no place in the workplace. That is a two-sided coin; a two-edged sword. In a booming labour market, they say they are advocating—I do not believe they advocate it seriously—that the power of the marketplace, the power of force, those who have the greatest might, shall prevail.

Those opposite want to ensure that there is a set of draconian laws—including no right to strike, sections 45D and 45E—and a set of draconian interventions in this so-called free labour market to restrict unions and employees when they do have the upper hand in the bargaining process. That is a consistent theme of the New Right. I believe the ultimate goal of the Business Council of Australia and the opposition is a union-free workplace as the final solution to industrial relations. They are the issues that I wanted to touch on in dealing with enterprise bargaining.

I have also touched on the central issue of the so-called flexibility in the labour market that allegedly will deliver low unemployment. I referred to the economists' figures for the United Kingdom which are clear evidence that this simply does not happen. There is a range of other issues.

Those opposite refer continually to Asia. They say that we should be basing and modelling ourselves on our international competitors. But many aspects of the Asian economy are very unlike those in Australia. Whilst wage differentials in Asia are significantly different from Australia—usually below—they are catching up quickly; they are no longer cheap wage economies. Certainly Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore have had significant increases in their wage levels over the last three or four decades.

But, importantly, there is a vastly different social structure in these countries. They do not enjoy pension entitlements or workers' compensation entitlements—the sorts of social structures that are provided by government in this country because of the nature of our society and family structure. In most parts of Asia those services are provided via a family structure. So it is not a valid comparison to make in continually referring to our Asian competitors. I refer to an issue that has not been touched on a great deal—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you like employment?

—That is the catchcry: `Do you like employment?'. The honourable senator has not been listening very well because I have argued—I think correctly—and presented the evidence that there is little correlation between industrial relations systems and the labour market. How do those opposite justify the fact that in the United Kingdom there was an unemployment rate of 10.3 per cent at the end of the Thatcher era? Despite all of the reforms and Thatcher rhetoric—the industrial relations reforms, the breaking up and the smashing of unions—the United Kingdom still has 10.3 per cent unemployment. The opposition's model, the Thatcherite model, has proved to be a failure.
—What is your answer?

—The answer lies in a very complex set of solutions that this government has been pursuing: tying our economy much more closely to Asia, ensuring that we have an export drive, and ensuring that we have more internationally competitive management and a better educated work force.

PARA.TAB: The last issue I want to touch on relates to my home state of Tasmania. In this act we have a set of very important fundamental protections for workers engaged in workplace bargaining, but we do not have these protections in Tasmania. I urge the federal minister, who has done a very good job in this debate despite some significant difficulties, to ensure that the provisions of the federal legislation override the provisions of the Tasmanian legislation which provides no protection for workers as part of workplace bargaining. That was evidenced recently in a Supreme Court appeal of a decision by Commissioner Johnson, the workplace commissioner in Tasmania. I believe that where states do not provide decent protection for their work forces the federal legislation should override that state legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 is nothing more than a pay-off from the government to the trade union movement for the role which the union movement played in supporting the campaign of lies embarked upon by the Australian Labor Party during the last election campaign with regard to the policies of the Liberal and National parties. This legislation therefore demonstrates, as I will show in a moment, that not only is this government incompetent but also it is corrupt.

PARA.TAB: We have seen another example of that corruption recently in Minister Kelly's sports rorts. As I say, that corruption is reinforced by this legislation. Why else would this legislation fall so dismally short of delivering the much heralded new era in industrial relations that was promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his speech to the Institute of Directors on 21 April this year?

Two to 2 1/2 weeks ago, I was part of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which examined this legislation. As I said in the debate in this chamber on the report of that committee, in support of the dissenting report of Senator Crane and me, the overwhelming evidence presented to that committee was that this legislation fails dismally to deliver what the Prime Minister promised. It is clear of course why the Prime Minister has broken yet another promise. He has had to provide the unions with a pay-off for their election support. He has had to bow to the demands of the ACTU with regard to this bill. Nothing could make that clearer than what Jennie George said after the federal election in a debate with Bryan Noakes from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we won the election in March and this bill is a pay back for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of that election campaign.

Clearly, there is the example of corruption embodied in this legislation. But we also ought to remember the incompetence associated with this legislation. In the other place 170 amendments to this legislation were introduced at the last minute. Those amendments were introduced after our committee had given consideration to this legislation. So that committee did not have any opportunity to look at the proposed amendments. One hundred and seventy amendments were introduced in the House of Representatives and guillotined through there. It is clear that this bill is a capitulation by the government to the demands of the trade union movement. It therefore represents a gross dereliction of duty on the part of the government in providing legislation in this form for a sectional interest rather than legislating for the community as a whole.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to consider the comments of the Labor senators who have so far taken part in the debate. Last night we heard Senator Carr, Senator Childs and Senator Murphy, and this morning we have heard Senator Sherry. Almost to a man, they have not attempted to defend this legislation. At least they have been honest about the legislation, unlike the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), who seeks to create a fantasy about this legislation's capacity to promote and develop enterprise bargaining and get genuine enterprise agreements. We have not had any of that fantasy from the honourable senators debating the legislation in this place. They told us the truth about the legislation—what it is really about. It is about protecting the interests of trade unions and protecting and maintaining our current outmoded system of industrial relations in this country.

Senator Carr referred to the Higgins model—the model of industrial relations that we have had in Australia for most of this century. Of course, that model was based on the 19th century experiences of workers and employers and, as I said, was introduced early this century. It is a system of industrial relations which has largely been responsible for Australia's standard of living in terms of per capita income falling from the highest in the world—Australia was the richest country in the world at the turn of the century—to now being well down on the international table of economic wellbeing. That system is outdated and needs urgent replacement.

Senator Carr also claimed that businesses and employers wanted an industrial relations system based on making employees fear the sack. That is errant nonsense. Nothing could make employees fear the sack more than this bill because of the detrimental effect it will have on the capacity of employers to maintain employment and to provide jobs. Certainly, the only people who will not fear the sack under this legislation are those who will not get jobs because of the inhibiting effect this legislation will have on the capacity of business to grow and create employment.

The whole of the speech of Senator Childs was devoted to the capacity of this legislation to provide protections for workers. There were no claims in Senator Childs's speech that this legislation was going to provide greater flexibility with regard to industrial relations. In fact, he argued strongly against enterprise agreements. In particular, he argued that women were the losers under such a system of industrial relations.

I remind him of the experience of the female textile workers in Sydney some time ago who sought to change their hours of work so that they could conveniently fit it in with their family responsibilities. They wanted to start and finish work earlier in the day so that they could be home from work to care for their children when they arrived home. They reached that agreement with their employer but then the textile workers union and Anna Booth got into the act and said, `You can't do that. That's contrary to the award. That's breaking down hard-won gains by the union movement'. So that whole agreement was overturned by the intervention of the trade unions. Women lost out because of the restrictions of the current structure. They were going to gain by an enterprise agreement, by the bargain they had reached with the employer; but, as soon as the union and the existing bureaucratic structure got involved, they lost out on that flexibility.

All we heard from Senator Murphy was a gross misrepresentation of the jobsback policy of the federal coalition. This morning we again heard Senator Sherry laud the outdated Higgins approach to industrial relations. He put up a straw man as far as the Liberal Party's understanding of enterprise bargaining and enterprise agreements is concerned, which he then sought to knock down. He also claimed that employers wanted to restrict employees in the negotiating process for enterprise agreements. Employers and this side of politics want some balance in the system. Senator Sherry ignored the fact that, under our approach to industrial relations, whatever restrictions apply to the trade union movement and to employees would also apply to employers.

In contrast, this legislation is extremely one-sided and gives special privileges to the trade union movement. Senator Sherry also tried to argue that there is no relationship between the structure of the labour market and employment levels. Certainly, the labour market is not the only factor that determines employment levels, but it flies in the face of reality and of experience to attempt to argue that there is no relationship between the structure of the labour market and employment levels.

Last night we also heard Senator Bell's address on behalf of the Australian Democrats. He clearly showed that he swallowed hook, line and sinker the fantasy the minister has tried to create as far as this legislation is concerned. In fact, he probably made a better fist of defending the government's legislation than we have heard from the government's own senators. In particular, he indicated his support for trade unions and their involvement in enterprise bargaining, irrespective of whether those trade unions have any members in the workplace involved with that particular enterprise agreement—one of the strong objections that the coalition has to this legislation.

We believe that the legislation is excessively prescriptive and interventionist on the development of a flexible approach to industrial relations and a genuine development of enterprise agreements and, therefore, does not provide any incentive or encouragement to improve the direct relationship between employers and employees in their negotiating process. The opposition believes that the legislation is heading in exactly the wrong direction as far as getting a more flexible industrial relations system is concerned. It does that in three particular areas: firstly, by increasing trade union power by removing sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act, where they are competent in preventing secondary boycotts, and putting those sections into the industrial relations legislation.

Secondly, the legislation increases union power by requiring that trade unions be consulted on the conduct and achievement of enterprise agreements if one member in a particular workplace belongs to a trade union. Even where no employees in a particular workplace are union members, the trade union still has the right to appear before the Industrial Relations Commission when that enterprise agreement goes before the commission for ratification.

Thirdly, the legislation increases trade union power by having a sanction-free period during which enterprise agreements are negotiated, which in effect confirms a definite right to strike on the part of trade unions irrespective of the damage that that industrial action might cause to a particular business.

The legislation is also heading in the wrong direction by making enterprise agreements much more difficult to achieve. It does that by requiring, firstly, that an award be in place before an enterprise agreement can be struck; secondly, that an industrial dispute exists; thirdly, that there be no disadvantage, so that in effect enterprise agreements will be nothing more than over-award agreements; and fourthly, as I have already mentioned, that both trade unions and the Industrial Relations Commission be involved in the establishment of these enterprise agreements.

The ultimate folly of this legislation is that there is a requirement for an industrial dispute to exist before an employer and his or her employees can strike an enterprise agreement. They cannot simply get together and say, `Let's do a deal. Let's establish work arrangements that will improve our productivity, which will improve the competitiveness of our particular business, and which will benefit me, the employer, and you, the employees'. The employer cannot get his employees together and work that out. He has got to actually create a dispute with them before he can go ahead and establish that enterprise agreement.

That highlights the nonsense of this legislation. So in the context of those two particular aspects—the increase in union power involved and the greater difficulty in reaching enterprise agreements, which will be inherent in this legislation—the legislation has many individual shortcomings.

Four particular shortcomings stand out in the legislation. The first of those shortcomings is the removal of sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act, which I have already referred to in brief; the second is the specific provisions relating to the establishment of enterprise agreements; the third is the use of the International Labour Organisation conventions and recommendations to establish minimum employment standards; and the fourth is the establishment of the Industrial Court to deal with industrial matters replacing the industrial division of the Federal Court.

This clearly demonstrates that this is legislation for a minority. It is legislation for trade union leaders. It is scandalous in the context that this government is legislating for a group which leads less than 30 per cent of the work force in the private sector of this country. That shows again the sectional nature of this legislation.

So it is no wonder that employers, especially small businessmen, are increasingly concerned about this legislation. But it is not only small businessmen who have recently expressed their concern. Towards the end of last week we heard two of the most senior businessmen in this country, both of whom have served on government advisory organisations, express their concern at this legislation.

The first of those was Mr Ian Webber, the chief executive of Mayne Nickless. In one address last week he voiced his concern by saying that he believed that business did not understand the full implications of the legislation and had not been vocal enough in criticising it. He went on to call on the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, to tear up this legislation and start again. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think business has not fully appreciated the extent of the fine print in this Bill and they may not even fully appreciate some of the legislative effects.

Hugh Morgan of Western Mining made similar statements. I have also received a letter from the chief executive officer of one of the major automotive component manufacturers, a national firm based in South Australia. He said:

This Bill is extremely damaging for the future of this country and I am surprised and amazed that more people, particularly the Chief Executives of major corporations are not standing up objecting to it. Please continue to do whatever you can to prevent this legislation from passing in its present form.

I have received many letters from small businessmen throughout Australia, including my own state of South Australia. We have received upward of 300 letters from small businessmen expressing their concern about the effect of this legislation on small business and the impact that it will have. I will quote from some of those:
We are a typical small business employing 10. None are, or want to be union members, but all are cared for on a personal basis and paid above award (in most cases substantially).
I have carefully studied the proposed Amendment Bill . . . and have grave reservations about the potential impact of certain aspects on our business. These include:
.The unbelievable complexity of the process required to establish an enterprise flexibility agreement.
.Notification of terms of a EFA to relevant unions, which potentially exposes us to their interference.
.Inflexibility of the `no disadvantage test', which if applied arbitrarily would prevent trading certain benefits for others, and may even be applied to above award payments.

.The possibility of us being roped into an industry-wide certified agreement which is aimed at securing increased wages and benefits from those who can pay and has nothing to do with increased productivity or increased employment.

.Much greater powers given to unions including the `right to strike', supposedly to fulfil Australia's international obligations, although the `right to strike' was never meant to apply where compulsory independent arbitration exists.

I have letter after letter expressing similar concerns and raising further concerns about various aspects of this legislation. I could quote from them at length, and they warrant quoting from. It is only a lack of time that prevents me from doing so.

PARA.TAB: Undoubtedly, the government is shoring up the position of trade unions with this legislation. In addition, the government will be funding, with taxpayers' money, the training of union organisers in the art of recruiting members to trade unions. It was highlighted in an article in the press yesterday that for the first time there will be formal training of union organisers in the art of recruitment. Part of that training process will be undertaken by the Trade Union Training Authority, funded by the federal government with taxpayers' money.

The trade union movement in the private sector is continuing to decline in numbers because it is not providing a service to its members. For that reason, the taxpayers will now be funding the training of union organisers in recruitment of more members. Who will be advising them on this matter? It will be Tas Bull, formerly of the Waterside Workers Federation, and Tom McDonald of the Building Workers Industrial Union—two typical union thugs who have caused so much damage to Australia's capacity to be productive and to our international reputation as a trading nation. They will be telling the union organisers how to behave as thugs—how to force people into unions when they do not want to be members. Again, this legislation fails to provide any protection at all to people who do not want to join unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tas Bull, the Jimmy Hoffa of Australia.

—That is exactly so. The minister has rejected the opposition's proposal to protect people from being sacked from the workplace if they do not want to be a member of a union. Under this legislation, while people cannot be sacked from the workplace for being a member of a union, people can be sacked if they do not want to be a member of a union. If they refuse to join, there is no protection under this legislation whatsoever. That simply reinforces the one-sided nature of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Time is running out and I will not have time to deal with the detailed shortcomings of this legislation in this second reading debate. But there will be an extended committee stage debate on this legislation because the opposition has a number of very important amendments to present in an attempt to at least improve it. One wonders whether improvement of this legislation is possible, but at least we will be doing our best to achieve that in the committee stage. I will certainly be addressing the significant shortcomings of individual parts of this legislation when I indicate my support for those amendments during that committee stage debate.

I conclude by saying that this legislation does nothing to create a better relationship between employers and employees at the workplace. It therefore does nothing to enhance the productivity of Australian businesses, nor our international competitiveness and the capacity of businesses to improve the economic state of Australia by lifting our export earnings and our import replacement capacity. That is why this legislation should be condemned and thrown out holus-bolus from this place, never to see the light of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that I should thank Senator Chapman for spelling out the essence of the opposition's ideology in a way that only Senator Chapman could. That ideology represents a return to the 19th century model of industrial relations. Higgins is too modern.
—Higgins is 19th century.

—Higgins is not 19th century. Higgins is too modern for Senator Chapman; he wants to go back to the 19th century. His ideology is based on the belief that the system cannot work unless employers have an unfettered control, unless they can hire, fire and set conditions without anybody else being involved—certainly without employees being involved because they do not have brains; they leave them behind at the work gate—with no-one to make sure that the contract is fair.

PARA.TAB: Exploitation does not occur in Senator Chapman's ideology or in the ideology of the Liberal-National parties opposite. It is a system based on an inability to countenance the involvement of unions, unless those unions are supine, ineffective and powerless. That is fine. The opposition says, `If you have got powerless unions, we accept them; if they show any sort of guts at all,'—which a union ought to do if it is representing its members—`we don't want a bar of it'.

To talk of Tas Bull and people such as him as thugs is a disgrace. It shows no capacity to understand the contribution that that man and many others in the union movement have made towards the restructuring of the economy of this country. Tas Bull led the charge in waterfront reform. He was central in reforming that industry in a way in which people did not believe it could be reformed. The whole position that Senator Chapman takes, which, as I have said, encapsulates the ideology of the opposition, is amazing in its irrelevance to the needs of a modern economy.

By contrast, I believe that this bill marks one of the greatest achievements in the 10-year history of this government. It will ensure that Australia has an industrial relations system which is fair, adaptable and efficient. It also provides the Australian people with an opportunity to compare this government's approach with that of the Liberal and National parties. It is particularly appropriate that this bill is before the Commonwealth parliament when other Liberal-National Party state governments are legislating to destroy the award safety net in their parliaments.

In my own state of Western Australia, for example, the Court government has introduced laws which give employers power over employees' wages and conditions, which they have not possessed for 90 years. They are punitive laws modelled on those in New Zealand and Victoria. They are based on an outdated philosophy which seeks to give employers the power to dictate employment conditions save for an obligation to provide a few so-called minimum conditions.

It is a system which enshrines the old 19th century concept of employer prerogative based on a conflict model of industrial relations rather than the model upon which this bill is based, a concept of partnership in which both parties—the employers and the employees—not only have rights, but they also have responsibilities to each other. The bill before us will greatly assist in restoring employees' capacity to effectively bargain with their employer, with the help of their union, for those employees unable to gain the full protection of the federal award system.

One can only speculate where the Liberal and National parties got their current industrial relations policies from. Perhaps it was the United States where many employees have to exist on a very low minimum wage of $5 or $6 a hour which, in the United States, does not go far.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would like that, Senator. Some employers, particularly in the hospitality industry, are not even obliged to pay those minimums. Even in the United States, however, employees and their unions have statutory rights guaranteeing that employers recognise unions and bargain in good faith. Even in the land of free enterprise, employees and unions have a right to strike in the bargaining process, and immunity from civil action during that period.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the source was the United Kingdom where Margaret Thatcher legislated to restrict trade union activities while at the same time her policies wiped out much of Britain's manufacturing industry. But even in the UK unions have a right to strike and freedom from civil suit in many circumstances. Bargaining in good faith is also enshrined in its system.

Only the Liberal and National parties would legislate for an industrial relations system which any tin-pot Third World dictatorship would be proud of. That is the sort of legislation we have seen already in Western Australia and Victoria, which we could characterise as the Jurassic Parks of industrial relations. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill will overturn some of the worst aspects of those laws and restore a fair and open system for Australia in the 21st century.

I will detail some of the provisions of the WA legislation and show how the Commonwealth legislation will redress the imbalances and injustices that WA workers face under these state laws. Perhaps the most iniquitous aspect of the WA minimum conditions of employment legislation is the power given to the minister for labour relations to set minimum wages. Honourable senators can imagine the howls of protest which would arise if the Minister for Health could arbitrarily set the medical benefits schedule fee with no consultation with or reference to the medical profession. Under the WA act, however, the minister can set whatever minimum wage he wishes. He is not obliged to consult with anyone or anybody, not even the employers. He is not required to give reasons for his decision. He is the Caesar of salaries, and his decree is law.

Under the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, WA employees will have access to the Australian Industrial Court, which will set them fair wages. The Industrial Court process will be open and accountable; its decisions will be reasoned and based on evidence presented in open proceedings. The IRC will take into account the needs of employees and their families, and similar factors it uses in deciding awards in industries. The contrast between the imperial decrees of a WA Liberal minister and the IRC processes are stark. It is a contrast between an arbitrary and capricious politicised process and one which guarantees natural justice to all parties, and in the integrity of a system in which the public can have confidence.

One can further illustrate the quaintly outmoded coalition industrial relations policies by reference to the substantial power that the WA laws give to employers to sack employees who refuse to forgo or bargain away their existing state award conditions. Ian Viner QC, a former Liberal industrial relations minister, summarised his findings in his recent joint legal opinion on the Workplace Agreements Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The legislation does not protect prospective employees who wish to be employed pursuant to an award rather than a workplace agreement in circumstances where the prospective employer requires that they enter into a workplace agreement as a precondition to employment.

2.The legislation does not protect employees who have entered into workplace agreements in circumstances where their employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept less favourable terms and conditions of employment in a new workplace agreement.

3.The legislation does not protect employees in circumstances where their employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept the terms and conditions of employment in a workplace agreement proposed by the employer, except in the situation where an employer has not previously entered into a workplace agreement. Whether the employee is actually protected will depend upon the particular circumstances.

4. The legislation does not protect employees if their employer dismisses all its work force by notice, advertises their jobs and then employs only those persons, including the former employees, who are willing to enter into a workplace agreement on the terms and conditions specified by the employer.

Both Ian Viner and the opinion's co-author, Rene Lemiere, are well-respected members of the Perth independent bar. Their opinion is a careful and reasoned analysis of the law. It reveals that employees who want to retain state award coverage can be forced off their award and onto individual contracts containing no more than the minimum conditions set by a minister. That is not the straw man that Senator Chapman just referred to; the man he accused Senator Sherry of setting up to knock over. This is fact; this is law and is currently being applied in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is a massive inequality of bargaining power under the WA legislation. In a period of high unemployment, few employees will be able to resist employer pressure to surrender their award. Fewer will be able to afford the legal costs involved in challenging their employer. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill ensures that any WA employee who is dismissed will have access to the new Industrial Relations Court, which can decide the fairness of any dismissal. The court can order reinstatement of an unfairly dismissed employee, and the bill also provides substantial protection from dismissal on a range of grounds, including temporary absence from work, from illness or injury, and absence from work during maternity or paternity leave.

One of the most cynical provisions of the Western Australian legislation is that which requires employers who intend to dismiss redundant employees to give their employees eight hours off work to look for another job. That is it. For example, a middle aged long-serving employee with a family to support can be given two weeks notice or pay in lieu and be told that he can have tomorrow off to job hunt. This provision reflects the mean spirited, greedy and insensitive philosophy behind the Western Australian legislation, which is supported by those opposite. It is bad enough that employees in the metropolitan area of Perth get one day to try to organise their working life, but it may take workers in country areas, which Senator Panizza represents and where there is no access to CES offices, eight hours simply to drive to the nearest office, let alone reorganise their lives and those of their families. The Commonwealth bill will guarantee retrenched employees minimum periods of notice, ranging up to four weeks for those with more than five years service. Those employees over 45 years of age will receive an extra week to reflect their special needs.

The Commonwealth bill also ensures that parents who take leave will be able to return to the same position they held when they took that leave. Under the state legislation the right to return to work is merely subject to the `availability' of a position. The provision is vague in the extreme. It offers a convenient escape for employers who want to rid themselves of employees with family responsibilities who take leave. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill will restore certainty and security to families.

I now wish to turn to some general comments about the philosophy underlying the approach the Liberal and National parties have adopted in industrial relations in the 1990s. Perhaps `philosophy' is too gentle a term to describe what motivates these policies. We have here, manifested particularly in Victoria and Western Australia, an intention to institutionalise massive inequalities of bargaining power in a period of high unemployment. The conservatives' legislation provides virtually no role for unions; it enables employers to apply their extensive financial and legal powers on individual employees.

As in New Zealand and Victoria, employees will be presented with pre-printed contracts of employment with conditions determined solely by the employer. There will be as much negotiation in these cases as there is if a consumer goes to a bank and asks for a Bankcard loan. The individual small borrower would be laughed out the doors of the bank if he or she tried to negotiate a lower interest rate. The same inequality of bargaining power exists in most workplaces, and the result would be the same.

I recently visited New Zealand. As I went around, I purposely questioned numerous people about this and I found that the vast majority of them had had contracts presented to them by the employer on a sign or leave basis. They were all pre-prepared, with no negotiation and no consultation at all with the employees or the unions.

It is interesting to note the euphemisms employed to describe this crude contractual process. The term `bargaining' is used to disguise what is in truth the imposition of terms and conditions over which most individual employees will have no control. `Flexibility' in the Liberal lexicon is code for wholesale reduction in wages and conditions and the restoration of total employer control over every aspect of the workplace—or the return, as I have said before, to the old and outdated concept of managerial prerogative, a term dear to the heart of the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, at whose bidding the Western Australian bill was introduced.

The Industrial Relations Reform Bill cuts through this Liberal Party obfuscation and euphemism to expose the reality of its industrial relations policy. There are many other features of the bill which will expedite the resolution of disputes and bring Australia's industrial relation laws into line with those of other nations who regard themselves as modern, not those who are trying to trip back into the 19th century. The bill reaffirms Labor's commitment to a system of genuine workplace bargaining supported by a substantial safety net of basic conditions. For those workers forced out of their state award systems under Liberal legislation, it provides access to an independent and fair tribunal to set their wages and safeguard them against unfair dismissals. I urge the Senate to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was absolutely astounded that a man of Senator Beahan's prestige, as chairman of the well known Corporations and Securities Committee, of which I am also a member, would defend Australia's waterfront and its work practices over the years.
—Tas Bull has done more to reform the waterfront than any employer has.

—I cannot believe that he would defend our waterfront work practices, let alone claim that Tas Bull should be credited with some sort of reform on the waterfront. Tas Bull has around his neck the worst practices in Australia's union history. The only thing Tas Bull has done for the waterfront, frankly, is to retire from his position as head of the Waterside Workers Federation. He has tied up thousands and thousands of ships in this country—more, I would say, than Allan Border has made test runs. The man is to be condemned for the export dollars he has lost this country. Senator Beahan defends the man who is probably known as the Jimmy Hoffa of Australia—Mr Tas Bull.

PARA.TAB: Equally, Senator Beahan spoke of his New Zealand experience. I attended that parliamentary delegation with Senator Beahan, and we must have been in two different countries. Frankly, the New Zealand industrial relations system, the enterprise bargaining system, is held up to be a great success, and we were told of that by employers and employees. Senator Beahan has defended Tas Bull and defended our waterfront practices, and that is indefensible. He has been telling us that the New Zealand experiment on enterprise bargaining is not a success. So, he is speaking with a political slant. He is not presenting the issue in its true light; he is not debating the issue as it ought to be debated in this forum. He has just given the government line, the government brief, and been quite misleading in so doing.

Prior to Senator Beahan, Senator Sherry spoke for the government side. I do not think we can let pass Senator Sherry's limp defence of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. As my colleague Senator Chapman pointed out, Senator Sherry put up a straw man by quoting the English experience. We are not here to defend England or any other nation. We are running our own industrial relations and are debating our own Industrial Relations Reform Bill. We are running our own sovereign government, regardless of what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would have us believe. We are not here to defend other nations or to overly examine their systems, because each system is different, nation by nation. We know that. Senator Sherry put up the straw man by saying that during the Thatcher years the United Kingdom entered the realms of genuine enterprise bargaining, or a totally de-regulated system, and yet, as Senator Sherry tell us, it still had a high unemployment rate of 10 per cent.

Senator Sherry quoted outdated figures from The Economist but, putting that aside, he failed to explain that the United Kingdom had faced decades of bad work practices, and it is still going through a transition and making those adjustments. But, worse than that, the United Kingdom is right on the doorstep of Europe, which is facing the worst recession since the 1930s. Frankly, it is cutting far deeper than it is here in Australia. I know this country is suffering greatly with its one million unemployed, but England and the rest of Europe is worse.

Senator Sherry failed to tell us that France has an unemployment rate of 12 to 15 per cent. Of course, he skipped over America, which has a very similar system to that in the United Kingdom and which has an unemployment rate of six per cent. We cannot compare apples and oranges. That is what Senator Sherry was trying to do. Even so, the unemployment rate in England would be far worse if it were not on the doorstep of Europe, which is facing its worst recession. We all know that England, being such a small country, is very export orientated and does not have strong commodity prices for its exports or a strong domestic market. I cannot tell honourable senators off the top of my head what the unemployment rate is in Germany, but I venture to say that it is greater than 15 per cent. So England is looking quite good to the rest of the world. Worse than that, Senator Sherry, Senator Beahan and all other government speakers—I believe Senator Burns will be getting up—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can bet on that.

—I will stick around for that because he is always entertaining. I invite Senator Burns to address what the other speakers on his side of the House have not tackled—the government's plan, its policy, for the one million unemployed. Quite frankly, that is what we are debating today on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. How are we going to unlock the one million unemployed Australians from that situation? The next five years look very bleak for the one million unemployed. This Industrial Relations Reform Bill is but one way, if not the most important way, of attempting to unlock the one million unemployed Australians. We have not heard one policy. If the government is not going to accept the genuine free enterprise bargaining policy of this side of the House, what is it going to do for the one million unemployed Australians?
—Absolutely nothing.

—Senator O'Chee tells us absolutely nothing. The government has floated the jobs levy scheme. Placing a tax on the rest of Australians is a very desperate attempt to tackle unemployment. It is absolutely no solution at all. Surely this is one opportunity to reform our industrial relations system so that employers and employees can face each other away from the unions but not away from the Industrial Relations Commission. There will be a floor in that bargaining. Employers are looking at every way to make themselves genuinely competitive and efficient. Employees are looking at every way to either get a job or to hold their job. That is the state this country is in. This Industrial Relations Reform Bill could be a major way of unlocking those one million Australians from unemployment.

PARA.TAB: It may be that those one million unemployed Australians are not listening to us on the broadcasting network and do not understand the effect that this reform bill will have upon them. Quite frankly, it is a large bill, a complex bill, a legal bill and a very in-house bill. But we know that it can help them. We know that it will immediately help one million unemployed Australians. We know that it is one of their best chances yet to get off the dole queue. We know that it will begin to make inroads into those one million unemployed Australians. If the unemployed knew that—they are depending on us to do something—I think Senator Burns would be getting phone calls in his electorate office. But they do not read these bills. They expect us to do our job.

Senator Burns has failed in doing his job. He is an old union man. Is he a union man who happens to care only about the employed, only about the enshrined position of the union, or does he genuinely care about the unemployed? I challenge him to stand up today, to put aside the rhetoric of this bill that he has been handed in his briefings by the government, to put aside the boring clause by clause discussion and tell us how he is going to unlock the one million unemployed. I would like to hear the views of Senator Burns.

Senator Burns has been down on the shop floor. He should know the pain and the hurt that comes with being unemployed, let alone being long-term unemployed. There are not many Australians who are not affected by unemployment. People's next-door neighbours, family and people down the street know the despair and the hopelessness that comes with being unemployed. It is not just the young who are unemployed. We all know that unemployment is not a very good way to start life. There are also people aged 40 to 50 or over who are unemployed. They are also greatly affected in their lives. They lose their self-respect and have nothing to do. People who have probably worked very hard as 18-year-olds and 19-year-olds are also being hurt by being unemployed.

I invite Senator Burns to cut the difference between himself and the other speakers and get straight down to the nitty-gritty. That is the challenge before him. We have all read the bill and we all know what it is about. We all know the argument of those opposite and they all know our argument. Senator Burns should get straight to it. He is an old unionist. He is not even looking up. I know he does not even have the answers. Is he trying to jot the answers down now? He has no idea at all.

Senator Burns should make a genuine contribution to the debate on this bill—this is his only area of expertise, quite frankly, he has no other expertise, but that is all right; there is nothing wrong with bringing old unionists in—for the people whom he espouses he represents, the working-class people. He should represent them. He should give us some idea how he will unlock those one million Australians from unemployment. Or are you just going to read off your brief, you drongo? I withdraw that comment, Mr Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is disgraceful.

—Senator Burns brought it out of me. I have withdrawn the comment. I know that he has no answers, and it frustrates me. Senator Burns should at least tell us whether he knows any unemployed. Has he cut himself off from his people that much? He should answer that.
—I know people who are unproductive like you.

—I am happy to take any insult that Senator Burns wants to throw at me in this chamber or outside. I invite Senator Burns to be libellous to me outside because I promise I will not slap a writ on him. I see Senator Crowley in the chamber. I do not offer the same invitation to her. I will take just about any insult from Senator Burns now and forever if he can tell me he is still in contact with his workers, that he still cares for the unemployed and that he has some real answers to get them jobs. That is quite an invitation to Senator Burns. I am asking him to throw all sorts of insults in or outside the chamber.

PARA.TAB: It is a very serious matter. All that really matters is the unemployment rate in this country. It cannot go on. It looks like it will go on for three to five years. We have to look for every little opportunity. Even if this were a small opportunity—but it is not—we should grab it. We should grab the smallest of opportunities to unlock those one million people from unemployment.

I happen to think that we have a major piece of legislation before us today. We should turn our attention towards stimulating employment in this country—we have this opportunity—yet this bill fails to make the appropriate adjustments that freely allow employers and employees the right to bargain and agree to work conditions and wages. The bill fails because it props up the very rigid award system and union power and, worse, union interference.

Once, now a very long time ago, the award system was not such a subject of debate in this country. We were far more economically secure than we are today and we were capable of absorbing wage hikes and unproductive practices. Quite frankly, we no longer have that luxury and we can no longer afford that luxury. Our backs are to the wall.

If the government and the unions have any concern or any heart for the unemployed, not just for the employed, they would allow the introduction of genuine employer and employee bargaining systems. Yet, incredibly, this legislation fails through a twisted path of ambivalent language, false perception and cumbersome structures. It would have been better if the government had left the system alone than to have introduced this so-called reform system. The legislation places an even greater block on the creation of employment for the great pool of unemployed in this country. It is accepted as a matter of commonsense by both sides of the house, the media, employer groups, such as the Business Council of Australia, and even the Treasury, that, if Australia is to pull itself towards a higher level of international competitiveness, it is vital to provide enterprise bargaining solutions to enterprise based problems.

Yet all this bill does is spread the old combative, rigid union power structures even more than before, at a time when large and small companies are scratching for every possible productivity gain to keep themselves in the marketplace. After all, if a company does not grow—this should be simple enough for Senator Burns—it does not employ. A company will shed labour or go to the wall. That is a simple fact of business life which is very much lost on the government and the unions.

Just prior to the introduction of this bill, the existing system of so-called enterprise bargaining, now to be replaced by the bill before the Senate, was never successful in freeing up the marketplace and producing productivity gains for business. It provided no more than the award being the base rate, and any agreements that were made were to be over-award payments. After all, these conditions were written into the charter of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. While this system maintained all its rigidities, it was seen and hoped to be but the first step in freeing up the system. It was the first signal to an entrenched and bloody-minded union movement that Australia needed desperately to change its industrial relations laws.

When Paul Keating addressed the Institute of Directors in April, employers were persuaded that he could deliver the goods. Other factors gave employers grounds for hope. Few really believed that the Prime Minister would deliver such a landmark speech in April on industrial relations without the blessing of the ACTU and Mr Bill Kelty. Moreover, his choice of Laurie Brereton as Minister for Industrial Relations suggested to some employers that the Prime Minister wanted to counter the ACTU's influence on policy.

Key sections of the bureaucracy, notably Treasury, have argued for a more flexible system of enterprise bargaining. It is little wonder that employers were so optimistic this time round. Instead, the union movement proved what we have all known in this country for a very long time: they are in charge. What could be more profound than the statement made in the media by Jennie George while debating the contents of the bill. This has been referred to by many speakers on this side of the house before, but it warrants repeating. Straight after the election, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: What the employers have got to understand is that we won the election—
the union movement won the election, according to Jennie George—
in March and this bill is a pay back for the commitments—
the money—
that were made by the government in the course of that election campaign.

That says it all. For all the slipping and sliding of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Laurie Brereton, he was not successful in pleading the case for real reform. He was booed, hissed and tomatoed at the ACTU congress back in August when he caved in to union demands.

PARA.TAB: The weakened proposal of the government is basically threefold: firstly, to maintain the award system with all its cumbersome approach as the base rate for negotiation; secondly, that unions are involved in every stage of negotiation when representing their members; and, thirdly, and most importantly, for the non-unionised labour, which makes up 70 per cent of the private enterprise, unions must be consulted and represented at the Industrial Relations Commission before any agreement can be accepted by the commission.

Having outlined the broad approach to this bill, in my final moments I can only say that this bill does not take us forward; in fact, it would have been better if the government had left the existing legislation alone. Sadly, this legislation does take us backwards. That is more sadly so for those in rural and regional Australia where the unemployment rate is well over the national average. In some parts of Ballarat, Bendigo and other parts of my state of Victoria, it is up to 18 to 20 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to follow Senator McGauran who has some practical knowledge of good industrial relations in the workplace. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill returns to the totally discredited 1987 Industrial Relations Bill which was withdrawn and reduces the protection available for employers against primary and secondary boycotts. It does so by restricting access both to common law and to the seriously weakened anti-boycott provisions, which have been transferred from the Trade Practices Act to the Industrial Relations Act, and by setting up a special labour court.

PARA.TAB: The opposition utterly opposes this bill. It should be withdrawn and we will do all we can to amend it or delay its passage through the Senate. It was forced through the House of Representatives without amendment on 22 November. Unfortunately, with the support of the Australian Democrats and the Greens, it will pass substantially here, but hopefully with amendments. Like other opposition senators, my fax is running hot from small businesses worried sick by this legislation. I urge the Greens and the Democrats to acknowledge the concerns of worried and decent Australian employers who are already burdened enough with Labor incompetence and industrial relations featherbedding. I have taken a few excerpts out of letters to demonstrate how small business people perceive this disastrous bill:

The government does not have a mandate from the people to enter into secret negotiations with the trade union movement, which will result in serious consequences upon the nation as a whole; employment levels and the economy.
This bill will give unions too much power and restrict small business confidence seriously.
Many people are unaware of the fine print of this bill.
The bill will bash on the head any remaining incentive for me to employ—and I'm not Robinson Crusoe!
This bill, when uncloaked, is a radical piece of proposed legislation which if passed, will strip business proprietors and employees of basic contractual rights.
This bill gives everything to the unions, and takes everything away from employers, particularly business confidence which this country so badly needs right now.
This bill places all the privilege with the unions, leaving small business—the spearhead of economic advancement and increased employment—defenceless.
This bill will put unions above the law in matters of strikes, boycotts and will discriminate against the majority of workers who are non-unionists.

SPEECH.PARA: These are mere samples of the concerns raised with me over this legislation. Labor will never attempt to govern for all Australians. I think that is perfectly clear from those letters. It rules only for its mates.

PARA.TAB: On the surface, the bill does provide for the making of industrial agreements. However, the bill provides unions with immunity from almost any legal liability, both civil and criminal, during the negotiation of a certified agreement. This immunity period will be initiated by the union and could extend for two years or longer.

As awards will become less comprehensive and more of a safety net, employees will be expected by the unions to make an enterprise agreement to cover their business. Though agreements are supposed to be voluntary, this will be an added pressure to enter into an agreement. Because of the period of immunity from liability, the relevant union will more readily be able to impose its will on employers without any restraint whatsoever from the Industrial Relations Commission and will be given the right to appear at the hearing for application for registration of the agreement.

The effective emasculation of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act will encourage boycotts to be used more frequently. Section 45D of the Trade Practices Act was effective and had quick results, as the very threat of such action brought many critical situations to a quick conclusion. A strike or primary boycott will be made completely legal in most cases. Even if a case can be made to satisfy the new watered down boycott provisions, employers will have to wait three days before they can obtain a certificate from the Industrial Relations Commission to enable them to begin legal action. By this time, many small businesses will be in severe financial difficulty.

This bill is described as an industrial relations reform bill but anyone who has looked at it and what it proposes—and debate has gone on in the community in the past month—will recognise that far from being an industrial relations reform bill, it is a trade union payback bill. This bill is paying back the trade union movement for the enormous and bigoted support it gave the government in March. This is a payback to the social and economic dinosaurs, best shown in this place by Senator Carr in his contribution last night. I include Senator Burns in that, too. The people he champions—or should I say patronises—are in the unionised work force in Victoria. Senator Carr views all workers as insipid, weak or exploited and all employers as greedy grubs. The trouble with the likes of Senator Carr is that he has not produced one dollar of wealth in his life. He is an example of the worst sort of modern Labor do-gooder.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's rubbish, and you know it.

—Senator Burns is the worst sort of old Labor do-gooder. He talks a lot; the rhetoric flows; but the tap to practical solutions has been choked by theory long ago. He, Senator Murphy and Senator Carr are pretty irrelevant. They are wind-up dolls—
—The Three Stooges.
—Yes, they are mouthing the class war rhetoric of the 1930s—or should I say the 1900s for Senator Burns?
—You want to ignore history, do you?

—Senator Burns needs to wake up because Labor's industrial relations policies have contributed significantly to Australia's experiencing the most profound economic downturn since the Great Depression—which Senator Burns probably can remember.

PARA.TAB: We have one million unemployed. What a legacy to the union movement and a Labor government that is. It is the 10-year partnership that has been trumpeted between Labor and the unions which has shamefully created the economic situation we are in now. There is no getting away from that. This bill is an 11th hour attempt to regain some respectability. Contrary to what Senator Murphy said last night, the freeing up of wages and the industrial relations system, as proposed by the coalition, would have increased productivity and competition and, more importantly, the number of jobs; jobs for almost all the one million people out of work today.

How can the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, claim to represent the interests of working men and women in Australia when he has allowed Australia's industrial relations agenda to be hijacked by the Zegna-suited union bosses now demanding their payback? Labor has aided and abetted them in this process. The Industrial Relations Bill that we are debating today will hand back considerable power to the trade unions. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, was rolled completely on enterprise bargaining. The terms are as laid down by the new labour union bosses.

The government pours taxpayers' dollars into the trade union movement and trade unions. In return, it gets support in its election campaigns. The Vice-President of the ACTU, Jennie George—Senator McGauran also quoted what she had said, but the words are worth repeating—said:

SPEECH.PARA: What the employers have got to understand is that we won the election—
absolute power corrupts—
in March and this bill is a pay back for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of that election campaign.

That is incredible. This bill will choke moves towards the true enterprise bargaining that is vital for this country to return to economic prosperity. It will make it harder and more expensive for employers to hire labour at a time when we are experiencing near record unemployment levels. This government cannot understand that until it frees up wages and the labour market, the economy will stagnate.

PARA.TAB: Labor support for compulsory unionism is undemocratic and full of humbug. The coalition's position at the last election was that we would have made it voluntary to be a member of a union, and those who joined unions would have been protected against victimisation. We would have prohibited the closed shop and removed union preference clauses in awards and agreements.

I conclude by saying that it is little wonder that union membership has been in continual decline. Workers are sick and tired of being bullied by heavy-handed unions which have only delivered higher and higher unemployment. Recent figures show that workplaces with fewer than 10 employees have only 16.3 per cent unionism; those with between 10 and 19 employees have 29.8 per cent unionism; those with between 20 and 29 employees have 46.1 per cent unionism; and workplaces with greater than 100 employees have 57.6 per cent unionism. Despite that, 67 per cent of the private sector workplaces have no union members at all. The game is up for the union movement in its present form. It knows it, workers know it and all Australians know it. It is a throwback to a more sinister time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You developed the sinister times.

—This legislation may buy it and Senator Burns another couple of years of entrenched privilege; but they should start looking for another job now. I do not recommend they come into the Senate because, for Australia's sake, we need a few people opposite who have done something with their lives.

—I probably have a point of order to raise, Mr Acting Deputy President; it is a point of clarification. I note that the honourable senator was reading his speech. Could you advise me on the ruling about speeches? I did not want to interrupt the honourable senator, but does the Senate still have a standing order that says that speeches in the large part ought not to be read?
