—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am not clear whether Senator Crowley has raised a point of order. I would like it clarified whether she is taking a point of order or seeking leave. She said that she `probably' had a point of order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—I have understood Senator Crowley to have risen on a point of order. It is in the standing orders of the Senate that senators will not read their speeches. I have observed that Senator Sandy Macdonald was using copious notes, as is quite often the practice in the Senate. There is no point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Industrial Relations Reform Bill but I indicate that the Australian Democrats have a number of amendments which we believe would improve it significantly. My colleague Senator Bell will present those at a later time. I, too, have received many faxes on this issue. In my contribution I will analyse a number of these faxes which have come from a particular and peculiar source. I do not want to simply sample the faxes, as Senator Sandy Macdonald has done, but to analyse in depth what they say.

PARA.TAB: I was also lobbied fairly extensively by a number of people who are also represented in those faxes. Many of these people come from a Christian sect known as the Exclusive Brethren. The emphasis must be on `exclusive' because they view the world as being totally hostile to them and believe in total separation from the world, except for the points at which it suits them to have contact.

They have a total right to pursue their own beliefs. There is no debate about that. But they do not have a right to impose those beliefs on the rest of the country; and certainly not to impose those beliefs on other Christians who do not agree with their particular and peculiar interpretation of scripture. I will quote one of the faxes I received. It states:
The title "reverend"—

SPEECH.PARA: referring to me—
suggests some connection with christianity,!—! and I say this.

"Be NOT DECEIVED", if you have a part in supporting this Bill, "YOU WILL BE HELD ACCOUNTABLE TO YOUR MASTER". Why has it Been kept a secret, woodley?—anything kept this quiet is beyond doubt, of a seedy and highly dubious Nature! May you not sleep until you get your priorities right. Government is of God, Unionism is of Satan, You are NOT ABOVE GOD. But held answerable to him. "Governments serve the people" the people are not enslaved to communism.

That is the tone of many of the faxes which I have received. I think it is worth putting on the record some analysis of the scriptural references which they use to show that, instead of supporting their position, trade unions have made a great contribution to industrial relations in this country and will continue to do so. I say that as a Christian—

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll put that one out in the bush.

—Senator O'Chee and those opposite need to understand this when they quote the faxes which have been received, because if they understood where those faxes were coming from I do not think even they would believe the kind of position which the people sending those faxes actually represent. I respect the right of these people to hold their opinions and to put their opinions to me, but I reject their understanding of the trade union movement and especially the way that they use scripture to support their opinion.

PARA.TAB: I turn to their use of scripture and quote particularly from one of the faxes from a business called Civiquip. One of the statements it makes is `Government is of God'. It uses a passage from Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter 13, verses 1 to 10. In this passage, Paul argues that it is the duty of citizens to obey state authorities. He is arguing that this supports the orderly functioning of society. It is a letter he wrote to Christians in Rome at a particular time—known as the Pax Romana—when there was great stability throughout the Mediterranean world, and at a time which allowed St Paul and other Christian missionaries to travel extensively in that part of the world in order to spread their message. Paul, as a Roman citizen, appealed on a number of occasions to the Roman emperor for protection from Jewish authorities whom he saw as persecuting him. So this is the context of the statement by Paul that citizens ought to obey the government.

In the same passage, he also talks of that obedience as being in the context of loving one another and of loving one's neighbour as oneself—in other words, government can operate to support the mutual relationship of citizens, one with another, and to support neighbourliness. Paul's experience at that time, as the background to the writing of this letter, was very positive with regard to government and the Roman Empire. Unfortunately, it was not many years before Paul's experience turned very sour indeed as, under the new Roman emperor, Nero, Christians were not only persecuted but many of them were executed, including Paul himself.

Eventually, from that position of being seen to be supporting good government within Rome, Christians came to be regarded as the worst of citizens. The requirement of Roman citizens under Nero was that they make a small sacrifice each year and declare that `Caesar is Lord'. Of course, the Christians' declaration was `Christ is Lord', and because of that they were seen to be very bad citizens who should be excluded from the empire. Many of them were excluded and killed.

About 40 years after the writing of Paul's letter to the Romans, the Book of Revelation was written. By this time, this benign Roman Empire had become the whore of Babylon and a horrible beast. The point I am trying to make is that one simply cannot transfer scripture across thousands of years without first understanding the historical background from which it comes. Government is of God to the extent that it supports the relationships based on the love of neighbour. In that light this legislation can be judged.

The second statement which is made is that unionism is not of God. There is no biblical reference given because the trade union movement is a relatively modern concept which had no equivalent at all in biblical times. But I would like to point to a couple of historical examples where Christians, because of their faith, became very involved in the trade union movement. One which is very important to me is the incident of the Tolpuddle martyrs. They were six Methodist lay preachers who, because of their training within the Methodist church as leaders and lay preachers, also became union organisers amongst farm labourers in England in the 19th century. They were arrested for belonging to an illegal association and were transported as convicts to Australia. They certainly understood that trade unionism was an expression of their faith. I point to the Australian experience where for many years Roman Catholics, particularly Irish Catholics, were very much at the forefront of the labour movement because of the oppression that they suffered here in Australia.

I am trying to underline that, as a Christian, I believe the trade union movement has delivered many benefits. But it is not perfect. I have some problems at times with some of the actions of the trade union movement, but, like any human institution or like any of us as human beings, we have both bad and good within our lives.

I turn to another reference which occurred time and time again in many of the faxes. I hope that the opposition really understands what this reference is saying because it is about master-servant relationships. The biblical passage is Colossians 3:22 to Colossians 4:1. The passage is not talking about master-servant relationships. The word in most of the modern English translations is the Greek word `doulos', which means `slave'. So it is talking about master-slave relationships.

The background to this passage was the conversion of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of slaves within the Roman Empire at the time when Paul wrote his letter. The question which came to Paul was: what do I do about this? Do I tell the slaves that they should revolt against their masters? He did not, in his own wisdom, make that decision. He told the slaves that they should remain in the service of their masters. To the masters, he then wrote `be fair and just in the way you treat your slaves'. Ultimately, Christians such as William Wilberforce and John Wesley opposed the slave trade and it was finally overthrown.

The point I want to make is that this passage has little application to industrial relationships today, unless we believe that the master-slave relationship is an appropriate model. Surely the opposition is not saying that when it reads to us the 300 or whatever faxes that it says it has received. I cannot believe that the opposition really could say that the master-slave relationship is an appropriate model. The principle, of course, which Paul was establishing and which eventually became something which broke open the whole of the slave trade was that we must treat one another with respect. Certainly, that is a good principle to use within industrial relationships.

But let me turn to one other passage which was not used by any of the people who sent me faxes. It is a very useful passage. It is one which underlines the problem of trying to translate social conditions of 2,000 years ago and thinking that we can simply make reference to them without some kind of background to the contemporary situation.

This is a parable, which was told by Jesus, about an employer and an industrial dispute. In the parable, the employer goes to a labour pool early in the morning and agrees with some labourers that they will work for a particular wage for that day. At the third hour, and the sixth hour, and the ninth hour and the 11th hour he hires labourers. In other words, at different times during the day he hires people to work for him. There is no discussion with the later workers about the wage they should be paid. At the end of the day he pays them all the same amount. Of course, they complain. The employer says, `Friend, I am doing you no wrong. Did you not agree with me to work for a denarius? Take what belongs to you and go. I choose to give to this last as I give to you. Am I not allowed to do what I choose with what belongs to me or do you begrudge my generosity?'.

What is the meaning of the parable? I suppose we could, if we wanted to, simply carry it across without any interpretation and say that payment need not bear any relation to quantity or quality of work done. I am certain that the opposition would not want to support that proposition. It underlines the difficulty of transferring biblical concepts to the contemporary situation.

This parable is not really about industrial relationships, although it is about an industrial dispute. It is rather about the nature of God's dealing with humanity. As we understand it, the amount quoted by the employer as the agreed wage was the amount needed to support a family for one day. So the proportional wage which would have been paid for the late workers could never have been adequate. They would have been left destitute. The point the parable is making is that God's generosity or grace is based on human need, not on the ability to bargain for a better deal for the strong over the weak.

The principle is that social intercourse ought to mirror God's determination and generosity to the disadvantaged and marginalised. Whenever trade unions follow these principles, to that extent they fulfil the purpose of God. I believe that often in early movements for social justice they did just that. However, when a trade union or any human institution, including this parliament, fails to protect those at the bottom and advantages only those on top, then that institution is outside the purpose of God for both human and industrial relationships.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Woodley for assisting me in the order of the speakers on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993. I got caught up on a parliamentary committee and, unfortunately, was not here when I was due to speak. So I thank him and thank the whips for making the arrangements.

PARA.TAB: This morning we are discussing, at the second reading stage, the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. It is a very significant piece of legislation. Like all significant pieces of legislation that go through this parliament, the intent of the legislation gets distorted by some with a vested interest in it and by others who merely seek to distort it. I would like to direct my remarks to some of those distortions this morning and hopefully correct them and clear up what this bill is about.

Before I do so, I want to acknowledge the fact that some of my constituents, particularly the employers in Western Australia, have also been sending me faxes. I dare say that every senator is receiving them. But, unfortunately, I have not yet had time to address and respond to those faxes. I certainly will do so. If any of the people who have attempted to make contact with me in the past few days are listening to this speech, I will lay it down very clearly for them now that I am strongly supporting this piece of legislation.

In strongly supporting it, I also commend the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Laurie Brereton, for bringing the legislation to the floor of the parliament. It has been a long time coming and we are aware of the enormous amount of work that he personally, his staff and the departmental officers have put into bringing this legislation before the Senate of Australia today. He is to be commended for that.

In commending and acknowledging his role in things, we must not forget the groundwork that had previously been put in by his predecessor in the portfolio, Senator Peter Cook. He is a colleague of mine from Western Australia. Senator Cook laid the groundwork for it. I am sure that, if he were in the chamber today, he too would be commending it and be very pleased that the culmination of his work, and that of Mr Brereton, is coming to the fore and that shortly we will be passing the bill.

I had expected to see on the desks in the chamber some amendments that may be being proposed by opposition members. After their escapades a couple of weeks ago, I expected opposition members would seek the disbandment of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and its replacement by the estimates committees. We saw rather a furphy here a couple of weeks ago where a matter of industrial relations was, in turn, going to be referred to an estimates committee. I am surprised that they have not been consistent and stuck with that and referred all matters of industrial relations to estimates committees. We will see how useful estimates committees can be in the resolution of industrial disputes.

That aside, I want to address some of the furphies that have been attached to this bill. In particular, what has riled me, apart from the distortions that have been directly presented to me, is an advertisement that was placed in the Australian press, certainly in my state of Western Australia, on 23 November this year which criticised the government's Industrial Relations Reform Bill on a number of grounds. The criticisms, of course, were inaccurate, misleading and caused some concern in the community by those who believe everything they read in newspapers. That is a problem in one instance, but when we end up believing what is in advertisements we, unfortunately, are going to have some problems. They certainly gave me some concern that advertisements of this nature appear and people get the wrong impression of what government action is about.The first point that was made in the advertisement that attracted my attention said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill could give trade unions a lawful right to interfere in your workplace agreements with your employees.

Of course, the bill does not provide unions with any form of automatic right to interfere in the workplace agreements between employers and employees. The fact of life is that currently in Australia, in all states and territories, trade unions, in the most enterprising of places, play a role in how the enterprise is being managed and being run. When a union operates with the agreement of an employer, it plays a productive and constructive role in an enterprise agreement. It was very irresponsible of the persons who paid for this advertisement to print such a contrary lie on the role of trade unions.

PARA.TAB: The bill provides for two enterprise agreements: certified agreements made directly with the employers and unions and flexible enterprise agreements made directly between the employer and employee. If no union is involved in a particular workplace there is no need for union involvement. That has raised concern amongst some of my colleagues in the trade union movement, but it is a fact of life that there is no union representation in some workplaces in Australia because the workers have chosen not to belong to a trade union. So those people will have the right if they wish to directly enter a flexible enterprise agreement with their employer and have it ratified in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

Even if unions are part of a workplace which negotiates an enterprise agreement, they will have no veto over what happens in that agreement. If the majority of workers within the enterprise democratically decide they want to be part of an enterprise agreement with their employer, the union will not be able to veto that agreement. So, hopefully, this bill will put to bed hereafter the lie that this legislation will give trade unions a lawful right to interfere in the workplace. The second distortion that appeared in the advertisement stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill explicitly protects unions from almost any action against themselves by employers seeking protection from oppressive boycott or intimidatory action.
Again, that is a distortion of reality, a distortion of the truth, and it does not well serve those people who paid for the advertisement to stretch their imagination to this length.

PARA.TAB: The bill does not protect unions against employer action in the case of illegal secondary boycotts. Unions will be held liable if they are engaged in unlawful actions. The bill adopts a commonsense approach which should have been taken years ago. Senator Cook was very keen about this and, upon his departure from the industrial relations portfolio, would love to have had this approach credited to his name. The bill transfers sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act 1974 to the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Senator Cook worked long and hard to try to bring about this commonsense change in this country's industrial legislation. That change has now come to fruition and I again acknowledge the role that Senator Cook played. Those comments are not meant to detract from anything Mr Brereton has achieved here today.

The transfer of the provisions of the Trade Practices Act to the Industrial Relations Act confines the operation of those provisions to secondary boycotts, which also covers a wide range of primary boycotts and provides exemptions for certain action—for example, peaceful picketing. Not all picketing is unruly; in fact, very little picketing is unruly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ones you were on were.

—Those pickets were not unruly. I am glad Senator Panizza has come in to help me along. In my life I have never been part of an unruly picket line. And I have been part of a few picket lines both before entering the trade union movement and since being elected as a political representative. I have never been part of an unruly picket line and I have never encouraged any unlawfulness or unruliness on a picket line.

PARA.TAB: The transfer of these provisions to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission requires the AIRC in both secondary boycotts and common law actions to conciliate between the parties before either party can seek a remedy from the court. This approach is designed to find and bring about a lasting resolution to industrial differences and recognises that litigation often hardens the attitudes of the parties, making a smooth return to work much more difficult.

Even when there is a return to work after very divisive and difficult industrial conflict, it is not always a satisfactory result because, in many cases, the action has left a bad taste and coloured the different attitudes. Many employers around Australia who have corrected their previous bad practices have found that such litigation does not lend itself to good industrial relations or good productivity.

The provisions transferring these matters to the Industrial Relations Commission also contain a number of protective clauses. Conciliation will be limited to 72 hours, after which either party will be free to seek a remedy from the court if so desired. When it is clear that conciliation will not resolve a dispute or where the damage is likely to be so serious that it would be inappropriate to delay legal action, the AIRC may allow immediate access to the court. Injunctions and damages will be available to the new Industrial Relations Court for breaches of the secondary boycott provisions. The advertisement went on with another distortion:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill allows trade unions to vet and monitor every job interview and termination in your business.

That is a load of bull. It is a load of codswallop because the bill does nothing of the sort. Unfortunately, the advertisement did not go on to say exactly where the bill states that trade unions would be allowed to vet and monitor job interviews and terminations. The writers of this advertisement could not do so because the bill contains no such provision—the bill does not deal with recruitment or job interviews.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly pleased, though, that the bill does address some aspects of job termination. The bill establishes minimum notice periods of termination of employment based on years of service and protection against unfair dismissal, including a general requirement for procedural fairness in dismissals. Trade unions will have a right to be consulted in those cases of terminations that are limited to redundancies of 15 or more people for economic, technological, structural or similar reasons. So, if somebody wants to get rid of 14 people for another reason, there is no compulsion on that person to make direct contact with the union.

The bill provides for unfair dismissals to be determined in the Industrial Relations Court. I am particularly pleased to see this provision in the bill. When I was a shop steward, I was dismissed on three occasions by my respective employers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us a bit more about it. What were you up to?

—I was dismissed mainly for my trade union activity as a shop steward. On one occasion it was almost instant dismissal, but on two other occasions I was given one week's notice. My workmates stood beside me and my union, the then AMWU, the metalworkers union, and I retained my job. One occasion did provoke small strike action, but we did not have the ability to approach the commission on the clear grounds of unfair dismissal. The employer knew that, but he just wanted to get rid of me.

PARA.TAB: If there is a case of unfair dismissal or a suspicion that it may be unfair, under this bill the union and the worker can take the matter before the Industrial Relations Court, which can make decisions on the matter or indeed the matter can be referred to the AIRC for conciliation to avoid the need to rule on the matter at all.The advertisement went on with another distortion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The bill takes away the freedom of employers and employees to decide how to operate their enterprise.

We have got to give it to the person who thought up that because, again, it is a gross distortion of the truth. One would have to think that the individual who dreamt this line up had not even read the bill or the explanatory memorandum and had not read the media reports—and there were many—when the negotiations on these particular changes were going on.

PARA.TAB: Clearly this bill does not take away the freedom of employers and employees to decide how to operate their enterprise. In fact, it does the opposite. By extending enterprise bargaining to the non-union sector and encouraging the use of enterprise flexibility clauses in awards the legislation increases the flexibility available to enterprises. That is quite the reverse of what is stated in the advertisement of 23 November. Included in the bill is the flexibility to vary award conditions, providing the employees are not disadvantaged. The advertisement went on with yet another distortion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The bill forces ILO rules on employers—the ILO is described as a `left wing alliance which this government—
the Australian government—
has made Australia become a signatory to'.

Australia is certainly a signatory to the International Labour Organisation. It is interesting to see who actually signed up to become a signatory organisation of the ILO. It was one Mr W. M. Hughes, who was Prime Minister of a nationalist government back in 1919 at the formation of the International Labour Organisation.

PARA.TAB: We are as a nation indeed part of the ILO and we have ratified 53 ILO conventions, 22 of which were ratified under non-Labor governments. As to whether the ILO is a left-wing alliance or not, it is interesting to cast one's mind across the member nations of the ILO. We find that there are actually 166 member nations of the ILO. One that springs to mind immediately when I am looking for left-wing nations is the United States of America. The United Kingdom is also a member, as is France, as is Germany, as is Canada and so the list goes on. They cannot be said to be a left-wing alliance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the Italians there?

—Senator Panizza asked whether the Italians are there. I am very pleased to report that the Italians are there, just below Israel and in front of Jamaica. So 166 nations are part of it. I will not waste the time of the Senate by reading each and every one of the nation states listed there.

PARA.TAB: I hope in my short address this morning that I have been able to put a stop to, or at least a balance on, what I consider to be a very dreadful advertisement—part of a smear campaign—on this very constructive and productive legislation. In closing, I commend the minister and his predecessor for bringing the legislation to the parliament. I certainly hope and I am confident that Australia will benefit from the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address just a small aspect of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and cognate bills which deal with the proposal to set up an Industrial Relations Court. It is a matter which concerns me greatly. There are four reasons why I would oppose the inception of such a body.

PARA.TAB: My first reason for opposing this proposal is that the government has not demonstrated any need whatsoever to set up a new industrial relations court. In fact, in 1976 the Federal Court was invested with the industrial division and since then has adequately dealt with this area of law. I see no reason whatsoever for there to be a change in this practice. As such, the Federal Court, through its specialist division, has had to deal with the interpretation and enforcement of awards and has also had to determine disputes involving registered organisations and references of questions of law from the Industrial Relations Commission.

Nowhere has the government given any cogent reason for such a new body to be set up. The government is proposing by the stroke of a hand to abolish an entire division of the Federal Court. It is really quite extraordinary that we have such a proposal before us without any supporting evidence or argument.

My second reason for opposing this proposal is that the taxpayer will unnecessarily incur a significant additional expense. The current budget allowance for the Federal Court and the Family Court is $164 million per year, including court construction. In these hard times we need to look very carefully at additional government spending. We also need to look at limiting the creation of further bureaucracies. There is an old saying that if there is no need for the new bureaucracy then it becomes necessary not to have the new bureaucracy. I say to the Senate that it is necessary for there to be no change for the reasons I have outlined. The Federal Court is doing an admirable job and there is just no need for this additional expenditure.

The third reason is to maintain the independence of the judiciary. The Law Council of Australia has had much to say on this aspect of the proposed legislation. It is perhaps an essential principle of our system of government that the judiciary maintain its independence from the executive arm of government and the legislature.

In the Australian Financial Review today Mr Mansfield QC, the President of the Law Council of Australia, was reported as saying that he feared that if such a court was set up its independence from government could not be guaranteed. In fact, the Law Council of Australia in a letter to me dated 3 December 1993 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed new Court, in those circumstances may be vulnerable (whether fairly or not) to the suspicion that it will not be as independent and impartial as the Federal Court.

One runs the danger in setting up such a specialist judicial body of its being seen to be influenced by government. On the other hand, simply having an industrial division in a court such as the Federal Court, with all its might, gives that division a perception of independence founded quite correctly on the basis that one would not expect a body such as the Federal Court to be subject to government influence.

PARA.TAB: The fourth reason is that it is generally undesirable to establish specialist judicial bodies. In the last 10 years this country has seen a growth of such tribunals and I do not believe in any way that it serves the ends of justice. It may be seen that a specialist judicial body is set up to advance a certain social purpose and that as such it is more an extension of the arm of policy than of the judiciary. That is another aspect that I find disturbing in relation to the setting up of such a specialist body.

The Federal Court is quite capable of dealing with the industrial jurisdiction. It has its own division to deal with that jurisdiction and I believe that it has dealt with that jurisdiction quite admirably. The Law Council of Australia is also of that view, and I ask the Senate to bear in mind the comments attributed to the President of the Law Council.

In relation to this one aspect of the legislation, there are four cogent reasons why this proposed Industrial Relations Court should not be set up. Firstly, the government has not proposed or advanced a cogent reason for the setting up of such a court. Secondly, the cost to the taxpayer would be substantial and there is no substantiation for such cost. Thirdly, there is the question of maintaining the independence of the judiciary, an essential part of our system. Finally, specialist judicial bodies have not served the ends of justice as well as people might think they have. In fact, they could be seen as bodies of policy more than judicial bodies.

I conclude by reminding the Senate of a recent report on the cost of justice delivered by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. In Australia, the cost of justice is getting out of hand. We do not need more bureaucratic bodies with more forms, more costs, more employees and more public servants. We simply do not need that, and the citizens of this country who would need to avail themselves of that judicial system do not need it either.

There are compelling arguments against the institution of this Industrial Relations Court. I do not think that it advances the government's proposals in this legislation in any way. Really, the setting up of this court can only have a detrimental effect. I cannot see it benefiting the people of Australia in any way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise to support the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993 and to congratulate the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) for their formulation and presentation to the parliament. At the outset, I would like to make some comments in response to a number of remarks from honourable senators opposite.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sandy Macdonald suggested that this legislation would put the unions above the law. They have never been above the law; when they have broken the law they have been penalised in accordance with it. Is he not smart enough, educated enough, knowledgeable enough to realise that when this legislation is promulgated it will be the law and it will be a question for judicial bodies in this country to decide on its superior jurisdiction over other laws that are in place?

The honourable senator was also nasty enough to get personal and suggest that I have done nothing with my life. I have spent some 40 years in the trade union movement. Most of my efforts I would call, and other people would call, unselfish. I have been concerned with the community in general and not with trying to accrue assets to myself through private business. By saying that, I am not suggesting that all private business people are evil. I will allow history to judge my role in society when both the honourable senator and I have gone, and history will make the comparison.

Senator McGauran raised the matter of unemployment. The unemployment situation is affected by a number of factors. In this country we have embraced the proposition of a world economy, reducing tariffs in the long-term interests of not only this nation but all the trading nations of the world. We have decided, on the initiative of the unions for the most part, to embrace the proposition of using the highest levels of technology and seeking the cooperation of employers in introducing and using the best possible methods of management to reduce areas of conflict at the workplace. We have done all of these things.

However, in the process of using the highest levels of technology, better management strategies, and in changing workplace philosophy and approach, many jobs have been destroyed. They have been destroyed through our seeking competitiveness with other countries—enabling us to earn income through world trade which is then passed on to the community. It is stupid to suggest that, because we put in place a proposal which would guarantee minimum wages, we do not care about unemployment.

The government clearly believes that the setting of minimum wages and conditions is not responsible for unemployment. The key factor in our current high rate of unemployment is lack of demand, not higher labour costs. Yes, we are concerned, and we have introduced all these macro-economic changes to minimise unemployment but, at the same time, for the sake of the broader picture, we have introduced legislation which provides a social wage and assists those people who are worse off than others.

The bills were clearly intended to create two things. One was the provision of a safety net to maintain the awards system at a particular level for those who cannot negotiate—for example, those who may be in industries where the capacity to create wealth is lessened because their products are in less demand or their cost is slightly higher. The other was to free up the process of labour and the process of management so that we could be much more creative, flexible and productive, thereby improving our wealth creation capacity.

Senator O'Chee and others have talked about my going back 100 years in history. I want to go back to 1947, to the judgment of the Full Court in the standard hours inquiry in order to show that attitudes have not changed a great deal over the years. The judgment says:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been the historic role of employers to oppose workers' claims for increased leisure. They have, as is well known, opposed in Parliament and everywhere every step in this direction, and this case is no exception. The arguments have not much changed in 100 years. Employers have feared such changes as threats to profits and added obstacles to production, a limitation upon industrial expansion, and a threat to internal and international trade relations. Steadily, first in one country then in another, this opposition has been overcome until great institutions, like the International Labour Organisation in the international arena, this Court in this country, and legislatures both here and elsewhere have declared the desirability of added leisure. History has invariably proved this foreboding of employers to be unfounded.

That same attitude is being expressed by employers today. One reason for looking at the need for minimum awards is to examine existing attitudes to what people should be paid, the level below which wages should not go, and the sorts of conditions in which people should work.

PARA.TAB: I also wish to quote from the Harvester decision, which goes back even further but which still has relevance. Those who ignore history are bound to repeat it. On page three of the decision it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The provision for fair and reasonable remuneration is obviously designed for the benefit of employees in the industry; and it must be meant to secure to them something which they cannot get by the ordinary system of individual bargaining with employers.

Even then, even though the industrial relations field did not operate in a sophisticated way, industrial commissions and courts understood that the capacity of individuals to bargain with employers was very limited, and it has not changed today except for the fact that employers have become more skilled at that game.

PARA.TAB: In my 40 years as a trade unionist I have met some very fair and decent employers who have been driven by a desire to maximise their profits within the boundaries of reasonable behaviour. However, I have met a lot of terrible ones, and I am sure I will meet more before I leave this planet. The judgment continued:

SPEECH.PARA: If Parliament meant that the conditions shall be such as they can get by individual bargaining—if it meant that those conditions are to be fair and reasonable, which employees will accept and employers will give, in contracts of service—there would have been no need for this provision. The remuneration could safely have been left to the usual, but unequal, contest, the "higgling of the market" for labour, with the pressure for bread on one side, and the pressure for profits on the other. The standard of "fair and reasonable" must, therefore, be something else; and I cannot think of any other standard appropriate than the normal needs of the average employee, regarded as a human being living in a civilized community. I have invited counsel and all concerned to suggest any other standard; and they have been unable to do so. If, instead of individual bargaining, one can conceive of a collective agreement—an agreement between all the employers in a given trade on the one side, and all the employees on the other—it seems to me that the framers of the agreement would have to take, as the first and dominant factor, the cost of living as a civilized being.
The judgment goes on to say:

If A lets B have the use of his horses, on the terms that he give them fair and reasonable treatment, I have no doubt that it is B's duty to give them proper food and water, and such shelter and rest as they need; and, as wages are the means of obtaining commodities, surely the State, in stipulating for fair and reasonable remuneration for the employees, means that the wages shall be sufficient to provide these things, and clothing, and a condition of frugal comfort estimated by current human standards.

When we talk about maintaining the award situation, we are saying that awards can be assured by way of arguments in the commission and in the main—as has always been the case—they will be based on what is happening in the community. I just make the point that in the future, because of changes that have taken place in the world and because of the enormous amounts of resources that are taken out of the world's capacity by the advanced nations of the world—nations like China, some of the other Asian nations and some of the eastern European countries which are now seeking to lift their living standards—we may well have a reduction of living standards in this country to accommodate reasonableness in the world. But it should be on the basis of equity, and people should not continue to make huge profits while others certainly do not have a reasonable standard of living.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding the sort of attitude that was held by the trade unions, in 1982, if I recall, before the election, we made an agreement with the Labor government on wages and conditions, training, safety and health in industry. Amongst those things was an agreement by the trade unions that we would allow certain elements of revenue from businesses, which could easily have gone to wages if we continued to seek higher wage levels, to go to employers and to owners of businesses as profit. We allowed them to redirect wage increases into profits. We took low wages and allowed employers to go into a profit situation. This was not an unselfish approach. On behalf of our members, we explained to employers why it was a good proposition, and we were able to do that.

The power of trade unions lies in their ability to go to their members and talk to them about what policy should be, about where the future lies and about what should be done in their interests and in the community interest. After all, trade unions are representative bodies of a particular group of people in the community and, while they do have concern for community values and community interests, they cannot serve their membership if they do not focus on the interests of those members.

History has shown very clearly that, if left up to the community, it certainly will not go to bat of its own initiative, nor will it respond to reasonable requests from those people in the work force who might be badly done by. So those people have had to make their own way and make their own arguments to achieve what they see as a reasonable proposition. That is the importance of the safety net. The safety net will provide minimum amounts; it will not provide maximum amounts.

On the question of negotiated agreements, two kinds of attitude exist in the community. We have employers who are totally wedded to the idea of maximising their profits and who see their employees only as a debit, only as a liability within the community—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course they want to maximise profits; they want to keep people in jobs.

—I know Senator Brownhill is not like that. He has had people work for him over time whom he regards as very good friends. I understand that. I would never accuse him of being a bad employer, but I do get upset when he tries to defend bad employers. I will refer to a couple of voluntary employment agreements. I love the word `agreement' because in the first one there never was any agreement. The Continental Cup Co. decided to say to its employees, `Here is a voluntary agreement—sign it or else'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The first three months of employment will be classed as a probationary period . . . Employees will be required to work 12 hour shifts either:—

PARA.TAB: Night Shift6 p.m. to 6 a.m.
Day Shift6 a.m. to 6 p.m..

SPEECH.PARA: Shifts are scheduled as follows:—
3 days on—2 days off; 2 days on—3 days off.
All employees must clock on and off every shift.
As though one needs to put that in an agreement. It continues:
WAGES/SALARY
Weekly wages have been calculated to include all allowances; penalty rates, loadings etc., the only exclusion being overtime which will be paid to permanent employees at their designated hourly rate.

It clearly means that if you are a casual you do not get overtime; you just work whatever hours at any time of the day or night—it does not matter about your family life or any rights you might have socially—and you get the ordinary rate of pay. It continues:
Wages/salaries will be paid directly into an ANZ Bank Access Account. All wages/salary packages will be reviewed annually.

They will not be negotiated; they will be reviewed. The employer will say, `I think you are getting too much, so we will reduce it'. That is what it is about. John Howard and all his friends on the other side of the chamber want flexibility on the basis of reducing wages and worsening conditions. That is what it is all about. Otherwise, they would support our legislation. The document goes on with the provision of sick leave:
Notification of non-attendance has been received at least 3 hours prior to commencement of the shift.
The document then mentions a doctor's certificate. That agreement is a straight-out situation of an employer who has no concern about people as human beings telling people what they must accept.

PARA.TAB: A fairly comprehensive agreement has been reached between the Metal Trades Federation of Unions and the MTIA. It consists of three headings: award restructuring, enterprise bargaining, and wages and superannuation. The agreement does not go into detail. Both of those groups of people have had enough experience—they are fairly skilled in the areas of industrial relations and negotiating—to know what is a reasonable request and whether, if a ridiculous proposition is put up, it is serious or not. They understand those things. This agreement says:
The agreement reached by the parties facilitates macro wage outcomes which we believe are economically sustainable . . .

SPEECH.PARA: So they are looking for a wage which will give people a reasonable amount and still proceed to give the business a profit which it can then use in research and development, new products, new machinery and other processes by which management can become more efficient and work better with its labour. The agreement says it will:
. . . clear the way for managements and employees in enterprises throughout the metal and engineering industry to achieve a significant breakthrough in a drive for higher productivity.
Higher productivity is hardly a negative attitude by trade unions. The agreement continues:

PARA.TAB: The parties agree that the international pressures on Australia's metal and engineering industry make the achievement of higher productivity absolutely imperative.

SPEECH.PARA: It did not take trade unions long to understand that things change because of the world trade position and that the engineering industry was not very efficient. Most of the machine tools were 50 years old some 20 or 30 years ago. That is not the case any more. The unions knew that the industry was not very efficient and pushed for this idea. It was not thrust upon them; it was a matter of negotiation, of people seeing the light and going in a direction that would be helpful not only to them but to the whole community. The agreement continues:

PARA.TAB: The parties agree that the settlement represents an important opportunity for all enterprises to make the industry a better place in which to work and invest, to maintain industries in Australia and to develop their export potential.
This opportunity must not be squandered by applying the terms of the agreement in a negative way—

SPEECH.PARA: that means both sides—
or, alternatively, by failing to implement the wide range of options which the agreement opens up for greater efficiency in the organisation of work.

That agreement is a collective approach to try to better productivity levels. A difference of opinion has now developed between the parties. The parties were embracing the process of developing skills, both horizontally and vertically, in a way that had never been considered before. The unions were very clear that there should be academic training as well as on-the-job training and that, as people reached a certain level of ability, understanding, skill and knowledge, they should be recognised by some sort of certificate entitling them to be able to go to another employer when unemployed or when seeking permanent employment and say, `Here are my qualifications; there is my level of skill'. At the moment, the employers are suggesting that there should an informal arrangement. There is some argument about it, but I am sure it can be worked out within the spirit of this agreement. The agreement continues:

PARA.TAB: While the commitment of MTIA and all levels of the metal unions to making the agreement work will be supportive and facilitative, the onus rests with individual company managements and the workforce to make the agreement fully productive.

SPEECH.PARA: That has already happened. I recall talking to some of the top management people from BHP at a caucus meeting some years ago. They informed me very clearly that, as far as they were concerned, workers were now an asset and not a burden on the company. The development of their skills and making the best use of their productive capacity were important to the company. Other companies had the same view and have been appreciative of the fact that workers on the job have the capacity to make a very real and important contribution.

PARA.TAB: But these things are going to happen only if trust is developed. These things are going to happen only if people feel that they are part of the organisation, that they are getting a reasonable wage, that the organisation has somewhat of a social conscience, that they produce some products that are desirable in the community, that those products are of good quality, that their delivery is reasonable, and that those standards can be maintained. That, therefore, meets all the desires of people who want to see everyone benefit, including the community generally. The agreement continues:

The objective of greater international competitiveness which is an integral part of the agreement is essential, not only for the benefit of people at every level of the metal and engineering industry, but also for the viability of the Australian economy and the level of living standards it can sustain.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is a very good document. I spoke with Senator Crane about it one day. He pointed out that this document is quite different from others he had seen. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

Through an exhaustive negotiating process, the agreement has succeeded, we believe in meeting the legitimate concerns which both parties had at the outset of the negotiations. It does so in a way which is economically responsible, while facilitating continued progress on award restructuring, training initiatives and improving the industrial culture.

The parties are of the view that the agreement provides an important framework to assist industry development in Australia, and strongly encourage all enterprises to take the opportunity to implement the agreement as rapidly as possible.
The parties will be taking the first opportunity to submit the agreement to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission with a view to its early implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the bill. I think it will help everybody in the nation, not just employees who will get a reasonable opportunity to get good wages and conditions under these provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Reform Bill is supposed to be about reform. It is supposed to have been drafted by a party that understands industrial relations. Why is it, then, that I have hundreds of letters in my office from ordinary people in the community—many of them quite possibly Labor voters—who are utterly and totally opposed to the legislation?

PARA.TAB: This bill was a long time in drafting. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) claims he consulted widely with those who will be most affected by it, but I sincerely doubt that. He consulted with the unions. He has done what the ACTU told him to do. Obviously, he has paid it back for the help and assistance it gave during the election campaign. But he failed to consult with the employers—the ones whom Senator Burns has just been attacking. The employers have the ability to employ people. He did not consult with those people who have the ability to create jobs. He did not consult with those people charged with the responsibility of finding wages each week so they can pay their employees and keep them off the dole. That is what is really wrong with this legislation.

The minister failed to find out what employers wanted reformed in the present industrial relations system in order to help them to better working relations with their employees. He failed to understand that a successful industrial relations policy must contain mutually beneficial agreement between employer and employee. It has to be like a good marriage. There has to be a good coming together of the two parties to make sure that they will consummate a good working relationship. The minister failed to understand that we have to compete in the world market. We cannot go through our lives thinking we are in isolation here in Australia, with different types of strictures and different sets of rules and conditions which make us uncompetitive.

This bill was supposed to be about consultation. In reality, it will be about confrontation. I have received close to 200 letters in my office since yesterday from ordinary Australians trying to make a living in today's tough economic conditions. They have come from electricians, cabinet-makers, motor mechanics, landscapers, orchardists and steel fabricators. They have asked for more consultation on the bill. They have asked for whole passages to be disallowed and they are frightened. I will quote from a few of those letters. This one comes from Moss Vale. It states:

I am an employer and will be affected detrimentally if this legislation be passed. How? Because at every step in administering my business I would be forced to negotiate with a non-government, irresponsible body (namely the union movement). Even the most naive person would understand the far-reaching implications, ruin of our businesses and the national economy!

SPEECH.PARA: Let me quote another letter. This one comes from Minto in New South Wales. It states:
The Industrial Relations Bill to be before the Senate today, will if enacted, have disastrous consequences to my manufacturing business. Some items of this Bill MUST be disallowed.
1.Non union labour, which represents in excess of 70% of the work force, must not be discriminated against.
That is what the government is trying to do. It will try to discriminate against the 70 per cent of the work force who are not members of unions. The letter continues:
Anti discrimination laws would be violated.
2.Denying the employer the right to protection of the law by legalising the unrestrained union inspired right to strike is unthinkable.

3.Removal of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act will lead to unprecedented union boycotting of businesses, and that, with protection of the Law! is totally unacceptable and is unconstitutional.
The letter goes on to say:

The needs of the small business sector must be considered. It must be realised that this sector is the kernel of this country's existence and if allowed to be crippled by the effects of this Bill then complete collapse of the economy is inevitable.
I refer to another letter. This one comes from an orchardist in Orange. It states:
I have a teenage family and run an agricultural business and am alarmed at this legislation.
So it goes on. I take another letter at random. This one comes from Wilberforce. It states:
I am outraged to perceive what the Government is trying to put through Parliament.
I am an employer of a non-union workshop in a so-called free country. I have found that the Government is intending to legalise a system of bondage. Where is our liberty?

The coalition's objections to this legislation are quite clear. It is quite clear what those people in the community are thinking about it as well. Our objections are well known, and they have the support of most non-unionist workers—that 70-odd per cent; perhaps closer to 80 per cent—in the country.

PARA.TAB: Legislation will not make the union movement more popular with the workers. If unions want members they have to work for those members—not legislate to ensure that the unions get them. The sad thing is that here we have a government which is trying to enshrine in legislation a membership that will give it the money to fight election campaigns. I have another letter. It comes from an earth boring company in rural New South Wales. What does it say? It states:

SPEECH.PARA: From our 35 years experience of the militancy of trade union delegates on building sites, we know that the proposed Industrial Relations Reform Bill will be a disaster for builders and subcontractors. The Giles report partly exposed the violence & corruption that then existed.

In Australia it is not the weakness of the trade union movement that is crippling the country; it is the weakness of the economy, the lack of competitiveness, the lack of a will to deliver quality goods on time and a lack of productivity. But this bill does not address any of those issues. It enshrines the power of the unions, it outlaws all forms of discrimination in the workplace, except the one discriminatory practice that is most common—that is, discrimination against the non-unionist—yet non-unionists, as I said, make up 70-odd per cent of the work force. This legislation discriminates in favour of 20-odd per cent of the work force and discriminates against 70-odd per cent. Where is the balance and equity in that? The majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training said:
The Committee is confident that the reforms proposed in this Bill will serve Australia well as the basis for an industrial relations system that is open to all.

The coalition senators on that committee disagreed with that conclusion and, from the correspondence that I have received, so do most, if not all, of the 70-odd per cent of non-unionist workers. A large number of employers and business witnesses who came before the committee were clearly not of that view.

PARA.TAB: To suggest that the bill is a sound basis for industrial relations in this country is an outrageous exaggeration: for example, the requirement that unions be involved in the development of certified agreements and enterprise flexibility agreements. Small business will continue to remain outside the industrial relations structure because the hurdles involved are too great and too high. How does that reform the present system? How does that ensure that workers are protected against unscrupulous employers? It will not. Apart from what Senator Burns said, it will not.

As Senator Parer told the Senate last night, this legislation is no more or less than a payback to the ACTU for delivering another term of office to the Labor Party. That it did so under false pretences and by outrageously misleading scare campaigns seemed to have been forgotten. Given our track record overseas as an unreliable supplier, a country with uncertain quality control, with heads of state who clearly do not know how to behave in national forums, such as our present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and unions who manage to go on strike at the most inappropriate times and for the most spurious of reasons, I would have thought that this government would be keen to establish legislation that works on improving the image of our work force. This legislation will not do that. It merely transfers even more power to those whose names never appear on the ballot paper but who, nevertheless and assuredly, control what this government does and how it does it.

I suppose that helps to explain why the Labor Party is prepared to introduce this obnoxious bill. It does not explain, however, why the Australian Democrats are prepared to support it. Maybe the Greens will think of not supporting it. It remains to be determined why the Democrats have chosen to support it. Perhaps further down the track we will be wiser. In the meantime, all Australians will have to suffer yet another piece of iniquitous legislation. One of the recommendations of the dissenting report, signed by Senator Chapman and Senator Crane, of the inquiry into the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government withdraws the bill and enters into full, proper and meaningful consultation with all parties to produce a bill which encourages direct negotiations between employers and employees to achieve the productivity gains Australia needs to reduce unemployment and improve living standards.

This bill will not do what the minister purports; it will do completely the opposite. It will put Australia back behind the eight-ball again as regards competitiveness on the world markets and the recovery that we hope will soon happen will be decimated. I ask the Greens, who are sitting in the chamber at the moment, to think of defeating this bill, to consider voting against it, to ensure that we do not have legislation that will definitely hurt the work force and hurt the employers that create the jobs in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be stated at the outset that the Greens WA believe that, as a nation, we must rethink the concept of work. Whilst many Australians unsuccessfully seek paid work, many others in paid work are working to the point of illness.

PARA.TAB: The Greens welcome many aspects of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, especially those aimed at guaranteeing minimum standards of employment with respect to wages, equal pay for equal work, termination of employment and unpaid parental leave. It is particularly important that these be national standards in times when working conditions are under attack in a number of states. The Greens consider that the use of international conventions to allow the federal government to provide a safety net for workers is both appropriate and necessary.

The main thrust of the bill, however, is to promote enterprise bargaining, and the Greens have considerable doubts over the motives behind the introduction of enterprise bargaining and the ways in which it is being pushed upon the Australian work force as part of a worldwide trend for labour market deregulation associated with the increasing mobility of capital and the obsession with attracting multinational investment. Employers and the major political parties are all extolling enterprise bargaining and labour market deregulation in general as the solution to Australia's industrial woes. The Greens believe that this view distracts us from the real issue, namely, the poor performance of Australian management.

Many Australian employers seem to want to perpetuate the `us' and `them' dichotomy between management and workers and are well behind international best practice in creating workplaces that run on cooperation and participation rather than hierarchies. Just as financial deregulation caused as many ills as it cured, so may inappropriate labour market deregulation. It is also conveniently forgotten that workers are much more than just a cost of production. They are also the clients and customers of small business. Squeeze them too hard and many local shops and businesses are plummeted into insolvency. We do not create employment by pushing down wages and conditions.

One thing that has been created in recent times is record corporate profits and executive salaries. The figures are there. However, enterprise bargaining is the flavour of the month. So we—and the Democrats, I would note—have focused our efforts on the protection of women and other groups that often have the weakest bargaining positions in the work force.

It is only relatively recently that women have seen advances in the workplace that take account of their particular requirements and responsibilities and which recognise the traditional disadvantages faced by women in this society. Even unions have been quite slow in putting the needs of women onto their agenda. Women are participating in the work force in greater numbers than ever before and, gradually, they have been obtaining greater consideration for their family responsibilities and their different style of working and overcoming the legacy of discrimination in rates of pay, conditions and promotions that have been unaddressed by governments for too long. Enterprise bargaining could see some of these advances lost if there are not adequate safeguards, as has been shown by the experience in some states and several surveys that have examined the impacts of enterprise bargaining.

One of these surveys has shown that male workers were four times more likely to receive a wage increase under enterprise bargaining in New South Wales than female workers. The survey found that some enterprise arrangements had the potential to disadvantage female workers. It is not hard to understand why this may be the case. Basically, women have very rarely had sufficient bargaining power to adequately protect, let alone advance, their interests. There are many reasons for this. Women are relatively inexperienced in industrial relations negotiations. They often work in non-unionised areas. In addition, even unions have tended to favour traditional male concerns. I note that only 10 per cent of so-called management positions in unions are filled by women.

The Greens have been critical of the union movement in terms of centralisation and have called for appropriate structures to be able to deal with the needs of women in the work force, especially in smaller workplaces, small and medium sized businesses in Australia. I am pleased that the federal government has been quite receptive to our concern to protect women and other parties in weak bargaining positions. The government has made several changes in its own legislation and is supporting a number of further amendments. The Greens have also requested the government to ensure that the Sex Discrimination Commissioner is involved in the design and analysis of the annual survey of developments in enterprise bargaining. I expect Senator McMullan to make comments to this effect in his concluding remarks on the bill.

I believe that this survey, which will be tabled annually in parliament, will be a vital safeguard with respect to enterprise bargaining. It will provide a mechanism by which the impacts on women and other underrepresented groups can be monitored. If it shows that the government has been wrong in viewing enterprise bargaining as the greatest thing since sliced bread, then we and the rest of the community will be warned and can make sure that the government takes some action before it is too late. Another action by the Greens to ensure that the interests of underrepresented groups are adequately protected will be an amendment that requires the Industrial Relations Commission to ascertain that all employees were consulted and informed in relation to negotiations and agreement.

Honourable senators will have noted the very important amendments by the government to the bill that are designed to prevent and eliminate discrimination on various grounds. I also look forward to the amendments by the Democrats being passed to additionally prevent discrimination on the grounds of sexuality, age and disability. I believe that Australia will be demonstrating considerable maturity as a society in enshrining these objectives into legislation. The government is still reticent about the use of the International Labour Organisation convention No. 111 to allow `spouse' to be defined as including same sex partners. The Greens will be following that one closely. We also expect the government to include such anti-discrimination objects into all relevant legislation that comes before the Senate.

With respect to helping prevent and eliminate discrimination in our society, there is a glaring inconsistency that exists in the Industrial Relations Act 1988. This occurs in section 113(2)(b) that allows discrimination against women to continue in awards if it is `in the public interest'. Accordingly, we will be moving an amendment that subjects industrial awards and agreements to the full force of the Sex Discrimination Act.

The government has made some very welcome changes to the secondary boycott provisions in the 1974 Trade Practices Act. Nevertheless, there has been disquiet expressed, especially in Western Australia, about the impact of remaining sections on boycotts. Hence, the Greens will be moving an amendment to repeal the relevant parts of these sections.

I wish to finish off with some observations about enterprise bargaining in my own state of Western Australia. Several Western Australian companies have already been using generous enterprise agreements to hive off core workers. However, these agreements include no strike clauses which enable the company to drastically reduce the level of wages for the majority of workers who are outside the chosen few. Hence, parts of the federal legislation are particularly necessary, given the regressive steps that have been taken by the Western Australian government. That the WA legislation is a step backwards for the workers of that state is clearly illustrated by the fact that the Western Australian legislation fails to comply with the relevant conventions of the International Labour Organisation in quite a few respects. Hamersley Iron's new workplace agreement does not even give workers freedom to choose to stay within existing industrial awards.

In relation to minimum wages, the Western Australian legislation is inadequate in meeting the requirements of International Labour Organisation convention No. 131. The Western Australian legislation does not properly specify the factors to be taken into consideration in fixing minimum pay. Most importantly, it does not require full consultation with worker and employer representatives. In fact, a person can get a workers' agreement in Western Australia that is secret. Nobody else is allowed to look at it, so who can check it? What kind of equal bargaining power is that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe the employer and employee are happy with what they are doing.

—That is working on the assumption that everybody has the power of a Queen's Counsel. In relation to termination of employment, the Western Australian legislation does not require that there be a valid reason for termination, does not provide for adequate notice and appeal procedures, does not provide the right of appeal against unjustified dismissal and does not provide for information to workers' organisations about redundancies for structural reasons. In short, inadequacies—indeed, inequities—of the Western Australian legislation illustrate that we must watch carefully the impacts of enterprise bargaining. I can assure honourable senators that the Greens in WA will be continuing to watch and monitor the impacts of the federal legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot has been said about this debate today. Some people have said that this debate is about unemployment, and to a degree it is. Some people have said this debate is about growth, and to a degree it is. Some people have said this debate is about investment, and to a degree it is. But this debate is overwhelmingly about freedom and individual liberty. We have before us a government which will, in the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, take away the freedoms and liberties of ordinary Australians and entrench in its place the right of the unions to take whatever liberties they wish to take with individual employees.

PARA.TAB: That is the essence of this government's bill. It is that essence which must be opposed to the utmost by those on this side of the chamber. Unlike this government, we do not believe that individual rights to freedom of association and to freedom to choose who the representatives should be, should be fettered in the manner which this bill does. This bill is an absolute absurdity.

Let me take a perfect example. If individual employees or employees generally in a workplace wish to take the step of entering into a voluntary employment agreement with their employer, even though they have rejected the union, they cannot go off and do it unless the union is allowed to appear at the hearings—the same union that those very employees have rejected lock, stock and barrel. What could be more ridiculous than that? The employees say, `Listen, we don't want to have anything to do with this union. We don't want to have anything to do with any of the other unions which try to represent us'. Yet those unions will be allowed to ride roughshod over their wishes and to appear at the hearings at which these voluntary employment agreements would be considered.

What is the rationale for that? Why should these people be allowed to butt their noses in and say, `This is what we believe'? It is none of their business whatsoever. More importantly, this bill takes yet another step in the pernicious and wholly unacceptable process of entrenching preference for unionists.

It was a sad day in the first year of my time in this parliament when the government, in a previous industrial relations amendment bill, sought to entrench preference for unionists. This so-called reform bill goes further. In entrenching the rights of unionists, it deprives those who are not unionists of equivalent rights. That is what this bill does; it strips away the rights of individuals unless they are willing to belong to a union. In some cases, it is not one union to which they have to belong, they often need two or three union tickets to get a start on a job. For example, a fellow working on a bobcat or using a jackhammer in many cases has to belong not only to the CFMEU but to the Building Workers Industrial Union—and other unions as well. It is not just a case of single jeopardy, or even a case of double jeopardy; under this bill it is a case of triple jeopardy or not getting equal rights.

How can this Senate chamber and this parliament—which is brought together to represent the interests of all Australians—in justice and truth support such abhorrent measures? How can we in this place give our seal of approval, our vote, to a measure that gives people second-class rights by virtue of their wish to exercise their God-given right to freedom? I do not believe that those of us on this side—or any senator—can vote for such a measure in good conscience.

As have other senators, I have been the recipient of many faxes on this matter from people in industry, small and large, who are screaming out against the provisions of this bill. I take the opportunity of reading some of those faxes. For example, I have a fax from the Heritage Wood Works in Queensland, signed by William S. Higgins, the owner. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been so little publicity on the Governments review of Industrial legislation. I must take this opportunity to protest at the way Government is handling this matter. I appeal to you to help halt any further progress of the bill until further input and understanding is made by business operators.

There is too much talk of Government to Union "Paybacks for earlier election support", and too little input by the people that really matter—the business owners and especially small business operators. Small business operators are in the main only "existing", in the most case owners themselves taking little in the way of remuneration for the hours they are putting into running their businesses—yet they are employing a significant number of workers and contributing greatly to the income of all Australians.

As a small businessman myself employing 7 people I hope I can influence you a little to look more closely at this terrible piece of legislation and oppose it whole heartedly until all persons concerned have been made aware of it's implications.
Yours Faithfully,
William S. Higgins

I give my pledge to Mr Higgins that I will support him in the same way that I take this opportunity to support the other people that have written to me. Kenneth J. Thrush and Roslyn A. Thrush of Kenro Metal Services in Toowoomba, and Ralph Cooper and Bruce Parker have written to me in relation to the bill. There is a letter from Fernland Agencies in Nambour, signed by Ron Parsons, Manager, and a letter entitled `Desperate Plea' from Mr Stuart J. Pringle, the Manager of SE Power Equipment, a division of Southside Engineering, at Tingalpa. Mr Stewart Reoch of the Apex Display Service sends an urgent request. He has looked at the bill and what has been said about it. He says:
We urge you to do all in your power to stop the passage of this bill through the Senate this week.

I shall do that. Mr Tony Rowland of Megatoy Play Systems has written to me opposing it. Gold Coast Bakeries—a business I know a little about, having grown up on the Gold Coast and having been through that bakery when I was at school—says:
We are a private family Bakery. We employ some 75 people, covered by three (3) Awards. Some are Union members—most are not. There is no pressure exerted by us to join or not to join.

This is what the whole debate should be about: whether anybody has the right to put pressure on individuals to join or not join a union. We on this side of the chamber believe that right to choose should be unfettered, and not just unfettered, but unaffected by the undue influence of governments, trade unions or the pernicious legislation which, together, they seek to have rammed through this parliament. That is why I support Mr Barry Laing, the General Manager of Gold Coast Bakeries. I support Neville and Shirley Hawkins of Hawkins Transport Pty Ltd, Mr Evans of Barbour Glass and Aluminium Pty Ltd and Mr Robert Hiscock from Neta Blinds, who has written to me asking me to give the industry time so that employers can give full consideration to the bills. Mr David McCorkell of Allcare Industries, which deals with pine products, has written to me. Jennifer Parsons from Thornlands said:

I cannot understand how a government can so blatantly disregard the obvious preference of the majority of the working populace by attempting to impose on us control by a non-productive, non-elected minority group.
How true that is. Mr Shepherd of Shepherd Contracting and Mr Bruce Rowland of Retro Seating have also written to me in similar terms.

PARA.TAB: Senator Woodley, in the chamber today, said that we are to disregard all these faxes because, according to him, they are inspired by a group called the Exclusive Brethren, with whom he is in religious disagreement. He says that is the basis upon which we should disregard all these faxes; and that they are written by a fanatical religious group. I went through all the faxes and could find—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a crazy basis on which to make a decision, isn't it?
