—It is a crazy way to make a decision. I could find only one fax that referred to conscience or God. That fax was sent by Mr Ralph Cooper and Mr Bruce Parker. So what if this fax refers to conscience? Is there something wrong with people—
—Do you have to shout?

—Unfortunately, some of the people on the other side of the chamber do not seem to be able to listen terribly well to the debate today. What is wrong with people listening to their conscience? Conscience has been the hallmark of and pivotal force in the forward development of man. The right to believe in morality, and morality compels individuals to take a particular course of action, has separated our society from the barbaric societies of previous times.

PARA.TAB: Yet Senator Woodley would have us throw out conscience because he does not agree with the religious sentiments of those who oppose this bill. Senator Woodley spoke for 15 minutes. I was in the chamber. I was almost going to take a point of order to ask when he would address the bill. But I wanted to let him finish his last parable before I did so. Having finished his parable, he sat down.

He did not address the bill once. All we had was Senator Woodley's flawed view of patristics and theological and scriptural interpretation. I will say something about Senator Woodley's view of theology and patristics; he seems to think that the people who oppose him or this bill do not understand scripture. It has always been the case that scripture is a very difficult thing to interpret.

Certainly, I heard nothing in Senator Woodley's exposition that made me believe that his view of scripture was superior to that held by the Brethren. They take a view which is perfectly reasonable: government should be of God, and governments should exercise their authority to uphold the law of God. There is absolutely nothing wrong with that view of scripture; it is one which we should be supporting. Every day we come into this chamber and we have prayers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not too many Labor people turn up, I might add.

—I know they do not. It is a source of grave regret for me, and I am sure it is a source of grave regret for many other people. We pray in this place that God will guide this parliament to the benefit of the true welfare of the people of Australia. The Exclusive Brethren are saying that this government, this parliament, and the people who make up this parliament, should actually do something to make those prayers come true. Yet, Senator Woodley says that that is somehow unsatisfactory. Senator Woodley's theological expositions, whilst always interesting, are not always very apposite. I would be interested to see Senator Woodley take his particular view of theology to the parts of Queensland he purports to represent to let the people there hear how he believes that God is on the side of the unions and against the individual consciences of particular people.

PARA.TAB: I do not think there is anything in the Bible that says that God supports unions over individuals or that it is wrong for persons to negotiate their own private agreement. I thought that the essence of Christianity was the fact that individuals were in communication with God and were judged on their merits and their faith. Yet, seemingly, Senator Woodley would install the trade unions to negotiate for us with God. He is saying that there is no basis for individual conscience or for individual agreements; people must have a trade union to act for them.

I have gone through all of the Old Testament and the New Testament and I cannot find one case where God has appointed a trade union representative to negotiate on behalf of the penitents. In fact, the Reformation, which gave birth to the religious denomination to which Senator Woodley belongs, was based on the fact that the Pope did not have exclusive right to negotiate with God on behalf of the faithful. That is what Martin Luther was on about; that is why there was a revolt against the whole idea of indulgences—because an individual's relationship with God is an individual thing. I will say no more about Senator Woodley but I will make some concluding remarks on this bill.

It has been said by those opposite that this bill is a great step forward. I have heard other people saying that one does not go forward by starting with a backward step. This bill is a backward step because it seeks to impose on Australians as a whole an ideology which has been shown to be moribund in practice and in morality. The bill says in a particularly offensive and patronising way that ordinary Australians who exercise their rights of freedom of association and freedom of choice are somehow not capable of making decisions on their own behalf or of deciding what is in their best interests. Even if they eschew a union, this bill tells us that they require a union representative to express their view on the particular voluntary employment agreement, or enterprise agreement, or whatever we want to call it.

When we look at some of the former union representatives in this place, it should give honourable senators enormous grounds for concern. Who are we going to choose to be the great representative and spokesman, to be the voice of reason, truth and logic? Are we to choose Senator Carr? Are we to choose Senator Murphy? If it were a matter of standing up for the right to interject, I am sure Senator Murphy would be a wonderful voice, but on matters of productivity, profitability and job creation, I do not think he knows very much. In fact, last night he tried to tell the chamber that it did not matter if a business made a profit provided it sold its goods. The business might sell its goods for a short time but unless it makes a profit it will not continue manufacturing those goods.

So, are we to choose Senator Carr, Senator Murphy, or the third member of the Three Stooges, Senator Burns? I say that we should not be compelled to choose any of them and that, more importantly, when individuals choose freedom and exercise freedom of choice they should not be compelled to hear any of these people unless they so choose. That is why the opposition opposes the bill, the compulsion and the stripping of rights from individuals but supports freedom over this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. This is the most poorly drafted, ill-conceived piece of legislation we have seen for at least a week. We are likely to see another next week, of course—the Mabo bill. This bill is one which has been put together by a government that is chock-a-block full of people who have never had to run a business. The problem is that they do not understand what business is about. They do not understand what negotiations between employer and employees are all about. They do not understand profitability or the fact that profit means continuation of the business and that, without profit, one cannot employ a soul. They do not understand that many employers and self-employed people actually pay their workers more than they are paid themselves. Moreover, they do not want to know.

PARA.TAB: As a result, we have this mishmash of industrial relations legislation that has been cobbled together not in consultation with business but in consultation with the ACTU—the political masters of this Labor Government. We must never forget, as my colleagues pointed out last night and today, that this is the ultimate payback. This government sits opposite thanks to the ACTU. Not only did the ACTU fund the lie campaign but it helped to distribute it to all its union members and their families right up until the Friday night prior to the election. The lies contained within that material were just breathtaking but, nonetheless, the ACTU did it. It funded this government to the tune of millions and millions of dollars. Many of the dollars poured in to fund this campaign were given by workers who could not afford the money in the first place and, secondly, did not want it given. But here we are today debating a piece of legislation that is all about saying, `Thank you very much for your kind donation'.

This piece of legislation does not focus on the real problems and attempt to solve them; it simply creates more. The Labor Party ignores the plight of so many—whether it is a small business struggling to survive, a medium-sized business trying to stop becoming small or a large business trying to stop going out of business. The Labor Party does not care about the low-paid workers; it does not care about the women; and it most certainly does not care about those of overseas origin—not at all. There is nothing in this bill that will go to the heart of solving the high levels of unemployment among our migrant communities—not a thing. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has obviously not contributed one thing to this legislation to ensure that the unacceptably high levels of unemployment being experienced by the ethnic communities are turned around. This bill will exacerbate that problem. It will create even higher levels of unemployment.

Two groups that are enormously vulnerable in this bill are women and the migrant communities. Where was Senator Crowley when this legislation was drawn up? She is meant to be representing the interests of women. She has been deafening in her silence—absolutely deafening. She is not on the speakers list; she has not been heard of. She probably has not read this bill either. If she is not capable of reading her own guidelines on child care, I suppose she would not be capable of reading this bill. We have two minister in this chamber—one representing women and one representing the ethnic communities—who are not contributing to the solution of the plight of those people whatsoever under this legislation. Senator Patterson last night clearly put down the coalition's concern affecting women—how badly the trade union movement treats the interest of women, how poorly represented they are in the trade union hierarchy and how few are given opportunities. Where is Senator Crowley? She is silent—absolutely silent.

TALK.START.PARA: —She's out there reading the child-care guidelines.

—I wish that were right. I would be a bit encouraged if she were out there reading the child-care guidelines, because it would be a first. I think the situation is quite clear when we look at the issue of women and those of overseas origin. How many of them have been represented by their ministers in this parliament through this piece of legislation? How does this bill impact on their well-being? How many people of overseas origin are represented in the trade union movement at key decision making levels? I exclude those who have been imported as militant union heavies.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is adequate to hear half a dozen English, Scottish, Irish—or whatever nationality—union leaders talk of how they brought industry to its knees in their home countries and say that that is representative of the millions of people and the many migrants who have come to Australia to make a new life for themselves and their families. What those people want is jobs, security and a future. What they do not want is the unacceptably high rates of unemployment which have been delivered to them by this Labor government. Some rates are as high as 30 per cent—rates that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has totally and utterly ignored. He has done nothing in this legislation or in any other piece of legislation to try to overturn that situation.

What people really want is to be able to work. They do not want to be given an opportunity to work and then be pulled out on strike by some militant union leader, who will get paid whether he works or not. That is the difficulty, because that union leader could not give a continental about the interests of the workers, who actually lose a lot of money. The union leader will simply get paid, and paid very well. Let us face it: most of them end up in this parliament. That is the sad fact. None of them have had to earn a buck. None of them have ever had to pay the wages bill, the rent for a business, the telephone account or any of the other impositions that this mob has put on top of them. They have not had to pay those bills. I have. Senator Panizza has. That is the real coalface of the facts of life. This mob has never, ever had to do it, and it is simply reflected in this piece of legislation.

Those union bosses will get paid regardless of any outcome of the dispute. The people who are the meat in the sandwich are those workers who are taken out on strike. What we will see in this legislation is more strike action. What we will see with sections 45D and 45E effectively disappearing—the 72-hour clause—is more industrial disputation. The 72-hour factor in this bill is a further demonstration of the lack of understanding of this Labor government. It does not understand that within 72 hours a business can be brought to its knees and sent out of business forevermore. Evidence was given to the Senate standing committee that looked at this legislation to that very fact. Seventy-two hours is of no help to many businesses; 72 hours can be total, utter and permanent devastation. Does the government care? No. Is it doing anything to try to resolve the unemployment levels? No. The government is simply exacerbating the situation.

One would think that over the last 10 years this mob would be satisfied with the extraordinarily high levels of bankruptcy that it has already achieved. It would say, `At least we have got to the end of that. We have really set the goal, and we have exceeded our expectations in sending businesses belly up. But, we want more, so we will devise a nice piece of legislation'. That is what the government has done here. This bill will certainly not help any of those people to whom I have referred. All it will deliver to them is fewer opportunities, particularly in the small business sector. As stated by a witness at the recent Senate committee, a greater degree of confusion will also prevail for many people in small business.

Can honourable senators imagine people of overseas origin struggling to come to terms with the way in which business operates here? This government is imposing more restrictions upon them, so this will make it more difficult for them to be able to start up a business and run one successfully. What small and larger businesses alike need is less red tape, not more. What this bill delivers is the latter. As I said before, the coalition totally rejects the changes to the boycott provisions. It is not just the coalition which is rejecting that; it is also every employer.

From my quick reading of the reports from the Senate standing committee, not one employer came before that committee and said that he or she did not reject it. What does this Labor Party say? It says, `Too bad, tough, because this is the deal that has been done with the ACTU. We do not care if you go out of business. What we do care about is our Labor mates in the ACTU'. We as a nation cannot afford to have that situation occur. Why does this Labor Party continue to acquiesce to a bunch of people who are effectively running this country? The Fergusons, the Keltys and so on have long since been de facto members of cabinet in this government, because not a decision is made without their being dragged to Canberra and taken into the cabinet room.

When are the interests of Australian business and workers taken into account? Those interests do not get a guernsey. With whom has all the alleged consultation taken place? It certainly has not taken place with business; rather, as everyone knows, that consultation has been with the ACTU, and the ACTU alone. The business community has simply been ignored again by this Labor government. Why have the pleas of the business community been in vain, its valid concerns dismissed and its interests in security of operation and profitability treated with disdain? It is simply because this Labor government is in power today only because of the ACTU.

There are almost 300,000 employers in Australia, many of whom employ fewer than 10 people. If an employer wants to make an enterprise deal, this bill insists that, before negotiations can even begin, the employer has to contact the union of which he and his staff are most likely not members. What absolute and utter nonsense. Today, more and more workers are opting out of unions rather than joining them. Hence, a few years ago we were confronted with the legislation to create mega-unions.

This government is hell-bent on creating more power for the union movement when the workers on the shop floor want less union involvement. Those workers want to negotiate. Today, some 71 per cent of employees in the private sector are not members of unions—71 per cent! So, why is the government pandering to a minority?

I do not know whether Senator West will speak on this bill. However, I have had the distressing experience of listening to her speak on this subject a number of times. She too does not understand what this is all about because she has never employed people—she has never had to pay the bills. Genuinely concerned people have been listening to this debate ever since it started—people who pay the bills, worry about profitability and worry about the security of their employees. Government members should not think for one moment that such worry is simply self-interest, which is how it will be described by Senator West if she speaks. Senator West always talks about the greedy employer—`All employers are greedy'. Employers could be a darned sight greedier if they did not employ people; but they actually create the vehicle by which people buy their homes, put food on the table and earn a living.

TALK.START.PARA: —And build homes too.

—And build homes—Senator Panizza is quite right. Such criticism simply highlights the policy of envy of this Labor government because its members have never had to struggle to make a business work. From personal experience I can tell those members that, if they had to struggle to make a business work, they would have a very different view of life. If they had to struggle to pay the wages bill every week, they would have a greatly different view on life. If they had to actually pay themselves less than their employees, they would be astounded. But last night we heard breathtaking nonsense from Senator Murphy who excelled himself by showing what a clown he is when it comes to understanding how the whole system of industrial relations works in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have to make sure that we achieve our aim: the defeat of this bill. I am very concerned that it will not be defeated for the very reasons that I have outlined today. None of the Australian Democrats here have run a business—I do not think one Democrat has ever run a business. Neither of the Greens has run a business. The majority of members of the Labor government have never run a business. So my hopes are very dim because none of those honourable senators understand what they are doing to the business community and this country's economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. After Mr Keating's inappropriate comments directed at the Malaysian Prime Minister, was the minister consulted on the best way to respond to the escalating tensions between Australia and Malaysia? Did he advise Mr Keating that an apology was unnecessary? Was he initially involved in the wording of Mr Keating's letter to Dr Mahathir? Did he see the final wording of the letter to Dr Mahathir? If not, why not?

—All the questions Senator Hill raises go to internal deliberations of government, advice given and received as between ministers within the cabinet and within the cabinet context. As such, it is inappropriate for me to comment and I decline to do so.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has obviously been reading the Australian today. There are some suggestions that it might have emanated from his office. Arising out of his non-answer, I ask the minister whether he endorses the comments that were originally made by the Prime Minister.
—Everything I want to say on the subject of the comments of the Prime Minister I said yesterday.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Can the minister advise on the progress that has been made in the development and implementation of a national system of classification and regulation of video and computer games?

—I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that work on a new regulatory scheme for computer games and computer generated images is very much at an advanced stage. As part of the background to this, federal, state and territory ministers agreed last month on a national approach for a regulatory scheme and asked for legislation to be drafted as a matter of priority.

PARA.TAB: The scheme will classify all computer games which are available for sale or hire or for use in places such as amusement arcades. The games will be classified by the Office of Film and Literature Classification according to age groupings to help parents decide which games are suitable for their children. The classifications will be based on the age categories for film and videos. However, all ministers agreed—the classifications will reflect this agreement—that the guidelines will be tighter in all categories, given the concern about the powerful influence these games may very well have on young people, particularly when they are played time and again. The games will also be labelled with consumer advice so that parents in particular will have full details of the strongest elements of the games.

In terms of the categories, all governments share the concern of others in the community about violent and sexually explicit computer games being marketed in Australia. We have taken steps to ensure that unacceptable material will not be sold. The scheme provides for restrictions on the stronger games to keep them away from younger children. A new category called G8 is also being created to warn parents about games that might be suitable for older children but not for the very young.

Ministers have also made it clear to the classification enforcement authorities that the scheme should operate in such a way to ensure that such inappropriate material does not become available to younger people. They will be backing up this particular measure with heavy penalties for breaches. As well, there will be an MA category preventing children under the age of 15 from buying or hiring such videos in that category or playing them in arcades. There will also be a restricted category which will be available only to those over the age of 18.

The guidelines for this particular scheme were released for public comment on 13 November and they, and any suggested improvements, will be considered at a meeting scheduled for 20 December. This question is timely in that it is getting close to Christmas when parents are always asked to buy these games for their children. I think parents should also play their part if the new scheme is to be effective. The best advice we can give parents is to look carefully at the labels and the advice on each game before deciding whether or not to buy it. While the scheme is not yet in force, there is very much an appeal to parents to take this approach. I think it is fair to say that the industry has generally reacted responsibly to community concerns about its products and many businesses have introduced their own system of labelling ahead of compulsory schemes.

The federal government intends to take urgent action early next year to develop a model ACT legislation for the classification of these computer games. This model can then be picked up by states and territories with their own enactments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it true that only a few months ago the Prime Minister was telling visitors to his office who were concerned about Malaysia and Dr Mahathir's attitude, `Don't you worry about Mahathir, leave Mahathir to me.'? Is this not yet another example of the gross arrogance of the Prime Minister? Is it also true that this little gem was given to Greg Sheridan of the Australian by Senator Evans or his office?

—Of all the crude fishing expeditions I have ever heard, that last one must take the cake. Of course I deny it. I have never heard the expression used before. It certainly did not come from me. I doubt very much that Mr Keating would ever have said anything like that. Of course, I have no knowledge whatsoever of the circumstances of any conversation he might have had with visitors in his office. It is a matter of press speculation, as so many of these things are.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister agree, with the wisdom of hindsight, that: firstly, the Prime Minister should never have made his `recalcitrant' remarks; secondly, he should have moved quickly to limit the damage by contacting Dr Mahathir and immediately issuing a public statement saying that he regretted his words in Seattle; and, thirdly, he should have sent a genuinely conciliatory letter to Dr Mahathir?
—Order! I do not really regard that as a supplementary question, but if the minister wants to answer it he can.

—All Senator Alston is doing is regurgitating bits from Greg Sheridan's article in this morning's Australian. I have the greatest respect for Greg Sheridan as an author and as a commentator, but I have no intention whatsoever of giving a running commentary on every bit of analysis that he might make.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given that the usual round of Christmas parties and festivities has begun around Australia, and given the Christmas-New Year road toll in recent years, can the minister advise what steps the federal and state governments will take this year to help reduce drink-driving in the Christmas-New Year holiday period?
—A national campaign to reduce drink-driving has been launched. The campaign, which will use television, radio and print advertisements, is entitled `Drive safe under .05'.
—No-one believes anything you say, anyway.

—I would listen to this if I were you, Senator Macdonald. I am happy to advise the Senate that all Australian states and the Australian Capital Territory will be united for the first time this Christmas under the .05 blood alcohol concentration limit for drivers. I regret to say that the only territory contribution to this is from the ACT: I deeply regret that the Northern Territory is the one out.
—Have you re-written the CAA minutes, yet?

—It would be a real test for Senator Macdonald to get .05, that is for sure. The Northern Territory Legislative Assembly passed legislation earlier this year to introduce the .05 limit, but I regret that it has yet to announce—
—You big, fat slob.
—Order! Senator Macdonald!
—Senator Macdonald is giving a good impression of being drunk now, actually.
—Order! Resume your seat, Senator Collins. Senator Macdonald, I ignored two previous unparliamentary remarks. I am not going to ignore the last one, and I ask you to withdraw.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You ignore Senator Collins's outrageous insults all the time, which he continues to make ad infinitum, yet you pull me up. What is the justification for ignoring him and asking me to withdraw?
—Order! The remarks that I heard you make, Senator Macdonald, were clearly unparliamentary. I am asking you to withdraw.
—What do you say about his remarks? I find them quite offensive and untrue.
—Order! I am asking you to withdraw.
—I will withdraw what I said, Mr President, but I ask you to—
—Mr President, on the point of order: I ask you to make Senator Collins withdraw.
—I withdraw unconditionally.
—Order! Senator Collins, I ask you to withdraw.

—Of course I withdraw. I am disappointed that the Northern Territory government has not done this, especially given its successful campaign in recent times—I give the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory great credit for this—to reduce the general consumption of alcohol in the community. I firmly believe that the Northern Territory government has a public duty to ensure that the lower blood limit is enforced before the festive season gets into full swing.

PARA.TAB: Statistically, there is a far stronger case for implementing the lower limit in the Northern Territory than elsewhere in Australia. Road deaths in the Northern Territory on a per capita—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you re-written the CAA minutes?
—Order! Senator Macdonald, that is a clear imputation against the minister. I ask you to cease—
—What is?
—That he has been rewriting official minutes. I ask you not to make it again.

—Road deaths in the Northern Territory on a per capita basis are almost triple the national average. Drink-driving is a major contributory cause in many of these accidents. While the national road toll has been halved over the past 20 years, the Northern Territory toll is at the same level as it was in the early 1970s. That is not a particularly happy result.

PARA.TAB: Drink-driving and speed remain the two biggest evils on Australian roads. Drink-driving still accounts for about one-third of Australian road deaths each year. I commend the current campaign to honourable senators, as it gives men and women a simple rule of thumb for staying under .05 while they enjoy a celebratory drink over the holiday period.

The rule of thumb for men is to rethink their third drink in the first hour; for women, it is to rethink their second drink in the first hour. For men and women, the message is: no more than one standard alcoholic drink each hour after that. If each driver in Australia, male or female, heeds this simple message, Australian roads will be a lot safer this Christmas than ever before.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. For years, every time the Australian Democrats or anyone else have suggested requiring superannuation funds to invest a small proportion of their funds for development capital for small and medium Australian businesses, government has thrown up its hands and said, `That is inappropriate. We shouldn't be picking winners'. What, then, has prompted the Treasurer and the industry minister to change direction and signal intervention in this matter? Are we seeing another piece of policy U-turn as the government is confronted with the policy failures of the 1980s in this area?

—There was no failure of the government's policy in the 1980s to make an internationally competitive economy. Every day in Australia we are seeing more and more small- and medium-sized firms, as well as large firms, exporting manufactured products of top quality to the world.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot has raised the issue of superannuation funds. It was quite appropriate for my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Mr Griffiths, in speaking to the first OECD world conference on small- and medium-sized enterprises held in Sydney this week, to raise the issue of getting a better balance in investment to meet the requirements of small- and medium-sized enterprises to create products that will make them internationally competitive. He said that, as we are preparing a major industry statement for next year, if the industry wanted to make submissions along those lines we would be interested in hearing those views. That invitation extends to any members of the community, including the Democrats. If they wish to make submissions along those lines, they will be considered.

Over the last few months, Mr Griffiths and I have been to many industry and association meetings, particularly those at small and medium size enterprise level, where the issues of availability of seed, venture and development capital for such businesses have been raised consistently. The problem of raising capital from banks has been an issue that has been raised consistently. People have raised the issue that, as there is now an ever-growing superannuation pool of money in this country as a result of this government's policies to establish a superannuation scheme for all Australians, it is not unreasonable that the government ensure that some of that money is invested in small and medium size enterprises that want to expand and develop their businesses.

We believe that this is a natural extension of the ongoing development of industry policy in the post-tariff and post-protection age. Mr Griffiths has made it very clear that in drafting the industry policy we are not going back to the old paradigms of protection and quotas for industry. We are looking at proactive ways to help industry to develop. Minister Griffiths has asked people to put forward submissions if they wish to. We look forward to receiving those submissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister said there was no policy failure. Would the minister not say there is a policy failure when the banks have been unwilling to lend the sort of capital we are talking about and when the government is now having to revamp the pool development scheme of the One Nation statement because again it has not generated significant capital—the capital that the minister says is needed? Is the government not having to acknowledge yet again the failure of two areas of voluntarism and is that not the real reason why the government is now looking at limited intervention?

—Not at all. There was no policy failure in the 1980s in making our economy internationally competitive. The substantial increase in manufactured exports in this country has significantly improved our balance of trade. Senator Kernot mentioned the pool development fund. In his speech yesterday, Minister Griffiths admitted that it had not been as successful as we would have liked. We have had consultations with the industry and it appears that it would like further concessions to encourage investors in the pool development fund. We have again indicated that we are willing to consider those suggestions in relation to the industry statement. We look forward to receiving submissions from industry and particularly from the Australian Development Capital Association, which has certain views about the way to improve the pool development fund. We look forward to receiving those submissions.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. I refer to the soon to be finalised Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, GATT, and in particular to the section relating to trade related intellectual property or TRIPS, and ask: is the minister aware that the combined effect of the implementation of the Uruguay Round of GATT, together with the failure of the Australian government to implement legislation protecting compact disc rental rights in Australia, will lead to the destruction of the compact disc rental industry throughout Australia? What action does the government propose to take to protect the 400 small business operations throughout Australia that rely on their ability to rent compact discs and records?

—I will first say something about the status of the TRIPS agreement. As it presently stands, the draft agreement will require countries, which at the time of adoption of the Uruguay Round outcome—expected to be April 1994, if everything goes well in the next few days—do not have in place a system of equitable remuneration of right holders in respect of the rental of sound recordings, to provide right holders in sound recordings with an exclusive right to prohibit or authorise the rental of sound recordings. There is a strong international consensus developing in support of an exclusive rental right for copyright holders in sound recording.

PARA.TAB: It is the case at the moment that Australia does not have a system of rental rights for copyright owners in sound recordings. This matter is currently under consideration by my colleagues the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services and the Minister for Justice. Emerging international obligations as a result of TRIPS and also in the World Intellectual Property Organisation, WIPO, and the need to provide certainty for all areas of the sound recording industry will have to be taken into account in this consideration.

The TRIPS agreement is not yet fully agreed and there are a number of proposals to amend the text, including in the area of rental rights for sound recordings. What emerges at the conclusion of the negotiations will obviously have a significant bearing on the form of rental rights that are introduced in Australia. It would compound the uncertainty of the record rental industry to make decisions on this prior to the TRIPS outcome and then to be required to alter those decisions as a result of the TRIPS outcome. Obviously, we have to wait until April next year to know where we are going in all this.
If the TRIPS agreement enters into force as it presently stands, rental rights will not need to be accorded to existing stocks of sound recordings. That needs to be made clear at the outset.

The record rental industry in Australia is fully aware of the implications of the Uruguay Round TRIPS agreement. My department has worked closely with the industry during the negotiations and has kept it regularly informed of developments in the negotiations. While latest figures do indicate that there are about 400 establishments around Australia renting out CDs, the situation is that in only about 10 of those 400 outlets is CD rental the main line of business. The rest are either video hire stores with a sideline in CDs or petrol stations, for example, which rent CDs as a sideline activity. There are also 3,000 sound recording retailers in Australia and their interests need to be weighed up against those of others. The ramifications of a rental right on both these groups will be taken into account in the development of a rental right in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As this seems to be just one of a vast number of unresolved issues with regard to GATT, I ask again: when are we going to get some indication of the full social and environmental implications of this agreement, which Australia is pushing forward to sign on 15 December?

—The basic outline of the agreement hopefully will be in place by 15 December. A few bits and pieces may remain to be tucked into place within that larger context in the months up until April, but it certainly will be possible to make the judgments of the kind that Senator Margetts wants us to make then. The notion of having some kind of social impact statement covering the total range of topics, products, services and so on that are covered by the Uruguay Round is, as I have said before in this chamber, manifestly an impossible task.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware that yesterday the South Australian forestry company SEAS Sapfor Ltd was told that a $200 million contract to manage a reafforestation project in Malaysia `can no longer proceed due to the deteriorating relations between Malaysia and Australia'? This followed an earlier statement by the company's managing director, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: We were the leading contender for the consultancy and management of the project but now it will almost certainly go to a European company. Our Malaysian office is saying the situation is absolutely desperate and if there is no apology from the Prime Minister in the next few days it will go to Europe.

I ask the minister: what services or support will he provide to this company in view of its potential multi-million dollar loss caused directly as a result of the irresponsibility and insensitivity of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating?

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons I spelt out in detail yesterday, I do not believe it is fair to say there was either irresponsibility or insensitivity on the part of the Prime Minister. In the circumstances of the case and, indeed, at the time in question, Mr Fischer and Mr Peacock were saying that it was perfectly understandable that the Prime Minister reacted as he did.

PARA.TAB: The subsequent course of events has demonstrated a clear willingness on the part of the Prime Minister to look forward rather than backwards; a very clear willingness on the part of the Prime Minister to communicate the propositions that no offence was intended and that, if offence was taken, it is regretted. We cannot state it any more clearly than that. We are going on stating it and restating it. We hope that it will be possible for this situation to resolve itself in the not too distant future.

In the meantime, there is going to be uncertainty and possible damage caused as a result of the attitude taken by particular ministries and particular firms in Malaysia that are acting on their own at this stage without any formal cabinet decision. Clearly, that has not been made, but there is still a capacity for individual companies or individual agencies to take action if they feel inclined to do so. That is operating, possibly, to the disadvantage of some Australian business. We very much regret that, but that is in the nature of the hazards of business life, I guess, and one has to contemplate the possibility that things like that will occur when business is being done with another country.

That is one of the problems we are trying to deal with at the moment, but we are trying to deal with it in a constructive way. It is not helped by this kind of partisan carping coming from those opposite, which is very much at odds with their own initial instincts on this matter as were communicated very clearly and very publicly by Mr Fischer and Mr Peacock in remarks which have not been denied since being reported at the time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister's answer suggested that the Prime Minister is obviously keen on communicating. The minister is obviously not aware that SEAS Sapfor faxed a letter to the Prime Minister on 2 December stating that it had spent considerable time, effort and expense fostering a relationship with the Malaysian primary industries minister and the Malaysian timber council and that it is looking at the loss of a multi-million dollar project. The company said in the letter:

QUESTION.PARA: We would appreciate your sincere assistance to the industry and Australia to recover the position as a matter of urgency.

In view of his enthusiasm to communicate, why has the Prime Minister not replied to this urgent request? What assistance or compensation will the government provide to SEAS Sapfor in light of the loss of the multi-million dollar contract?

TALK.START.PARA: —On the very day that the Prime Minister would have received that particular fax he communicated the letter to the Malaysian Prime Minister in an endeavour to help resolve the situation. The fact that it has not resolved it is one of the problems that we are currently trying to work our way through. I sympathise fully with the plight of this company and, indeed, any other company that is caught up in this particular situation at the moment, but it does not help the situation to continue to carp and harp in the way those opposite are.

PARA.TAB: We are trying to create a cooler environment in which this matter is considered—to create, as I said yesterday, a climate in which there can be a pause for reflection on both sides about the implications of all of this, and in which on the Malaysian side there will be some consideration given to the impact on its own investment levels, on its capacity to receive technology transfer and, indeed, on the demonstration effect to countries elsewhere of this kind of activity occurring. We want all those factors to be taken into account. It is not a question of the Prime Minister lacking any sympathy at all for companies in this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to the APEC meeting held in Seattle last month and note that subsequent to that meeting Senator Cook referred to a commitment made to the harmonisation of customs administration and practice. Is the minister able to provide any information on the significance of the role played by the Australian Customs Service during APEC negotiations? What are the expectations for an ongoing role within the Asia-Pacific region for the Australian Customs Service?

—I note that honourable senators opposite are not interested in all the constructive things that came out of the APEC conference and want to ignore it. I want to outline a very positive outcome which involved the Australian Customs Service. I recognise and note that all of us in this parliament in the recent year or so have often been publicising bad stories about Customs, but I think this is a very good story about a development that Customs has been involved in.

PARA.TAB: Within the regional trade liberalisation group the Australian Customs Service chaired a working group which has been convened to advance customs issues relevant to trade liberalisation within APEC. The group had a substantial workload. It was able to complete a program which led to a number of major outcomes which include: the conclusion and reporting in Seattle of a viability study for an APEC-wide tariff database; the conduct by a joint team from SPL Australia Pty Ltd and the ACS of a series of demonstrations to all APEC economies of the ACS electronic tariff, known as TAPIN, as the basis for an eventual APEC-wide database; the publication of an APEC customs guide providing information on the procedures and requirements of all APEC customs; and the continuation of an air express courier consignment electronic data interchange project managed by ACS involving Chinese-Taipei and at least two other APEC economies.

Undoubtedly the most visible outcome for the customs group at Seattle was the staging of the first APEC customs trade fair symposium. Representatives from all 15 APEC administrations participated in the fair, which gave a unique opportunity for customs officials and the international trade community to interact and exchange views on the appropriate balance between legitimate customs enforcement needs and the practices and facilitation of the international movement of goods. It was a very practical demonstration and was very well received by the several thousand representatives who attended that APEC fair in Seattle.

The government is committed to an ongoing role for the ACS within APEC. We accept that we have the opportunity to provide leadership in the introduction of electronic devices in creating a paperless customs system, and we will continue to be involved. A recent example is that the trans-Tasman-APEC EDI project, initiated earlier this year by the Australian government, has saved BHP and its New Zealand customers considerable transaction costs through the implementation of paperless trading. This project is a positive manifestation of APEC's ability to foster practical cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region. ACS will do all it can to extend the lessons learnt to other trade facilitation projects under the APEC umbrella.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that Voxson, a leading Queensland and Australian mobile communications company, has been informed that a scheduled current affairs television appearance by Voxson representatives in Kuala Lumpur is to be cancelled because of Prime Minister Keating's initial insult and subsequent refusal to apologise to Dr Mahathir? Does the government dispute the claim by the managing director, Mr Lucas Longginou, that his company has millions of dollars and many years invested in Malaysia and throughout the broader Asian rim, and that that investment, along with the investment of countless other Australian companies, is in immediate danger of irreparable damage? Would the minister please advise why the Australian High Commissioner in Malaysia told Voxson, which stands to lose $40 million a year in export income, to go away and sort the situation out for itself?

—Knowing the High Commissioner in Malaysia as well as I do, I doubt very much that he would have given any advice in those terms to a company caught up in the situation as Senator Parer describes it. I was on the phone to him as recently as an hour or so ago. We are all extremely concerned about the situation for Australian companies. It is inconceivable to me that there would be that kind of allegedly unhelpful response.

PARA.TAB: As to the particular circumstances of that company, I cannot comment. But if it is to do with the media industry, as Senator Parer describes, clearly the information minister has made an announcement about his attitude to Australian programs and business involvement in that sector, and this is one apparent consequence of that. That is a matter for very deep regret. We hope very much that the situation can be contained and ultimately resolved. We are working to do our best to achieve that, as I said yesterday.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Defence Science and Technology Organisation: Links with Industry

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. What progress has the Defence Science and Technology Organisation made in its strategy of developing broader links with Australian industry? Will this strategy detract from the DSTO's primary responsibility to serve the Australian Defence Force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation is strengthening its close links with Australian industry. In doing this, it has two clear aims. First of all, close links will enable industry to better support the Australian Defence Force and reduce reliance on overseas suppliers. Secondly, these close links will also assist Australian industry to become more internationally competitive through enhancement of the Australian technology base.

PARA.TAB: These mutually beneficial links were demonstrated at an industry day at the DSTO laboratories at Salisbury in South Australia, which I attended on Tuesday of last week. Among a range of initiatives announced at that time, the industry day saw the launch of a communications research network by both me and my colleague Mr David Beddall, the Minister for Communications. This network, which has been developed in partnership by DSTO and Telecom, includes a high-technology communications link between Melbourne and Adelaide using asynchronous transfer mode technology.

This technology is expected to underpin the global information age of the 21st century and is likely to be the basis of many future civil and military networks. ATM technology will allow Defence to make maximum practical use of the national civil communications infrastructure. The research network is a product of a cooperative relationship between DSTO and Telecom, which has existed for some 20 years and was formalised by a memorandum of understanding in 1990.

I made a further announcement at the industry day regarding a new opportunity for industry to join DSTO in the development of high technology equipment. DSTO has sought proposals for companies to join it to further develop an Australian designed airborne synthetic aperture radar which can produce photograph-like images of the countryside up to 50 kilometres away from the aircraft which carries this radar. It has great potential for use by the Defence Force in surveillance of Australia's north and north west, and it also has some significant possible civil applications. DSTO expects that the radar can be produced at far less cost than that of similar equipment developed overseas. The radar has been named Ingara, which is an Aboriginal word meaning `long way'.

The ATM research network and the Ingara radar are, however, only two examples of how DSTO's partnership with industry is proving that the products of high technology defence research and development are now very good business indeed for Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What actions has the minister, as foreign minister, taken to minimise the damage resulting from Mr Keating's comments in Seattle regarding the Malaysian Prime Minister? When did he take such actions?

—I have been away, obviously, all last week in Vietnam and Papua New Guinea. Since my return, I have been doing my best to keep in touch with the situation and to discuss it with all relevant parties, including the Prime Minister, our representatives in Malaysia and the team that is over there at the moment, with some of the results that I foreshadowed yesterday. I will be continuing to do the best I can to assist to resolve the situation.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the minister what he has done. He seems to be indicating that he has not done anything, apart from trying to get on top of the brief. In case he misunderstood the question, I ask again: what actions has he taken? Presuming he has been in contact with Senator Cook, who is obviously much more concerned about the matter than Senator Evans was yesterday, has he taken any further actions as a result of those discussions with Senator Cook to try to minimise damage being caused to Australian interests?
—If Senator Hill thinks that on this or any other issue I am going to give him a blow-by-blow account of how I conduct this country's international relations, he has got another think coming.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the passage last week of the Western Australian Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act 1993 and ask: is the minister aware of reports that there are some 110 lease applications now being processed in Western Australia under this act? Does the minister agree that such action is likely to create and exacerbate community tensions in the expectation that Commonwealth native title legislation will override at least some of the action now being taken under the Western Australian act? Thirdly, does the government intend to request the Premier of Western Australia to defer action until the Commonwealth legislation is passed?

—Our information is that Western Australia has in recent years processed in the order of 5,000 to 6,000 mining, prospecting and exploration leases annually; that would be consistent with the figure of 110 mentioned by Senator Spindler. We do not have any access to any special information on this issue. I can only suggest that Senator Spindler himself approach the Western Australian government for more detail on that matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. In light of the total rejection of the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System Handbook firstly by child-care representative bodies, such as the Australian Confederation of Child Care and the Australian Federation of Child Care, which represent some 60 per cent of the industry and; secondly, the Sydney Rescue Works Society, which represents the poorest families; thirdly, the Catholic Social Services, which describes the linking of funds to the handbook as despicable; and, fourthly, the two members from the National Child Care Accreditation Council, who resigned in protest over the development of the handbook, will the minister withdraw the handbook so that greater consultation can be undertaken with the industry? Or is it the minister's intention to withdraw federal government fee relief from those child-care centres which do not sign on to the new accreditation guidelines?

—Senator McGauran persists in promoting a whole lot of misinformation, and that misinformation is contained in his question. First of all, the confederation and the federation do not constitute 60 per cent of the industry. All private child care in total constitutes 60 per cent of child care, so the score of the confederation and the federation is much less than that. That is a small point, perhaps, but a very important one to start off with.
—Liar!
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to ask Senator McGauran to withdraw that remark—he was calling the minister a liar.
—Order! I did not hear the interjection but, Senator McGauran, if you did call the minister a liar, I ask you to withdraw.
—Mr President, I did call Senator Crowley a liar, and I withdraw.

—Thank you, Mr President. Secondly, the confusion in the community about what constitutes the accreditation program is not at all assisted by the opposition's program of obfuscation, particularly Senator McGauran's very pathetic and ridiculous contribution to it. But it is curious—and I have to ask again—why Senator McGauran, in speaking on behalf of the opposition, is opposed to accreditation when Senator Newman supports it. I have previously quoted Senator Newman in this matter. She supports voluntary accreditation.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is utterly offensive as well as utterly irrelevant for Senator Crowley to start talking about what she does not understand of Senator Newman's views. This has nothing to do with the question and it is utterly irrelevant.
—Order! Senator Alston, resume your seat. You know that is not a point of order.
—Indeed, it is interesting to observe how quickly the opposition springs up when it is faced with division within its own ranks about accreditation.

PARA.TAB: I also point out that at my office I have been receiving a considerable number of letters—and this would interest Senator McGauran—from the private sector supporting not only accreditation but also the link with fee relief. Quite clearly, there is a difference of opinion in the industry; that I do not dispute at all. But it is quite wrong to claim that all people represented by the federation or all people represented by the confederation are opposed to accreditation and/or the link with fee relief. Many people, including many members of both those organisations, have been at pains to contact my office and make clear that their opinions differ from those of the peak representatives of those organisations.

Also, there is a very big distinction between people who are opposed to accreditation and the link with fee relief and, as Senator Newman has said, those people who support accreditation but want it to be voluntary. Perhaps the best line I can give about that is the one attributed to Senator Lees—and I think she is quite right—that voluntary accreditation would be a bit like voluntary income tax. But we know that there is a very big difference out there in the community about the voluntary process.

The problem with the opposition is that it does not actually know what accreditation constitutes. Those opposite say they support a voluntary accreditation and then criticise the whole process of accreditation which would allow the centres to implement the kind of child care that the guidelines describe and which give a description about how to achieve it.

The point is apparently lost on Senator McGauran that if you want to support accreditation then you support what is in the guidelines. If, like the opposition, you support the accreditation but oppose the link, as Senator Newman has spelt out, that is a very different position from opposing what is in the guidelines. If opposition senators want to understand this, they had better appreciate that accreditation is about the guidelines and a voluntary accreditation would be about exactly the same guidelines. I suggest that Senator McGauran gets those facts exact before he adds further to the mischievous misinformation he has been putting around.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the crisis of confidence within the child-care industry and the widespread community anxiety over the accreditation guidelines, will the minister now seek the dismissal of the board of the National Child Care Accreditation Council, including its chairperson Quentin Bryce, for failing to work with the industry groups and acting as a law unto itself by, for example, watering down Christmas?
—Make some approximation of the facts; just get close to the facts. Why don't you try that for a change?

—I am very assisted by Senator McMullan's interjection. It would be very interesting to get close to the facts. I notice that Senator McGauran says we are watering down Christmas. Previously he said we were banning it, so he had better get his lines right. He is absolutely wrong on that, as he has been all along. As I have said before, there is quite clearly a huge amount of anxiety and confusion in the community created by this mischievous misinformation campaign. There is no doubt about it at all. That is why I have been very pleased to address very significant meetings. Last week I was more than happy to address a huge meeting organised by the Australian Confederation of Child Care in Victoria. It would be interesting to ask the people leaving that meeting what they felt at the end of the meeting compared with what they knew when they came in. It is perfectly possible that if one talks sense to the people in the community their understanding of the accreditation process is not what Senator McGauran is claiming it to be.

—My question is directed to the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Can the minister tell the Senate why men are wearing white ribbons today and explain the federal government's contribution to this campaign?

—Senator Childs asked this question because he is very aware of how many people do not know what the white ribbon campaign is about. This week men are being urged to wear white ribbons as part of an international campaign to get men to participate in the campaign to stop violence against women. The catalyst for this campaign by Men Against Sexual Assault, known as MASA, was the massacre in the University of Montreal on 6 December 1989 where a gunman separated male students from female students and then gunned down 14 women. This massacre is an extreme example of violence against women. It certainly is an American example, but there is no doubt at all about violence against women being a very significant problem in our own country. The white ribbon campaign runs from 5-11 December—
—They didn't have them on yesterday.
—Senator Patterson keeps saying it was yesterday, and I am very pleased that she knows about it, but it is also quite clear that many people do not know what this program is about.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.
—Thank you, Mr President. I am quite shocked that the opposition seems not to want to know the answer.

PARA.TAB: The white ribbon campaign encourages men to break their silence about men's violence, including domestic violence, spousal murder and sexual assault of children. It is very much in sympathy with the federal government's program, which I launched earlier this year, involving non-violent men in the campaign against violence. MASA encourages men to acknowledge responsibility for their part in stopping violence and it also aims to undermine male acceptance of violence. It is interesting to read the account in this morning's Canberra Times of the launch and discover that some young men at that launch found that it was better to laugh about violence against women than to even consider their role in helping to resolve the problem.

Violence against women is a crime and I am interested that members of the opposition, who have said in the past that they strongly support this view, seem not to be in that mood today. The federal government's campaign, as I have already said, draws on public figure men, such as Darren Mercer, Kieren Perkins, Don Burke and James Blundell, to assist with the message that violence against women is unacceptable and that non-violent men must join women in opposing violence by men.

At the launch I announced the second round of community projects funded under this program. I am pleased to tell the Senate that MASA's campaign is partly funded by the stopping violence against women program. A grant of $10,000 was made to MASA to assist it to promote education and to help with publicity material to promote the issue of violence against women. It also recognises that men and men's organisations have a vital role to play in this campaign. We know that not all men are violent, but all men are responsible for helping end men's violence against women.

TALK.START.PARA: —The vast majority are not violent.
—Only some men are part of the problem, Senator Hill, but all men are part of the solution.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I notice in today's Herald-Sun that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Mr Alan Griffiths, has suggested that Essendon airport should be relocated for economic and residential considerations. Does the minister agree with Mr Griffiths? Is this current departmental policy? Why did Mr Griffiths make this announcement rather than Senator Collins, as the relevant minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering whether Senator Ian Macdonald was one of the ambulance chasers that the Premier of Victoria was just referring to publicly.
—Sensitive little flowers, aren't you?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is offensive.
—I am not going to give a ruling on it, but I ask Senator Collins to withdraw the remark if offence was taken.

—I withdraw it. The accident referred to by Senator Macdonald involving a De Havilland Dove aircraft is currently being investigated by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. I am very grateful that miraculously there were no fatalities following this accident. My position on this issue is one that has been taken publicly by others, and that is that we will be in a far better position to assess the future operations of Essendon airport once the investigation of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is complete and the report is available.

PARA.TAB: There is one thing that I think is important to correct. There have been endless statements made in the last few days that, following this very unfortunate incident, Essendon airport is in some way unique, in terms of the proximity of the take-off threshold of aircraft and the residences in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Sydney?
—Precisely, Senator. These statements are grossly wrong.
—So Griffiths is wrong?

—I do not know whether or not he said that. I did not see any statements from Mr Griffiths asserting that at Essendon airport the take-off threshold of the aircraft was closer to residences than was the case anywhere else in Australia. In fact, it is not. Essendon airport, which was Melbourne's major airport for many years and currently has about 80,000 movements per year, has a take-off threshold in proximity to residences which is equal to or better than comparable airports around Australia.

PARA.TAB: There may be a number of reasons why Essendon airport should be closed. Mr Griffiths for a long time has had a public position on the issue of closing Essendon airport. It came as no surprise to me to see Mr Griffiths make the statement that he did, and he is perfectly able to do so. He is an effective local member from that area and he has had a long held public position, along with a number of others, that Essendon airport should be closed.

I want to make one fundamental point. If Essendon airport is closed on the sole grounds of the proximity of the take-off threshold of aircraft from Essendon and residences, we will be closing a great many airports in Australia. Indeed, if the rule were applied internationally, a great many airports around the world would be closed. Anybody who doubts that should refer to the very detailed Port Phillip study that was done only two years ago—a cooperative study between the Commonwealth government and the then Victorian government which determined that Essendon airport should remain open.

What I will do, along with the Victorian government and others, is await the results of the BASI investigation into the accident at Essendon, after which both the Commonwealth and the Victorian governments will be

ANSWER.PARA: in a much better position to assess future operations at Essendon airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not quite sure what is wrong with the minister's mental processes, but I did not ask about any of the matters to which he has responded. I asked: does he agree with Mr Griffiths' announcement that the airport will be relocated for economic and residential considerations? The second part of my question was: is that current departmental policy?
—I am sure that, on request, a special large print version of the Hansard can be made available to Senator Ian Macdonald so that he can read the answer that I just gave.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I noticed in the weekend's papers an advertisement calling for applications for grants to the Visions of Australia program. Will the minister explain to the Senate why this program was established, how it will work and who will benefit?
—More social engineering!

—This is a program that is particularly directed to people in rural and regional areas and I am surprised that the National Party opposes it. In fact, I am not surprised because at the end of the day it never supports programs for people in remote areas; its members just come in here and talk about it.

PARA.TAB: This is an extension of an important principle that has been underlying initiatives in Commonwealth arts and cultural policy for several years, with particular emphasis on issues of access and participation—not just access in terms of geography, of people disadvantaged by where they might live in Australia in the nature of Australia's demography, but that is an important element in it. This program will build on initiatives, particularly those over the past 12 months, that have been designed to provide opportunities for people all over the country, wherever they live, to participate in cultural activities and to overcome the disadvantage of people in rural and remote areas.

This program follows on from the very successful Playing Australia program, which has enabled performing arts to appear in cities where that would not otherwise have been possible and to assist people living in rural and remote areas to get access to performances that would not otherwise have been available outside the major capital cities. That has been a very successful program and has been responded to very positively by people outside the major cities.

We announced in the election, and are now implementing, a proposal so that Australians living outside the major cities will also be able to enjoy such benefits with regard to visual arts. This will occur through the federal government's first national exhibition touring program, which will be called Visions of Australia. That is the basis of the advertisement which Senator Denman saw in the newspapers on the weekend—the first round of advertisements, which I was pleased to announce on a visit to Hobart recently and which will have significant benefits for Tasmania.

Visions of Australia will make it possible for more Australians to enjoy and take great pride in the high standard of visual arts and crafts and collections of heritage and scientific material that are spread all over this country. It will enable exhibitions to move from the major cities to the regional centres, into new cities, into regional areas where they might not otherwise have gone, providing opportunities for small communities to see major collections.

One other thing we have learnt from Playing Australia, and which will be reflected in this program, is that there are also significant collections in major regional centres that can go to other regional centres to their benefit. I recently had the opportunity to see an outstanding collection of glassware in the Wagga art gallery which would be an outstanding basis for tour to many other cities and, of course, there are art galleries around Australia in regional centres which could also benefit. It is designed to meet community needs and hopefully will open up options that have been closed to people around Australia for too long.

As announced in the budget, we have provided $1 million this financial year and will provide a further $5 million over the next three years. The most important point I want to reiterate is that the committee that has been appointed to supervise this program which I announced last week is representative of the industry and of all the states and territories and, although the advertisements appeared in the newspapers only last weekend, I am pleased to tell the Senate that we have already had more than 50 inquiries in the last two days from people hoping to take up this important program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On 18 November, Senator Crane asked Senator Bolkus a question without notice in his capacity as minister representing Senator Cook, who represents the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in this chamber. The question related to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, so it also involved the Minister for Industrial Relations. All of them, no doubt, have contributed to this answer.

PARA.TAB: The government is conscious of the need for reform in the meat processing sector to make it more competitive internationally. The June 1992 Full Bench decision arising from the AIRC inquiry into the meat industry established a framework within which the direct industrial parties could develop processes and outcomes designed to significantly improve the industrial relations climate and productivity within the industry. The government fully supports the framework established by the Full Bench, which encompassed many of the recommendations of the overseas study mission by industry participants and the Commonwealth's own submission to the inquiry.

Progress is being made. In April 1993, the commission called the industry parties together to hear a report on progress. At those proceedings the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia and the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union presented an agreed eight-point plan to progress the commission's decision.

I am advised that the union is currently involved in negotiations with the Meat and Allied Trades Federation in respect of appropriate award regulation, in keeping with the AIRC inquiry decision. I am also advised that the union, in conjunction with the ACTU, has made a substantive submission to the Industry Commission's meat processing inquiry.

The IC inquiry will examine in detail the situation in the meat processing sector. Amongst other things, the IC will examine the cost structure of the processing and marketing chain, and will seek to identify any factors which unnecessarily add to costs and inhibit the development of the industry. The inquiry commenced on 23 June and is expected to make its final report to the government on 23 March 1994.

The government will also conduct a comprehensive and independent review of the meat and livestock industry to provide the government with options to address the broader strategic and structural issues faced by the industry. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) will be announcing the membership and terms of reference of this review in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 November, Senator Watson asked me a question without notice concerning self-assessment. I have an answer from the Treasurer and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: A taxpayer who wishes to vary the ascertainment of taxable income can at any time during the amendment period request that the Commissioner amend an assessment. In general, an amendment can be made at any time up to four years from either the date upon which the tax became due and payable or the date upon which the assessment is deemed to have been made. There are no restrictions on the number of amendments that can be made during the amendment period provided they are considered by the Commissioner to be necessary.

A taxpayer dissatisfied with an assessment can object against that assessment at any time during the objection period. An objection can be lodged at any time up to the later of 60 days from the date of service of a notice of amended assessment or four years from the date of service of the original notice of assessment.

Where the Commissioner amends an assessment to allow an objection either wholly or in part, the Commissioner may of his own volition or at the request of the taxpayer make such further amendments to the assessment as he considers necessary. However, the Commissioner will not generally further amend an assessment in respect of a particular covered by an objection that has been disallowed, unless it is necessary to give effect to a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or a Court overruling the Commissioner's decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator may proceed.

—In a letter dated 29 September 1993, the Network for Christian Values made an objection to a reference to NCV which I made in a speech to the Senate on 28 September 1993. Mr John McNicol of NCV stated in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Your speech implied that NCV espouses a right wing and ultra-Calvinist philosophy. I am writing to inform you that this statement is misleading and untrue.

If one reads my speech from pages 1303 to 1306 of the Hansard, one will see that nowhere in the speech did I use the phrase `right wing'. The term `ultra Calvinist' was used with reference to the Foundation for the Advancement of Christian Studies.

PARA.TAB: Later in my speech I made reference to the Network for Christian Values to which Mr McNichol objects. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Foundation for the Advancement of Christian Studies is linked with the Logos Foundation, as is the Network for Christian Values—another source of the many objections which I received.

As can be seen from my reference to the Network for Christian Values, it is about links between that organisation and the Logos Foundation. In support of this assertion, I offer the following information. The letterhead for the Network for Christian Values gives the phone number for the national director of NCV as 291 4611. The Canberra phone book gives the same phone number for the Logos Foundation.

PARA.TAB: When the Logos Foundation was based in Toowoomba, one of its leaders was Derek Brown. It has now re-established its headquarters in Canberra. The letterhead for the NCV records Derek Brown as its national director. The letterhead for the Network for Christian Values also records Ian Shelton from Queensland as a member of its executive.
