Mr Shelton is the minister of the Toowoomba City Church. I understand that this church was renamed and reformed from the remnants of the Covenant Evangelical Church, the religious arm of the Logos Foundation when it was based in Toowoomba. I believe, therefore, that my assertion of a link between the Network for Christian Values and the Logos Foundation is reasonable.
In a further letter from the Network for Christian Values, Derek Brown claims—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley, this is really turning into a speech. It is a personal explanation.
—Why don't you seek leave to incorporate the rest of it?
—I seek leave to incorporate other information.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I received a further letter from NCV dated 13 October 1993 and signed by Derek Brown the National Director. In his letter he claims:

"Network for Christian Values (NCV) was set up earlier this year after a series of meetings held in Canberra, by a group of Ministers of Religion. . . Our constituent membership is representative of more than 500,000 Christians of various religious and political persuasions."

These claims made me curious as to who these Canberra Ministers of Religion might be so that I'd have some idea of the churches to which these 500,000 Christians might belong. I contacted the Canberra leadership of the following churches: The Anglican Church, the Baptist Church, the Catholic Church, the Salvation Army and the Uniting Church. None of them had heard of the Network for Christian Values. I suspect that the NCV has a tendency to overstate its case somewhat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson this day, relating to relations between Australia and Malaysia.

SPEECH.PARA: I was absolutely amazed by Senator Gareth Evans's answer to my question today, which related to a specific company which is currently having specific problems because of remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the ongoing effect of those remarks on industry throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: What staggers me is that the government and the Prime Minister had the chance to save a $200 million project. The Prime Minister was warned by a letter faxed to his office on 2 December by SEAS Sapfor Ltd from south-east South Australia but, at that stage, the government took absolutely no action. I will read the letter for the sake of the Senate. It is addressed to the Prime Minister, the Hon. Paul Keating, and states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is with deep concern that this company views the deteriorating relations that have developed between Malaysia and Australia.

S.E.A.S. Sapfor Limited has spent considerable time, effort and expense in fostering a relationship with the Malaysian Minister of Primary Industries and the Malaysian Timber Industry Development Council to progress our involvement in a major plantation development scheme in Peninsula Malaysia.
We have just been informed that the Malaysian Cabinet have put aside all trade and developments with Australia which will now severely impact our future planning with the Malaysian Government.
We are looking at the loss of a multi million dollar project which would have significant benefits to Australia and to S.E.A.S. Sapfor Limited.
We would appreciate your sincere assistance to the industry and Australia to recover the position as a matter of urgency.

This letter was faxed to the Prime Minister's office on 2 December. I would have thought that an industry worth $200 million, which was being placed in jeopardy purely because of the insensitive remarks that the Prime Minister made in Seattle, at least would have warranted an acknowledgment or reply in the intervening period. As of this morning, SEAS Sapfor has received no reply or acknowledgment of that faxed letter sent to the Prime Minister, outlining the facts about placing this whole development and $200 million investment in jeopardy.

PARA.TAB: This morning I received a letter from SEAS Sapfor which gives some background of the Australian based forestry company. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . its corporate office located near Mount Gambier . . . The Company has a large plantation resource (42,000 hectares) with downstream processing through sawmills and preservative treatment plants in South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. Timber products from the Company's own production in combination with other Australian and imported timbers are marketed throughout Australia through Timbersales Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary company.

S.E.A.S. Sapfor Ltd has developed high levels of expertise in plantation management with its first plantings dating back to 1926. The Company's practical approach to commercial and financial management of plantations is recognised throughout Australia.

It is extremely disappointing to now be placed in the position of losing the opportunity to be appointed as consultants and managers of a large plantation development program in Malaysia involving expenditure of an estimated $A200 million.

This project had been progressed by S.E.A.S. Sapfor Ltd senior executives during the year involving a number of visits to Kuala Lumpur. The Company was very favourably placed to proceed with the contract and yesterday we were advised that we can no longer proceed due to the deteriorating relations between Malaysia and Australia.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, said in the Senate today and on other days that we have had a good relationship with Malaysia in the past and we will have a good relationship with it in the future. Yet absolutely nothing is being done to try to save these companies from losing money. The companies that are being affected today are not concerned with what is going to happen years down the track; they are concerned about what is happening today.

PARA.TAB: This contract has been lost at great cost to the company and South Australia. What will the Prime Minister do to fix up this mess so that further contracts are not lost? What will the Prime Minister do for companies like Sapfor which have already lost multimillion dollar contracts? There is no point in saying that he did not mean to offend. He has caused offence and it is having extremely negative effects in Australia. Will the Prime Minister continue to sit on his hands while more contracts are cancelled, or will he act now to protect the interests of other Australian businesses?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard over the last three or four days various senators on this side of the chamber getting up and giving instances of millions of dollars being lost by businesses. Yesterday Senator Parer mentioned a company that is in this situation. Senator Ferguson mentioned today another company, Sapfor, which is in the same situation. I would also like to mention a company that finds itself in the same situation.

PARA.TAB: Today Senator Parer asked a question relating to Voxson. Voxson has had an office in Malaysia for a number of years. Voxson has around $100 million worth of export sales. It gets very little assistance from the government or government instrumentalities. Senator Richardson has been to Voxson to try to assist this company but at that stage the ministry was changed.

Voxson does not get any assistance from Telecom and it gets very little assistance from Optus. It is totally reliant on the export sales it gets in Malaysia, Indonesia and China. It employs 100 to 150 people, depending on the orders received.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is Australian owned.

—It is not only Australian owned, as the Leader of the Democrats reminds me, but also the only mobile phone company that has products totally Australian built and totally Australian designed. Those sorts of industries should be encouraged. They are at the leading edge of the high-tech industry. For those reasons they need to be encouraged.

PARA.TAB: This company goes to an enormous amount of trouble and expends hundreds of thousands of advertising dollars in Malaysia trying to break into the market. Voxson is devastated to see all its efforts and work go down the drain because the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) cannot engage his brain before he puts his foot in his mouth.

It is all right for us to come into this chamber and use rough and tumble tactics because we have nothing to lose. This business was started in the 1960s. It has been built up over the years and exports its products. This is the type of business that the government says we should encourage. This company meets the market demand, provides investment and wins export dollars for Australia; and what does it get in return? It gets an enormous kick in the head by the Prime Minister.

Voxson is only one example of many companies that are experiencing this downturn in their business and investments. I ask Senator Richardson—because he has some influence in the government—to lend a bit of weight. We have to stop the rot in Malaysia. If we do not stop the rot in Malaysia, we are going to find that many companies will be very financially damaged.

We can no longer have Senator Gareth Evans come into the Senate and pontificate about what is happening in Malaysia. The time has now come, before the rot sets in or before it goes any further down the drain, for the government to bite the bullet and do what is necessary to give these businesses not protection—they do not want protection—but a fair go. They are saying `Give us a fair go. We'll take the marketing risks, we'll invest our dollars and take the risks of investment in starting a business, but we cannot tolerate a Prime Minister going there and wrecking our businesses'.

That is what is happening. The Prime Minister must now do what is necessary to stand up for the interests of businesses that have taken the government's advice and gone offshore and invested, and brought in export dollars. The Prime Minister—I do not believe deliberately, but because he could not control his emotions—has sunk millions of dollars worth of investment and hundreds of businesses that have taken the opportunity to go offshore to invest and create employment.

Someone has to do something about it because we on this side of the chamber are not going to let this matter rest; we are going to continue to embarrass the government day after day until it finally has to do something to stand up for the people who have been affected. I urge Senator Richardson to do something about this, and encourage the Prime Minister to back off.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues to bring to the Senate the widespread concern in the business community, particularly of those who trade in the region and with Malaysia. I wish to alert the Senate to the concerns of one particular company. It is not a large company but it is a company that has been able, through very hard work, to establish effective trading relations with Malaysia. The company is called Rose's Fruit Juice Co. Pty Ltd. It worked very hard to establish a market in Malaysia and, after a period of hard work, managed to achieve some success. It is concerned that, because of the problems which have now emerged in our relations with Malaysia as a result of the blundering of Mr Keating and the mishandling by Senator Gareth Evans, the future of this market which it worked so hard for may, in some way, be put in jeopardy.

PARA.TAB: I put it to the Senate that there is widespread concern in the business community. We have been lectured by this Prime Minister for a long time about how we need to establish links with Asia and how Australians have to become more sensitive to Asian feelings. Mr President, you will recall the absurdity of a few short months ago when we were told that we had to change our constitution and our flag to make ourselves more part of the region. It was a foolish comment at the time, and does it not sound so utterly absurd now!

TALK.START.PARA: —This is Mr Keating engaging in Asia!

—That is right. As my colleague Senator Hill said, this is Mr Keating's attempt to engage in the region and make a big man of himself. How one can make a big man and a big leader of himself when he bags his country's flag and constitution in the region is beyond me, but it shows the attitude of this man.

PARA.TAB: I stress what my colleagues have said, which is certainly backed up by my own contacts in the business community, that there is very widespread concern about our trading with Malaysia. Many jobs are at stake and a number of people who have invested a lot of money in order to build this relationship—a relationship that was encouraged by the Prime Minister—are now feeling greatly concerned.

I put it to the Senate that this mishandling has to cease. The government has to take some action in my view to ensure that our relations are restored to a more productive basis. Failing that, Senator Richardson, who is in the chamber and who seems to be the king maker in the Labor Party, perhaps might do the country a favour and find another leader. This country certainly needs one.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Kernot this day, relating to the investment of superannuation funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Not surprisingly, the response this afternoon by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) confirming and endorsing the fact that the federal government is seriously examining a move to direct a fixed proportion of superannuation funds to be invested in small and medium sized business has brought outrage and criticism from a wide range of industry groups.

PARA.TAB: When the government first mooted the superannuation guarantee charge whereby employers were obliged to fund their employees' superannuation retirement benefits, many far-sighted observers believed that this pool of funds would be seen as a pool that the government could use for its own economic directions.

Within about 12 months of the passage of this legislation the government is now moving to interfere with investment patterns of superannuation moneys. Such plans to interfere with retirement savings will undermine the public's confidence in superannuation. A recent report by MLC-BIS Shrapnel confirmed that confidence in superannuation had unfortunately fallen to a new low.

Many years ago we had what is known as the 30-20 investment rule whereby legislative provisions meant that investment had to be 30 per cent in government securities of which a minimum had to be placed in Commonwealth bonds. Although unpopular at the time, I remind the Senate that both capital and income in such a legislative provision were secure, but not so; with income flowing to medium and small size businesses, even the capital could be at risk.

I also draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in the event of loss of such capital, there could be constitutional implications for the Commonwealth's directives. But attempts by state governments in recent times to meddle in capital markets have not been good, and I draw the Senate's attention to the Victorian Economic Development Corporation.

When banks cannot be persuaded to lend, why should the government allow small contributions from people to be put at risk? It also runs counter to the prudential standards and the need to protect retirees' superannuation moneys, particularly in the recently passed superannuation security investment legislation package of seven important bills.

The government's failure to enable moneys to be attracted through incentives, such as development capital for new corporations through the MICs, which provided generous tax incentives, is but one example of the government's failed attempts to provide a climate in which capital could be available to small business. Therefore, I use this opportunity to call on the government to promote small business not only through economic reform but also to develop appropriate finance mechanisms available to small business, but not by putting retirees' funds at risk in the form of a direction of superannuation moneys.

I remind the Senate that a set percentage of superannuation directed to small business can also cause dilemmas for trustees because under the SIS legislation, the prudential controls which were designed to protect the superannuation moneys of retirees, these trustees and investment managers are charged with the responsibility of upholding prudential standards and investing securely.

SPEECH.PARA: They could be legislatively at risk in terms of a financial or a gaol penalty in the event of investing in small companies which, for example, go bankrupt. I urge the government to approach this issue with caution because it has many ramifications, particularly for the superannuation industry. I think finance for small business can be better served by other avenues.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson will not be surprised to know, considering the remarks I have made in the Select Committee on Superannuation over several years, that I look with great interest at this policy U-turn by the government. He will recall from the Senate committee recommendations that I was hoping that we would be more specific about the direction of investment, but I agreed to the recommendation which said, `Give us time, we'll change the culture, and we'll have a three-year review of how the industry is changing its own culture'. I am not convinced that that is happening as swiftly as ASFA is claiming in today's press.

PARA.TAB: We should not lose sight of the facts that the superannuation funds have already received an absolutely massive fillip from this government from the compulsory collection of superannuation and that the scheme is underpinned by a massive $5 billion in tax concessions. That is why I think it is a legitimate question to ask: should not a very small fixed proportion of this $5 billion be invested in Australian small and medium business enterprises in this wonderfully nebulous national interest?

In my view, it is wrong to say that we cannot pick winners. We can have set criteria. Other countries do it and they do it well. It is also erroneous to assume that all of us would not benefit from the productive investment of some small fixed amount of this money. If we look at the investment patterns of the super funds, we see that many of them have overinvested in property, equities, cash and overseas investments. In fact, $26 billion of the $169 billion in super fund assets is held overseas.

Despite the answer of the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) today, I think there is clear evidence that banks are not lending the necessary capital to small and medium businesses and that the interest rate spread on fully secured small business loans is currently between eight and 10 per cent—and is rising. That is not conducive to the success of small and medium sized businesses.

As to the mandating of this small amount, we have not even seen some sort of requirement from the government which says, `Okay, let fund members nominate if they are prepared to take a small risk in the longer term national interest'. As I have said before, if someone had put that to me when I was just starting in the work force, I am the sort of person who would have said, `Yes, I am'. I think there are a lot of other Australians out there who would be willing to do it.

Overall, this situation points to the failure of voluntarism. Voluntarism underpinned the government's entire superannuation policy. It failed. Here are two more areas of failure: the failure of the pooled development funds—they have not worked and the government now has to restructure them—and the failure of voluntarism to persuade banks to look at sufficient lending rates for small businesses.

I welcome the minister's statements. I do not want him to lose sight of where the ideas came from, though. That is becoming very common. The jobs levy is a recent example that comes to mind. Guess what? Now it is having another look at the direction of superannuation investment funds. I will just send it another invoice for policy development.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was stimulated into rising by that last remark of Senator Kernot. I cannot let go the claim by Senator Kernot, as well as she handles her position, that the Democrats are the fountain of all good policy—
—Nobody said that.

—She certainly implied it if she did not say it. Let me deal with the substance of her claims. Firstly, Minister Griffiths has not made a policy U-turn. He has not enunciated any policy. What he has done is encourage a public debate, and he has made that very clear.

PARA.TAB: He has also said that, at the end of the day, cabinet must make the decisions on this matter. In fact, the minister is doing no more than Senator Kernot, the opposition and this side endorsed in respect of the policy recommendation of the Senate committee that we should have a very public debate on this matter over the next couple of years. So Senator Kernot should not claim that she is the centre of all virtue when it comes to public policy on superannuation.

As to Senator Kernot's remarks about overseas experience, it is certainly true that there are some success stories involving the direction of investment by governments overseas. Senator Kernot did not mention it, but I think she had in mind the Singapore Central Provident Fund. In that case, 40 per cent of the wages of employers and employees is collected and put into the Singapore Central Provident Fund.

We are off-side with Malaysia at the moment and so I do not want to get off-side with the Singapore government, but Singapore does have what I would regard as a quasi-democracy. It does have the authority and political power to—and it does it, as I understand—direct investment quite rigorously from one section of the economy to the other. It does that to the extent that the Singapore government has said to heavy industry through the Central Provident Fund, `We don't want heavy industry; we are not going to give you capital'. That is what I understand happens in Singapore.

If that is the sort of regime Senator Kernot is suggesting, I do not believe that is acceptable in Australia. It just will not work in this country. However, that is not to say that we do not have a problem. There certainly is a problem. The very structure and nature of superannuation, with the trustee system, do not encourage a sufficient spread of investment, particularly in some of the more innovative capital areas. That is not to accept the logic of the Democrats' argument that one would therefore mandate investment. There are other ways of overcoming what may be problems with the trustee system. They were highlighted in the recent legislation that Senator Watson has drawn attention to—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that was the problem.

—That is what I believe is part of the problem. The trustees themselves are inherently conservative. They do not have an awareness of the market; they do not have an awareness of risk. I think part of the program in the superannuation area is to encourage the trustees. It may well be that we have to mandate them to take part in investment courses and education and training of some standing. Minister Griffiths is, I think quite rightly, ensuring that we have a rigorous public debate on this matter. A rigorous public debate has not taken place and I am concerned that, as part of the policy agenda, this rigorous public debate has not taken place.

—I simply cannot sit in this chamber and listen to Senator Kernot speaking about her concern for small business. Senator Kernot has cooperated with the government in a massive tax hike on small business. She is cooperating with the government in an industrial relations reform bill which will savagely affect small business via sections 45D and 45E. She helped the government put through the superannuation levy and the training levy.

PARA.TAB: All those things add greatly to the costs of small business. For Senator Kernot and her colleagues in the Australian Democrats to stand up in this chamber and say that they have some concern for these people is just absurd.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! On 25 November 1993, I informed the Senate of the death earlier that day of former Senator Condon Bryan Byrne, senator for the state of Queensland from 1951 to 1959 and from 1968 to 1974. In accordance with the wishes of the Senate, I now call the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Thursday 25 November 1993, of former Senator Condon Bryan Byrne, Senator for the State of Queensland from 1951 to 1959 and from 1968 to 1974, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Condon Byrne was born on 25 May 1910 at Yea, Victoria. He was educated at the Christian Brothers College, Brisbane, and the University of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: He joined the Queensland Public Service in 1928 and among the positions he held were Acting Official Secretary of the Queensland Premier's Department and Acting Assistant Under Secretary of the Department of Labour and Industry. He was also private secretary to Vince Gair when he was a minister in the Queensland government.

Senator Byrne was first elected to the Senate in 1951. He served on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for six years. From 1952 to 1955 he was Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

After his defeat in the 1958 election, he returned to his Brisbane legal practice. In 1967 he again stood for election, but this time as a Democratic Labor Party candidate. He was successful in that election and served a further six years in this place. During that time Senator Byrne also held the positions of Temporary Chairman of Committees and that of DLP Whip.

Senator Byrne was a well liked member of this house. He was a keen debater and welcomed contributions from both sides of the chamber. He was a firm supporter of the role of the Senate as the house of review.

I had the opportunity of meeting Senator Byrne on a number of occasions. In fact, on the only two occasions that I ever attended the races in Queensland he was there as well. I shall remember him as a pleasant and generous companion. On behalf of the government, I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of coalition senators, I join with Senator Richardson in expressing our regret at the recent death at the age of 83 of former Senator Condon Byrne. As was stated, he was born in Victoria in 1910 and later moved to Queensland. He studied at the University of Queensland and later qualified as a barrister. He began his career in the Queensland Public Service. For nine years from 1942 to 1951 he was private secretary to Vince Gair, who was then Minister for Mines, Labour and Industry in the Queensland Labor government.

PARA.TAB: This partnership was only broken in 1951 when Condon Byrne was elected a Labor senator. I understand that he was reputed to be the first graduate of the University of Queensland to enter federal parliament. He came here with a formidable reputation as a debater, which I understand was further enhanced during his years in the Senate.

In 1957 he left the Australian Labor Party and joined the newly formed Queensland Labor Party, again with Vince Gair. As it turned out, Condon Byrne was the only federal representative the QLP ever had. In the 1958 election, he stood as a QLP candidate but was defeated. The QLP was later absorbed into the Democratic Labor Party. From 1968 Condon Byrne and Vince Gair were two of the four DLP senators who held the balance of power in the Senate. After his defeat in 1974 he returned to his practice at the Queensland bar.
On behalf of opposition senators, I join with the government in offering our sincere condolences to his relatives and friends in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the members of the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the government. Condon Byrne had a long and distinguished career in federal politics as a Queensland senator, firstly for the ALP and then later for the Democratic Labor Party. Condon Byrne was a man of great integrity who always put his personal beliefs and loyalties above party politics. He was a lifelong opponent of the tyranny of communism and a strong supporter of basic family values.

PARA.TAB: Although born in Victoria, Condon Byrne was raised and educated in Brisbane and attended my alma mater, St Joseph's College, Gregory Terrace, before entering the University of Queensland to study law. He qualified as a barrister before joining the Queensland Public Service. He was employed as a private secretary to the former Queensland Premier, Vince Gair, when Gair was Minister for Mines, Labour and Industry and then Treasurer.

In 1951 Condon Byrne's career in federal politics was launched with his election to the Senate as a Labor senator for Queensland. With the Labor split in 1957, he joined the breakaway Queensland Labor Party, following the lead of his mentor, the ousted Premier, Vince Gair.He stood as a Queensland Labor Party candidate in 1958 but was defeated and left public life to practice law.

In 1967 Condon Byrne was returned to the Senate as a Queensland senator for the Democratic Labor Party, which had formally affiliated with the Queensland Labor Party in 1962. He then joined his ex-boss, Vince Gair, who had been elected as a DLP senator two years earlier. With the election of Condon Byrne, the Democratic Labor Party became a four-strong Senate team that was able to command the balance of power in the Senate, which it held for seven years.

During his parliamentary career Condon Byrne was a hard working committee member on several key committees including the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs; the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Science and the Arts; and the Senate Select Committee on Foreign Ownership and Control. He also served as Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts as well as the DLP Whip.

In 1974 Condon Byrne retired from federal politics for good and returned to his Brisbane legal practice. Condon Byrne will be remembered for his integrity, loyalty and staunch personal convictions as well as for the many years of service that he devoted to the people of Queensland. I am sure that all honourable senators will join with me in extending our sympathy to Condon Byrne's family and many friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —Condon Bryan Byrne, a former Queensland senator, represented three parties in this parliament: the Australian Labor Party, the Queensland Labor Party and the Democratic Labor Party. His victory in 1968, after nine years in the political wilderness, gave the DLP four senators and the balance of power in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: During his time in the parliament he was regarded as one of the Senate's best debaters. His party, the DLP, played a major role in Australia's controversial decision in the 1960s to buy F111 fighter bombers for the RAAF. As a matter of fact, his party was involved not only in that controversy, but also, as Senator Boswell has indicated, in the controversy surrounding the Labor split in the 1950s. That controversy has always been of great interest to me. I have studied it at some length because I am fascinated by the deep loyalties and the deep antagonisms which his party and this period of Australian history generated.

Condon Byrne once got me into deep trouble. When I advertised a church meeting at which he was speaking, I was told that one should not mix religion and politics. Everyone knows that they have always mixed. Former Senator Condon Byrne knew that and never disguised his political or his religious commitment. The Australian Democrats salute him for that, although we would not always have been on his side with respect to the opinions that he expressed. I would like to add to the other condolences which have been expressed by extending the sympathy of the Australian Democrats to the family of Condon Byrne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with this condolence motion to honour the passing of former Senator Condon Byrne. I met Condon Byrne perhaps three times. I was elected to this place the year after he left, so I do not have a great deal of personal knowledge of Condon Byrne. I am grateful, however, to Mr Denis Strangman, who many senators will recall worked in this place for over 30 years. He is an erudite and meticulous historian who is responsible for the following obituary of Condon Byrne.

PARA.TAB: This is an historic occasion because Condon Byrne was the last of the Democratic Labor Party senators to pass away. At the height of the Democratic Labor Party's influence in 1974, when it held the balance of power in the Senate, there were five DLP senators: Vince Gair from Queensland; Frank McManus from Victoria; Jack Kane from New South Wales; Jack Little from Victoria; and Condon Byrne from Queensland. The party had grown out of the split in the Labor Party during the fifties.

The DLP lost its Senate representation at the 1974 election following acceptance by Vince Gair of an appointment by the ALP government as ambassador to Ireland. The posting was part of a scheme hatched by the late Senator Lionel Murphy to create a more favourable numbers balance for the government in the Senate but was thwarted by some very clever footwork by the then Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and his Canberra party colleagues. Nevertheless, the episode contributed greatly to the party's Senate demise in 1974.

The DLP had continual representation in the Senate from 1955 when former ALP Senator George Cole, from the state of Tasmania, declared for the DLP. Over the years time has claimed them all. George Cole died in 1969, Vince Gair in 1980, Frank McManus in 1983, and Jack Little and Jack Kane in 1988.

As with George Cole, Condon Byrne had been elected to the Senate first as an ALP senator but associated himself with the Queensland Labor Party in May 1957 after Vince Gair, as Queensland Labor Premier, was expelled from the ALP. Gair was expelled ostensibly because of his failure to implement party policy but, in reality, as part of the continuing split in the Labor Party which commenced with Dr Evatt's attack in October 1954 on industrial groupers and the Catholic social studies movement and the role it played in the ALP.
Condon Byrne had been private secretary to Gair when he was Queensland Treasurer. Although most of the state Labor cabinet stuck with Gair, Byrne was the only federal MP to join him in the QLP.

Condon saw out his term as a senator until 1959 and returned to practice at the bar in Brisbane but was re-elected in 1967 as a DLP senator. Although he was born at Yea in Victoria on 15 May 1910, his family moved to Brisbane during his early years. He was educated by the Marist Brothers in Bendigo and, as has been indicated by other honourable senators, the Christian Brothers in Brisbane and was thought to have been the first graduate from the University of Queensland to enter federal parliament.

He never married and lived with his sister, Pierre, who died in Brisbane last year. Condon Byrne was a gracious person who had a firm attachment to his Catholic faith. More than once in reaching quickly for his handkerchief while debating in the Senate, he would inadvertently pull out some loose coins, a packet of cigars and a set of rosary beads which would clatter on to his desk.

Condon Byrne was a polished debater who relied only on a handful of written notes. He was firmly committed to the DLP policies of the time of opposition to communism internationally and within the Australian industrial movement, economic justice for the family, equality in educational funding for government and non-government schools and the distributist philosophy of decentralisation of administration and ownership.

In the Senate Condon Byrne played a key part in the resurgence of the Senate committee system in the late 1960s and early 1970s and performed the role of consensus promoter between the unlikely alliance of the ALP and the DLP. In this role he formulated resolutions which could attract the support of both parties and he worked closely with the then clerk of the Senate, the late Jim Odgers.

During his time at the Queensland bar Condon Byrne was part of what one might describe as a salon of criminal and civil barristers, which included Jim Killen in his pre-ministerial days, Dan Casey, and Bill Cuthbert, with whom he shared ownership of several, mostly unsuccessful, horses. To an outsider, the salon was believed to be in perpetual debate about current social and political issues with court appearances an irritating interruption. Another colleague with whom he enjoyed discussing the great issues of the day was the late Kevin Cairns, MHR, from Queensland who became minister for housing.

Those who worked with Condon in the parliamentary arena will remember him as a charming and courteous person who, despite the often bitter experience of the Labor split, did not bear personal grudges. On New Year's day this year he phoned a former colleague in Canberra to say that his legs were packing up and it seemed as though he would have to enter a nursing home. Reminiscing about the Gair affair, he recalled that he had been in the chair when Vince Gair was expelled from the parliamentary DLP. For a man who always sought to focus on the best side of human nature and to promote reconciliation, this episode involving his former political mentor and parliamentary colleague must have been a bitter experience.

Condon Byrne came from an era when writers such as G.K. Chesterton were popular in some circles. In a copy of one of G.K. Chesterton's books, which Condon Byrne probably used, a saying has been marked which one could almost visualise Condon introducing into a debate about education in the Senate. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Modern education means handing down the customs of the minority, and rooting out the customs of the majority.
Condon enjoyed these pithy sayings, another favourite being:
Tradition is the democracy of the dead.

PARA.TAB: The late Condon Byrne was a defender of tradition and customs—not as a reactionary, but as a believer who laid claim to a Labor tradition which, in earlier times, once found a coexistence with a philosophy of social action based on religious beliefs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about Condon Byrne, as I knew him in his maturity. I think Senator Harradine summarised his character very well. He was a man of absolute integrity. His philosophy was as straight as a gun barrel, as were his character and his bearing. He had a twinkle in his eye and he engaged in political discourse every moment of the day. As Senator Harradine said, social policy interested him.

PARA.TAB: It was a great delight to meet Condon Byrne in company with the fabled Dan Casey, the leader of the bar in Queensland in his time and a person who dominated the law in Queensland. With both of them quipping away, as they did in their maturity—I think they were in their seventies at the time—one could not spend a more pleasant time than spend a few minutes with them while they debated the issues of the day, solving all the problems affecting Australia and the world at large. I am sure that if we had the opportunity of following the advice that they gave, we would not have some of the problems that exist today.
In summary, Condon Byrne was a man of absolute integrity who had a religious basis that dominated his philosophy of intellectual calibre that was equalled only by his friend Dan Casey.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.
Senator SHERRY (Tasmania—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Prim-

PROCTEXT.PARA: ary Industries and Energy)—I present the government's response to report No. 9 of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on the superannuation supervision bills.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.
Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: RESPONSE TO NINTH REPORT OF SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON SUPERANNUATION
4.1 The Committee recommends that clause 64 be amended to allow certain types of assets to be acquired by a superannuation fund from a member or relative of the member at arms length price.
The Government has given consideration to the Committee's recommendation and will not make an amendment to this clause.
4.2 The Committee recommends that the penalty for breach of clause 64 be amended to provide a maximum penalty of 200 penalty points (one penalty point equals $100) and/or one years imprisonment.
The Government has given consideration to the Committee's recommendation and will not make an amendment to this clause.

5.1 The Committee recommends that the Government consider amending the Corporations Law to provide public offer superannuation fund managers with the right to request that the trustee retire on the grounds that it is in the best interests of unit holders.
The Government will give consideration to this issue.

6.1 The Committee recommends that short term borrowing be allowed where it was `not intended' that the borrowing would be needed, rather than if the need for the borrowing `was not reasonably foreseeable'. Accordingly, clause 65 should be amended to substitute the words `not intended' for `not reasonably foreseeable'.
The Government will be moving an amendment to give effect to this recommendation.
6.2 The Committee recommends that, following the implementation of the SIS legislation, consideration be given to spelling out in regulations the duties of custodians.
The Government will give further consideration to this issue when drafting the regulations.

6.3 The Committee recognises the need for a capital adequacy requirement to establish the substance of custodians and, to a lesser extent, provide a financial buffer in the case of insolvency. The Committee recommends that in drafting regulations the ISC continue to consider a more comprehensive and flexible approach to the capital adequacy requirements for fund managers and custodians.
The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation and will give further consideration to the matter.

6.4 The Committee recommends that provisions relating to the removal of fund managers consequent to a responsible officer becoming a disqualified person be amended to ensure that there is not an automatic termination of the manager.
The Committee further recommends that in these cases it is the duty of the fund manager to remove the disqualified person from any financial dealings with the fund.
The Government will be moving an amendment to clause 118 and 119 of the SIS Bill which will give effect to both recommendations of the Committee.

6.5 The Committee recommends that the Government monitor the operation of SIS legislation to ensure that it does not result in any harsh or unintended consequences for custodians who temporarily fail to satisfy eligibility requirements.
The Government will give further consideration to this issue.
6.6 The Committee recommends that the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities investigate `soft commissions' as part of its inquiry into institutional investment.

7.1 The Committee recommends that the ISC monitor closely the appointment and termination of auditors in the superannuation industry and, if necessary, advise the Government that legislation be introduced to protect auditors from unjust or unreasonable termination.
The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation and will give further consideration as necessary.
7.2 The Committee recommends that the ISC continue the practice of notifying the professional accounting bodies where it has cause to believe that an auditor should be removed.
The ISC will continue in this practice.

7.3 The Committee recommends that, in accordance with the Committee's first report Safeguarding Super (recommendation 4.11), the Government, in consultation with the professional accounting bodies, again consider establishing a register of superannuation auditors and that the register consist of persons who have completed the training prescribed by the accounting professions.
The Government will give further consideration to this issue in the light of experience and after discussions with the professions.

8.1 The Committee reiterates the recommendation of its first report that the Government explore the possibility of obtaining a referral by the states, either formal or defacto, of their power over superannuation.
The Government will give further consideration to this issue.
8.2 The Committee further recommends that the ISC and ASC implement a system of registration and filing where only a single return is required by corporate trustees of superannuation funds.
The ISC is exploring this issue with the ASC and the Attorney-General's Department with the objective of achieving the terms of this recommendation.

9.1 The Committee recommends that the SIS legislation be amended to allow superannuation funds to collect member TFNs, subject to member consent, from the date the Bill receives Royal Assent. In addition the Committee recommends that the SIS legislation be amended to allow superannuation funds, to use TFNs for taxation and transfer of benefits purposes.
The Government will be moving an amendment to give effect to this recommendation.

10.1 The Committee recommends that the Bill be amended to exempt the States and the Northern Territory. It is further recommended that, if required, the ITAA and the Superannuation Guarantee Charge (Administration) Act be amended to ensure that existing treatment/coverage for certain state superannuation schemes under those Acts is maintained.
The Government will be moving an amendment to give effect to this recommendation.

11.1 The Committee recommends that having regard to the impact of the SIS legislation on the superannuation industry, the Government amends the SIS legislation to have the temporary powers of modification and exemption for the ISC continued until 1 July 1995. The Committee recommends that during this period the ISC develop definitive guidelines on discretions to replace the existing broad powers.
The Committee further recommends that the ISC report annually to Parliament on the frequency, incidence an nature of the exercise of its discretions.
The Government will be moving amendments to give effect to these recommendations.

11.2 The Committee recommends that the Government negotiate with the States and the Northern Territory with a view to agreeing to amendments to the SIS and relevant state legislation to enable Commonwealth legislation on unclaimed superannuation moneys to operate to the exclusion of state law.
The Government will give further consideration to this issue.

11.3 The Committee recommends that the ISC liaise with the ASC with a view to overcoming the exclusion of board members of trustee companies from participating in the company's conduct as trustee of a superannuation fund by the operation of section 232A of the Corporations Law.

The Government agrees that is desirable that board members of trustee companies should be able to fully participate in the company's conduct as trustees and will give further consideration to this issue.
12.1 The Committee recommends that the Government amend the SIS legislation to insert the definition of `market value'.
The Government will be moving an amendment to give effect to this recommendation.

12.2 The Committee recommends that the Senate agree to a Government amendment extending the dates of elections for superannuation funds to become regulated funds under SIS according to the schedule set out in the Report at page xi.
The Government will be moving an amendment to give effect to this recommendation.

13.1 The Committee recommends that the Consequential Amendments Bill be amended to include a definition of `the value of the property', which outlines a method of valuation and specifies a point in time at which the valuation is to occur.

The reason for the recommendation, which reflects a submission received by the Committee, appears to be to correct a perceived gap in proposed section 116(5) of the Act, which would be added by enactment of paragraph 7(f) of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill 1993. The perceived gap is that there is no provision for the time and method of valuation of `the value of the property' in proposed section 116(5) of the Act.

The Government does not consider, there is any such gap as the proposed subsection 116(7) of the Act provides for a comprehensive power to make Statutory Rules prescribing the time and method of valuation of `the value of the property' in proposed section 116(5) of the Act.

16.1 The Committee recommends that the Government regulate to exclude from the Complaints Tribunal those matters involving trustee decisions, made prior to the commencement of the Superannuation (resolution of Complaints) Act, as to who is entitled to a benefit which has already been paid.
The Government does not consider it appropriate to restrict access to the Tribunal in the way proposed by the Committee.

16.2 The Committee recommends that the Government exclude from the Tribunal's jurisdiction, the parts of a complaint involving issues of procedural fairness and the legal interpretation of the terms `disability' in a deed.
This issue will be considered in the preparation of regulations.

17.1 The Committee recommends that the Government consider supporting the establishment of an independent superannuation consumer advisory service by way of grants from Consolidated Revenue over three years. The Committee further recommends that the Government review the funding arrangement with a view to industry assisted funding after the expiry of the three year period.
The Government will give further consideration to this issue.

18.1 The Committee recommends the Bill be amended to specify that the degree of satisfaction required for the Tribunal to affirm a decision pursuant to clause 37(2) of the Bill is that of reasonable satisfaction, that is, satisfaction on the balance of probabilities.
The Government considered this amendment to be unnecessary because such decisions are of an administrative nature and therefore must be made on the balance of probabilities.
18.2 The Committee recommends that the ISC address the issue of notifying members of their right to have an adverse decision of a trustee reviewed by the Superannuation Consumer Complaints Tribunal.
The Government will ensure that this matter is covered in the regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National Botanic Gardens is one of our national collecting institutions, like the Australian National Gallery. It was the first major botanic gardens to be devoted to Australian native plants. The collections include the magnificent living collections in the gardens at Black Mountain and Jervis Bay, the specimens collection in the herbarium, and a spectacular photographic collection. The gardens pioneered the computerised linking of each plant among all of these collections.

PARA.TAB: The gardens has been a focus for this study—the use and enjoyment of Australian native plants. It has coordinated the development of the Australian plant conservation network to manage the national effort to grow endangered plants and to prevent their extinction. The Australian National Botanic Gardens plays other national roles in helping our neighbours in South East Asia and the Pacific to develop botanic gardens and to conserve their native plants.

This management plan is the first formal recognition by the parliament of these important activities for this country. The gardens has suffered in the past because of the informal nature of its origin. The management plan provides the strategic directions for the gardens to develop over the next five years, and I hope that it will obtain the resources to improve its collections, its national role and its visitor services. Anyone who has visited the gardens realises what an excellent resource it is; people take pleasure in looking at the native flora of this country.

The plan also discusses the initiative to combine the national gardens herbarium and research facilities and that of the CSIRO in a new centre for plant biodiversity research. A national herbarium linked to the other collections of the gardens and associated research are essential for managing our national botanic resources to conserve and utilise effectively our unique and wonderful plants. I commend the Australian National Botanic Gardens and the ANCA for this foresighted management plan.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate Mr Irving, Mr Clements, the other members of the board, and the staff of the Australian Horticultural Corporation on the progress that has been made since 1988. The horticultural industries of Australia offer vast export potential. A lot of people in our part of the world are going to require a lot of food in the years ahead, and Australia is still best placed to provide top quality products as they further develop.

PARA.TAB: For instance, the CSIRO and others have provided considerable assistance in developing the green plastic film and in improving the transport of fruit and vegetables by chilling and humidifying them. We have all sorts of developing areas that can still do much to develop Australia's export trade. On page 19 of the annual report, we see how significant Malaysia is for our export industries. Of the horticultural corporation members' exports to the Far East, apples comprise 28 per cent, pears comprise 12 per cent, naval oranges comprise 28 per cent, and valencia oranges comprise 25 per cent. What will happen with all these things?

There is absolutely no feeling of urgency as, day by day, we watch our trade disappear down the gurgler. How long will it be before somebody does something? Are these people supposed to leave the apples on the trees? Are they supposed to not plant their vegetables? These people have spent considerable amounts of money. They have spent years of work establishing industries and trade in this part of the world and, with one word, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) can put it all down the chute and then do nothing at all about trying to get some recovery. What is going to happen? Will it be hours, days, weeks or months before something will happen? Are these people not entitled to be told? It is all very well to produce a nice book and come up with photos of Senator Sherry, but the figures are absolutely disastrous. This is a major export area that has been shot to ribbons and nothing is happening to put it back together.

We have to look at the effort that has been put into working closely with these countries and their industries. I realise that this matter probably does not worry the government members too much; they do not seem to be at all concerned about it. But I point out to those opposite that the industries that I am talking about are worried. Those of us on this side of the chamber are also worried.

The value of vegetable exports in the Malaysian trade increased by $21 million in 1992-93. The growth in export of vegetables was 13 per cent over the previous year, and 34 per cent from 1990-91. That is an enormous increase. It has happened after a big investment of money and a long time. The value of exports of fruit and nuts for 1992-93 was $33.2 million. This represents an increase of 28 per cent over the previous year, and an increase of 69 per cent from 1990 to 1992. Out of all these agricultural products that we are talking about, milk and cream products, at a value of $105 million, represent a significantly larger export than everything, other than horticultural products. We do need to know what is going to happen with this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to this report, I wish to make some comments relating to the funding of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and to its functions. I recently spoke to representatives of some of the fruit growers in Western Australia who expressed great concern about the levy system used to fund the activities of the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

PARA.TAB: Currently, a levy is charged on the gross value of farm-gate production to fund marketing programs by the Australian Horticultural Corporation. Whilst this is a laudable aim, the concern in Western Australia is that the regional differences in this large nation are not acknowledged within the centralised AHC system. This point was made by the Western Australian Fruit Growers Association to the horticultural task force.

The key points made in that submission relate to the uniqueness of the Western Australian fruit industry with its geographical isolation, which is exacerbated by quarantine restrictions. This isolation has resulted in a dependence on local markets and exports to South-East Asia. The current Malaysian debacle is not helping in this regard. As a result, the Western Australian apple, pear, citrus and stone fruit industries have resolved to achieve a withdrawal from the AHC and an exemption from the levy.
It is interesting to note in this regard that reference to this problem is made in the Industry Commission report, which was also tabled today. Page 24 of that report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission proposed that levy funds used for programs requested by the contributing industry should be paid directly to that industry, with no obligation on the industry to engage the services of the AHC. Because of disparate regional characteristics of many parts of the sector, the Commission also proposed that levy funds be devolved to regional industry bodies.
I understand that the Western Australian Fruit Growers Association supports this approach. I trust that the government gives it serious consideration. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1992-93 annual report of the Industry Commission that has been tabled here today provides a quite damning indictment of Labor's poor economic management. In particular, it shows quite clearly that either Labor has given up the game of economic reform or it simply does not know where to go from here. More likely, it is a combination of both.

PARA.TAB: The opening page of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has the knowledge and the resources to achieve the rapid and sustained growth needed to improve living standards and to make real inroads into unacceptably high levels of unemployment. But we need to improve the operation of the Australian economy quickly if we are to make the most of the opportunities that are available to us. This means both stepping up the progress on existing reform and extending reforms to new areas. A key issue is to remove the institutional blockages to reform that are preventing a better functioning of Australia's federal system of government. More than ever, Australia needs to establish a national approach to resolving truly national problems.
The report says many things in amplification of that. I will try to touch on two or three of them.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I congratulate the Industry Commission for identifying an improvement in federal-state relations as an essential institutional reform that is required in this country if we are to achieve our potential. That was one of the key planks of the coalition's policies at the last election. It is regrettable that this Prime Minister, a very centralist Prime Minister, has through most of his actions, not just as Prime Minister but in his earlier years, fought to prevent a proper balance of federal-state relations. The Industry Commission seems to have picked that up in its report.
The commission also states:

SPEECH.PARA: More than a decade ago, the Commonwealth Government recognised that Australians could only secure a better long-term future by opening the economy to the rest of the world and confronting the challenges and opportunities in global markets.
It then goes on to say:
With a more open economy, world economic conditions and Australia's ability to improve its productivity performance are of critical importance for our prosperity.

It says that the movement towards the achievement of those things and the necessary reforms have been frustratingly slow in some areas and that, although some reform achievements have been made, `much more remains to be done'.

PARA.TAB: There is a very interesting appendix to the report. Appendix C attempts to measure Australia's comparative economic performance against its top 16 trading partners. On virtually all of the criteria that the measurement comparison is taken against, Australia performs very poorly. By 1992, Australia had the second highest rate of unemployment against the economies with which it was being compared. We had the fifth lowest rate of economic growth of all the economies shown.

In terms of our ranking as an exporter, we have gone backwards in the decade from 1980 to 1990 as far as merchandise trade is concerned. In 1990, we were 18th in the world in world trade in merchandise. By 1990, we had slipped to 22nd.

It is very disturbing to note that Australia has lost its market share in important east Asian markets. We have fallen from a 4.3 per cent share of that market in the mid-1980s to a 3.8 per cent share in the early 1990s.

As I said at the outset, the report on all counts is a quite damning indictment of our lack of progress in terms of economic reform when our progress is compared to other countries in the world. That is what one needs to do to measure properly our international competitiveness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate particularly to appendix U of the annual report of the Industry Commission, which talks about the activities of the inquiry and the reports of the commission. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission's inquiry program embraces a wide range of industry and reform issues. This appendix documents the progress of inquiries.
The report also mentions some inquiries which are listed for the future. I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to one of them, which is the projected inquiry into charities and related bodies.

PARA.TAB: I asked a question of Senator Schacht in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) some time ago about the matter. I received an answer which at the time was not satisfactory but which nevertheless enabled me to continue some research into this issue and to note the concern of many church welfare related bodies about this inquiry.

The Democrats believe that there ought to be a wide-ranging inquiry of which the Industry Commission inquiry could be a part. Our concern is that this inquiry by the Industry Commission would be too narrow to get at the questions which need to be asked. We are waiting for the terms of reference for the inquiry to be released. Although they were supposed to have been made available a week ago, we have still not been able to get our hands on them.

It seems to us that issues such as accounting and audit standards, law reform and a more complete list of church, welfare and not-for-profit sector organisations would be a very useful area of inquiry for the Senate. Our problem is that we believe that an inquiry by the Industry Commission would have too narrow a focus—a focus on economic and efficiency issues—and that this framework would not get at the areas in the whole charity and welfare sector which we believe need to be addressed. I place on the record our appreciation for the work of the commission but also our apprehension that the commission will not be able to ascertain the kinds of questions which we would want to ask of this sector.

It may be that one would have to ask whether the Industry Commission is the appropriate body to be asking questions of the church and welfare sector. We suggested to the government that a Senate select committee or a joint select committee would be the more appropriate body to ask these questions. We commend this report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry Commission report is very interesting. It is probably the first report that the new chairperson, Mr Scales, has presented. One could, as Senator Short has done, take the tables and economic statements in the report and draw a long bow to criticise the government. That is an absolutely legitimate thing to do.

PARA.TAB: My concern is with the totality of the report. I share Senator Woodley's concern but I suggest to him that we look at the Industry Commission in a new light now that it has a new chairman and hope that it will move out of the rut that it has got into as a propagator of economic rationalist theory in so many of its reports. The report I read recently that fits accurately into that category was the report on regional development.

I am sensitive to the fact that the churches and charities are to be looked at. The Industry Commission might fulfil some of the objectives that it has not fulfilled so far. On page 23 of the report some of the commission objectives are stated. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: facilitate adjustment to structural change in the economy and to ease social and economic hardships arising from those changes.

Once again, I believe that this report lacks the emphasis on the need for social and economic hardship to be addressed in its reports. It has been my belief over time that the Industry Commission presents a one sided analysis of the particular problems of industry. It is dominated by a theoretical economic approach in most cases. At the same time it has not taken up the need to give the government advice on addressing the social and economic hardships which inevitably must occur if we seek to change the structure of society.

PARA.TAB: For those reasons I am looking to the Chairman, Mr Scales, to broaden the approach of the Industry Commission in the future. I believe that the current inquiry into welfare and charities will probably be the final test for the commission. If the Industry Commission cannot be sensitive in this area in the way that I have described and finally achieve its objectives—I do not believe it has been able to do so up until now—we will have to examine whether it is worthwhile and if it is to be an authority for economic rationalist theories whether it might be better if it moves into the private sector. This would be one organisation that I could probably support for privatisation if it cannot give government balanced information and proposals for inevitable changes. If we propose change and we do not consider human beings, then we have failed. Up until now I believe that has been a singular weakness in the reports that have come from the Industry Commission. I look to Mr Scales to arrest that development. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend Robin Ritchie for the job he does on this council. I also commend Warren Starick and Murray Watson, who are the National Farmers Federation nominees, for their work. I note at the beginning of the report what Mr Ritchie said in his letter to the Hon. Simon Crean. The letter reads:

While it is clear that we have identified rather more of the state of national preparedness during this year, it is also clear that most of the States have continued to reduce their individual levels of resources. We are in the process of trying to identify whether the level of resources in national terms is adequate for any potential outbreak. We are holding a workshop early next year to enable us to put reliable figures on the question for you.
We have to take note of the object and functions of EXANDIS. The stated object of EXANDIS is to:

make available to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy a reliable source of information and advice of the nation's preparedness to take combatative and rehabilitative action regarding outbreaks in Australia of exotic animal diseases.

We have to think about the refugees coming into Australia at the moment and the problems they may create with some of their foods when they drop them on our northern shores. We have to consider the problems associated with wild pigs and other native feral animals in that area catching exotic diseases. The stated functions of EXANDIS are:
to inquire into, assess, and report to the Minister on:
—the adequacy of the strategies and procedures provided in any approved veterinary emergency plan, particularly in relation to planning, implementation, training, plant and equipment;
—the social and economic effects of exotic disease outbreaks . . .
In Australia, our reputation in quarantine matters is second to none. Fortunately, the council has developed a formula for paying compensation before we have had a major outbreak. The report states:

This recommends that the valuation, for compensation payments, of animals that are destroyed pursuant to response programs or that die of exotic disease, be assessed on a `post-quarantine clearance' basis (`market value' at the time of death/ destruction, adjusted if necessary to take account of any upward movement in market value at the time the affected property is cleared from quarantine restrictions and thus is eligible for restocking).

This is very important because if people in the industry know that there is to be just and adequate compensation obviously they will be much quicker in coming forward if an exotic disease is detected in their area. I commend this report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I commend the work that the council is doing. Australia at the moment is the leader as far as clean foods are concerned. We compete with other nations in the world that have blue tongue and other disease which are at the moment precluded from our markets. If we keep our markets clean we will be at the forefront of exports in the beef industry in particular in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Resolution of the Malaysian House of Representatives

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present the text of a resolution adopted by the Malaysian House of Representatives and an English translation, together with a letter from the High Commissioner for Malaysia to the President of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:
