TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 16 of 1993-94: Project Audit—`Pay for Performance'—Performance Appraisal and Pay in the Australian Public Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's report No. 16 is an important report. The Auditor-General's reports are always interesting and useful, and I think this one falls very much into that category. It is entitled Project Audit—`Pay for Performance'—Performance Appraisal and Pay in the Australian Public Service, and looks at performance appraisal and pay arrangements in the Australian Public Service.

PARA.TAB: The aim of the audit was to examine the implementation of performance appraisal and pay in the Australian Public Service with a view to identifying areas which could be made more effective or efficient. The audit also aimed to measure the extent to which the objectives of performance appraisal and pay have been met and whether individual agencies had complied with the Australian Public Service guidelines.

As we are all well aware, performance based pay is a relatively new innovation in the Public Service. Its progress is being watched with very keen interest because it has a great number of implications. It has considerable implications for the overall efficiency and productivity of the Australian Public Service. It also has significant potential implications for the total amount of money that the Australian taxpayers fork out to meet the salaries and other costs of employment of members of the Australian Public Service. The idea of the introduction of performance appraisal and pay was to see whether the efficiency of the Public Service could be lifted in the same way that we seek to achieve productivity and other efficiency gains throughout the economy.

It is a matter for concern that the Auditor-General's report is highly critical of the Public Service performance based pay arrangements to date. A flier that accompanies the report reproduces some of the report's main findings—and that is a very useful innovation—and summarises some of the key aspects of the report. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, it is the ANAO's opinion that performance appraisal and pay has not been implemented in accordance with the spirit of the workplace bargaining agreement or the APS guidelines in a significant number of agencies and that most agencies do not have any mechanisms for measuring the extent of achievement against the scheme's objectives.
In the body of the report the audit office adds to this by saying:
. . . it was unable to verify that any progress towards achievement of these objectives—
of the performance based pay—

had occurred at either the agency level or for the APS. The ANAO also has serious concerns as to whether the level of evaluation being undertaken by agencies will demonstrate that the objectives of performance appraisal and pay have been met in the future.
Some of the major findings of the report were as follows:
.90% of agencies—
of public sector agencies—
have paid performance pay to more than 90% of their senior officer staff

TALK.START.PARA: —Pretty high performers!

—As my colleague Senator Kemp says, there are either a lot of very high performers or there are some very real questions to be asked about the underlying bases of the scheme. The second finding states:

SPEECH.PARA: .there is an urgent need for the PSC and DIR to make a clear statement on whether performance pay is to be used as a reward for performance above normal job requirements or as recognition for the achievement of an officer's normal job requirements

In other words—and I am confident that my colleague Senator Kemp may build on this in his own remarks—we have been concerned for some time as to whether this system is simply going to be a method of giving a lot more people a lot more pay without any real performance requirement so far as increased productivity or efficiency is concerned. The third finding states:
.the higher the officer's classification the more likely they were to achieve a higher performance appraisal rating

Again, that raises many questions. It raises the old question in a different context of who guards the guardians, in my opinion, because if the main spin-offs—the higher appraisal ratings and, therefore, the higher financial rewards—are going to higher officers, one would surely have to question the efficiency of the operation and implementation of the scheme. It is an important finding that certainly requires a very careful explanation. The fourth finding states:
.in some agencies, ratings and payments have not been awarded in accordance with the spirit of the guidelines
This is very damning criticism indeed. The Auditor-General's next finding states:
.the scheme is not always being used to identify poor performance or to ensure that poor performance is not rewarded
Again, this is a very important finding and a very critical one in terms of needing elaboration, identification and correction. The audit office also found that:
.the scheme is costly in administrative terms—

not just in the amount of extra money paid to people but simply in the cost of administering the arrangements. For this initial cycle the cost was $52 million. That is a lot of money before one adds in one cent of the additional payments that have been made as a result of the appraisals resulting from the administration of the scheme. The audit office then goes on to say:
However a significant number of agencies did not expect any improvement against the majority of the objectives for performance appraisal and pay . . .
The final main finding of the audit office states:
.most agencies plan to review their scheme. However, many have not identified any performance indicators to measure outcomes against performance appraisal and pay objectives.

This matter has also exercised the mind and attracted the concern of the coalition considerably in recent times. I think we have had some very worthwhile improvements in management practices in the public sector over the last few years. For example, the implementation of the financial management improvement program is a very desirable step forward, as are the performance statements, now required of government departments at the time of the budget, which form the basis of estimates committee examinations. There certainly have been improvements in some of these areas.

PARA.TAB: One thing that has always concerned me and a lot of my colleagues is that far too often results are immeasurable, or are seen to be immeasurable, because there have not been the proper performance indicators against which to make the necessary judgments. For the audit office to say that, even in the course of planning to review their schemes, many agencies still have not identified any performance indicators to measure outcomes against performance appraisal and pay objectives is a matter of considerable concern.

The audit office goes on to make various recommendations as a result of the deficiencies that it has noted in its audit. I will not go into all of those, other than to say that I believe many of these recommendations should not have needed to be made because the whole introduction of performance pay arrangements should have been much more efficiently managed than appears to have been the case.

The Auditor-General is to be commended for drawing the attention of the parliament and the community to the problems in the present arrangements. I hope that those deficiencies can be overcome, from the point of view not just of the taxpayers' dollars that are involved but also of the efficiency of the Public Service as a whole and the service that it provides to the community. After all, the one and only objective and the rationale for the Public Service is to provide that service to the Australian taxpayers, who are its clients. I commend the report to the Senate. I know others may wish to speak to it. This subject as a whole needs to be kept on the agenda of the Senate because it is a matter of considerable ongoing importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks of my colleague Senator Short on the Auditor-General's report Pay for performance. I do not propose to traverse the ground that he has covered so well in his comments.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is currently considering the whole issue of performance pay. I am a member of that esteemed committee, which has had a number of days of hearings with people throughout the Public Service. We may have one or two more days of hearings and then we will move to a report. I certainly would not wish to pre-empt that report. The Auditor-General's office has offered to brief our committee tomorrow on this report. I certainly look forward to hearing its remarks.

This is a very important report, and it presents the government with a major problem. The performance pay issue was rushed in prior to the last election. It has always surprised me that the Public Service unions were prepared to agree to significant pay rises for higher paid officers in the service and agree to lower pay rises for the so-called lower grades. It has always surprised me that in a period of serious recession, with incomes being cut all over the place, the Labor government was prepared to negotiate an agreement which, certainly at face value, seemed to be particularly generous to higher paid officers and less generous to lower paid officers.

The story of how and why this agreement was reached certainly has to be written. It has not been written to date. Nonetheless, the performance pay scheme came in. It is now a significant part of the pay for higher paid officers in the Public Service. This report shows that it has run into very serious problems. From the evidence that I have heard from public servants, I have to say that the Auditor-General's views are widely confirmed by my experience and by comments that have been received.

Recently I had the privilege of addressing a seminar of middle management public servants. At the end of the seminar, the idea was that they should question me and put me on the spot so as to speak about the performance of senators. We are always questioning the performance of public servants, and we thought that public servants might like to return the compliment and fire some questions at me. The questions I received were not unkind.

At the end of the presentation, I asked them whether they could assist me. I asked the large number—probably in the order of 60 to 80—of public servants who were there, `Is there anyone in this room who is opposed to performance pay arrangements?'. There was obviously a degree of nervousness. I said, `Let me repeat it, just to get it clear and make it easier. Is there anyone in this room who supports performance arrangements?'. Despite a couple of urgings, I could not get one hand in the air. I think that shows that, at least amongst the middle management levels of the Public Service, there is widespread concern about the whole nature of this in the Public Service, the theoretical basis on which this has been brought into the Public Service, and the practice which the Auditor-General is exposing in his report.

Performance pay can be very generous. At the very top level, for higher paid public servants, it can provide bonuses of up to $15,000. This scheme may well have been brought in to address what were perceived to be some anomalies between the public sector and the private sector, but the hearings that I have attended seem to show not only that there is a somewhat shaky theoretical base for performance pay but also that the implementation of it is a nightmare.

To illustrate just why this report is a big problem for the government, I will mention one of the recommendations which has not been mentioned to date. A number of agencies have decided to just provide a flat rate—in other words, to not really grade people on performance but provide a flat bonus to all who come within the ambit of the scheme. A couple of major agencies have done that, including, I think, the Australian Taxation Office. The Auditor-General recommends that this sort of arrangement, this flat rate payment, should be expressly excluded and says that it is contrary to the guidelines. The report goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . agencies with more than six senior officers who rate and/or pay all staff the same be subject to a review of their performance appraisal and pay practices—
That is a very interesting proposal by the Auditor-General. The report further recommends:
. . . that DoF—
the Department of Finance—
be given the power to withhold supplementation for performance based pay for one cycle from agencies found to have taken a flat rating or payment approach to performance appraisal.

It is a very strong recommendation. It is directed at a number of senior agencies in the government that have, in effect, decided that it is better for staff morale to pay flat rate performance pay increases. Not surprisingly, this is causing a degree of angst in some of the departments, as we can see from their responses to this particular recommendation.

PARA.TAB: The other issue that emerges here, which I do not think Senator Short touched on, is the need for government departments to be accountable on the one hand and to retain some privacy for the financial arrangements of officers on the other. This has been criticised in the Senate. Indeed, very real fears were expressed that this performance pay money could be used as a sort of political slush fund to reward mates. I can understand this because I think there is a real dilemma. Often in politics there are clashes of principle. One is the principle of privacy and another is the principle of accountability. In relation to performance pay, those two important principles clash.

It is interesting that a couple of the more senior government departments were loath to provide the Auditor-General with the papers so that he could carry out his assessment because they felt it would intrude on the privacy of individuals. In the end, those departments, the Department of Treasury and the Department of Finance, decided to provide the papers, but the Auditor-General expressed concern that there should be any question at all that he should have access to all papers which relate to the expenditure of public funds.

I conclude my remarks by saying that this is an important report. It has given the government a real problem from the perspective of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which I can speak for, albeit only on my own behalf. I think it is an important document and will certainly be carefully studied by members of that committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies is an important report as it goes to the question of the protection of privacy of individual Australians. The Senate over the years has regarded as a special duty the protection of the rights of individual citizens. That has always been regarded by the Senate as one of its special functions.

PARA.TAB: On 18 August 1993, the Senate referred to the committee for inquiry and report the following matter:

SPEECH.PARA: The 0055 service offered by Telecom called `Reverse Phone Directory', which enabled subscribers to match private telephone numbers with specific residential addresses and the development of a proper and enforceable code of conduct to protect the privacy of Telecom customers from developments of this kind.

I indicate—the report notes this on page 3—that the reverse phone directory referred to the committee for inquiry was not actually offered by Telecom, as could be inferred by the committee's terms of reference. The report states:

While the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) provided by Telstra Corporation Limited (Telecom's parent company) is used to access the service, and the Service Provider of the 0055 technology is in a contractual relationship with Telstra for access to the PSTN, Telstra stressed in its submission that the suppliers of the several reverse directories currently on the market are not associated with Telstra in any way and their reproduction of the information contained in the conventional printed directories had not been authorised.

This report, though brief, is important. I think honourable senators would do well to read it and the public would do well to obtain copies. Just to explain, as the committee report does, reverse directories are directories which enable a user to ascertain a name and address by reference to a phone number, or the name and phone number by reference to an address. Unlike traditional printed directories, reverse directories are computer based. Whilst the reverse phone directory, RPD, is a relatively new initiative, reverse directories have been available in Australia for several years.

PARA.TAB: Telstra's submission informed the committee that these reverse directories are compiled through a process of rekeying or scanning the entries contained in conventional printed directories and reproducing the information on a CD-ROM disk. The CD-ROM disk can then be loaded onto a computer where a number of tasks can be performed, including number to name searching. Honourable senators will realise that this has great and grave privacy implications.

The committee received submissions from a number of organisations and groups and the committee is grateful for those submissions. We received submissions from Austel; Barwon Bank Pty Ltd; the Privacy Commissioner, Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission; the Telephone Service Providers Association of Australia; Telstra Pty Ltd, which is Telecom Australia; and the Victoria Police. We are most grateful for those submissions and the cooperation of those organisations with the work of the committee.

On 13 August Telecom announced a permanent ban from its network of all 0055 reverse directory services containing information about residential customers. In a prominent media announcement on 23 August it stated that, because of concerns having been expressed by many people about personal information being disclosed by the privately operated 0055 reverse directory service, the residential search reverse service was no longer available on its network.

It also had an assurance from a private operator that, prior to any complaints being lodged, that operator had initiated privacy considerations to clarify what it believed to be its obligations. That is all to be supported, but the committee concluded that, whilst that private operator claimed the residential component of the RPD had been permanently suspended, there is a possibility that the service might be reintroduced in the future, unless the regulatory situation is settled.
What does the committee recommend for that regulatory situation? The committee has made certain recommendations which I think should be placed on the record. Our first recommendation is:
That the principle of informed consent apply in relation to the use and re-use for commercial purposes of telephone directories containing personal details of individual subscribers.

SPEECH.PARA: Our second recommendation is:

PARA.TAB: That the Telephone Information Services Standards Committee implement as a matter of priority an amendment to the 0055 Code of Practice to entrench this principle.

SPEECH.PARA: Our third recommendation is:

PARA.TAB: That the Information Provider offering the Reverse Phone Directory service be instructed by Telstra—

SPEECH.PARA: that is Telecom—
to immediately amend the 0055 message to indicate that only business information based on Yellow Pages is available from the service.
Our fourth recommendation is:

PARA.TAB: That the Government, in its consideration of AUSTEL's December 1992 Telecommunications Privacy report, ensure that all telecommunications carriers and service providers will be required to provide subscribers with such privacy protection as the right to refuse, free of charge and without justification, to have their personal data included in a directory, and that the consent of silent number subscribers must be obtained before their personal data is provided by directory inquiries services.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand, of course, that this could well be costly, but I believe that the interests of privacy are paramount in this particular area, and the Senate committee was conscious of all the factors involved when it came to those conclusions.

PARA.TAB: I commend the report to the Senate. I think the Senate should realise that this is a hard working committee. It is composed of persons with very diverse views on a range of subjects. The Chair of the committee is Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds and the Deputy Chair is Senator John Tierney. We have Senator Bourne representing the Australian Democrats; Senator Burns from Queensland, Senator Barney Cooney from Victoria and Senator Stephen Loosley from New South Wales representing the ALP; Senator John Herron from Queensland representing the Liberal Party; and me.

We have made unanimous recommendations, one of which was recently directed to state censorship ministers on the question of guidelines for computer and video games. Unfortunately, it appears—and perhaps I am a little premature in saying this because it will be said more authoritatively—that the OFLC has chosen not to accept the unanimous recommendations of our committee in respect of that matter. Perhaps the federal and state Attorneys-General and censorship ministers should have a good look at what the Senate committee has unanimously recommended.

On the subject of the current motion, it is urgent that our report be heeded because it has grave ramifications for the privacy of individuals within Australia. If organisations can access the names and addresses of individual Australians simply by accessing a telephone number through a CD ROM purchased by a company or a government department, it will be an intrusion into the privacy of the individuals if they have not had an opportunity to make clear that that information should not be available.
Finally, I refer the Senate to our report at page 13, paragraph 2.24, which states:
The Committee concludes that, while it is claimed by—

SPEECH.PARA: and I will not mention the name of the private organisation—

that the residential component of the RPD is `permanently suspended', there is a real possibility that the service might be re-introduced in the future unless the regulatory situation is settled. One of the Committee's research staff has rung the relevant 0055 number and, at extra expense caused by various malfunctions of the service, ascertained that the service still claims to provide residential and business information, although `at present only business numbers will be given in full'. Clearly, the service exists and could be re-activated at short notice.

Unless the committee's recommendations are promptly taken account of, it is our view that there will be serious privacy consequences for a large number of Australians. I take this opportunity to thank the members of the staff of the committee for their excellent work.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COURT (JUDGES' REMUNERATION) BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave pursuant to section 191 of the standing orders to make an explanation on the basis that I have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to explain that, during the course of my speech yesterday dealing with the two bills before the chamber, Senator O'Chee subsequently misquoted me by saying that I said that profits do not matter in respect to business operation, which is quite untrue. In fact, I do understand that profits are very important with respect to business operation and totally support them.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, what I did say with regard to the industrial relations legislation before this chamber was that, in respect to business operation, the trade union movement had made a substantial contribution under the current legislation—as has this government—to improving the lot of industry within this country. What is important with regard to profits, and I am sure that honourable senators on the other side would agree—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The issues that are now being canvassed by Senator Murphy are in fact debating points in terms of the bills before the chamber and not a personal explanation. I would ask you to call him to order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—On that point of order, Senator Murphy has been quite brief on this point. It is also correct that the response of any senator on a matter of personal explanation needs to be germane to the matter he or she is seeking to respond to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I just wonder whether Senator Murphy had the courtesy to inform Senator O'Chee that he intended to rise on this issue.
—Courtesies are desirable in senators, but it is not a requirement of the standing orders. I call Senator Murphy to complete his personal explanation.
—It is rather disappointing that Senator Knowles and Senator Kemp would choose to do what they have just done.
—Why don't you understand the standing orders before you stand up and speak?
—I would have to say to Senator Knowles that sometimes her knowledge of a number of things is a bit like a base drum—a lot on noise and little on substance.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a further point of order. We gave leave to Senator Murphy to get up on a personal explanation to the effect that he was misquoted. I thought that he had given the explanation as to what he was misquoted about. I then take up the point made by Senator Knowles that Senator Murphy is going into debating points. We are happy to listen to him telling us where Senator O'Chee misquoted him, but I would suggest that he sit down after that and not sling cheap shots at Senator Knowles.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As I have already said, I never said during the course of my speech that profits did not matter. That is a very important aspect with regard to the industrial relations bills that are before this chamber. That is what I sought to address during my speech.

PARA.TAB: Likewise, Senator Knowles says that unless one has run a business one has no knowledge about particular matters that relate to industrial relations. Nothing could be further from the truth. I reject that claim on the basis that I certainly do have knowledge with respect to business operations. It does not necessarily mean that one has to have run a business. I have not and I would be first to admit that. But I have certainly participated in many activities that are relevant to business operations in a number of areas.

I believe that I have a quite full understanding of the necessities of running a business. I would point out that the records would show that there have been substantial failings by people who have run businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order—
—There is no need for a point of order. I ask Senator Murphy to conclude his remarks now.
—I just wanted to refute the statements and claims made by both Senator O'Chee and Senator Knowles as being totally inaccurate and irrelevant to the debate that has been occurring in this chamber.

—I am glad that Senator Knowles has decided to come back into the chamber to listen. Having listened to her contribution this morning, one would have got the impression that the fount of all wisdom was the employer, and certainly not the worker or the union. The union was the source of all evil; it was the cause of everything that had gone wrong in industry and in business today. That was certainly the impression one was left with after listening to Senator Knowles. That could not be further from the truth.

PARA.TAB: I would be the first to admit that in the past unions have not been terribly speedy in picking up the needs of female members of their unions in the work force. But in recent times that has changed quite markedly. I welcome the day when we have in this chamber the likes of Jennie George, Pat Staunton and Anna Booth. They would make a lot of women in the opposition have second thoughts about the ability of women and the ability of unionists. These are women who have great ability, knowledge and the capacity to work well within their unions, to work well for the people that they represent and for the businesses for which they work.

One of the very interesting and important things that has been happening in recent times has been the fact that the ACTU and business have been working together to improve the number of jobs available for the unemployed and looking at how they can address the issues of regional development. These are all the important issues that relate to employment and unemployment. We are seeing cooperation between business and the union movement. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill is all about cooperation and bringing down something that was agreed to by all sectors of industry and the union movement aimed at improving the industrial relations area and to work towards the future. This is of vital importance to this country.

In this debate we have heard a lot about the faxes that we have been receiving. I think Senator Woodley summed up the faxes particularly well. When it comes to theology, if there is anyone in this place who wishes to discuss theology and cast themselves as experts on theology, I would take heed of the opinion of one person only in that debate—I may be casting aspersions on others—and that is the opinion of Senator Woodley. He has been practising in this area and has been dealing with these matters for some considerable time. Therefore, I think he is a man who knows the subject and the issues involved.I found his contribution today to be very informative. It certainly exposed a number of the issues relating to the faxes that we have been sent.

It was interesting to hear on this morning's news that the opposition's shadow spokesperson on industrial relations is saying that there is only one thing that the opposition would revisit with Jobsback, namely the minimum youth wage. It is wonderful that we have actually had it outlined that, irrespective of what the election result was in March, this is the debate we were going to have. We were going to have this debate because of what the opposition was planning to introduce. All through Jobsback, and through Fightback for those who remember it, the opposition talked about the rights of the individual. But those opposite keep talking about these faxes that we have been receiving in our offices. The interesting thing is that they keep talking about the importance of the master-servant relationship. A master-servant relationship is certainly not a relationship where individuals are equal. It is a relationship where one is superior to the other.

In Jobsback the opposition also talks about the right of the individual to negotiate. For negotiation to have any meaning, relevance or importance it has to be negotiation between people of equal ability, knowledge and standing. Master-servant relationships do not have people of equal ability, status and standing; they immediately put one on a more superior level than the other. I know that is something that opposition senators find very hard and very unpalatable, but if they want to talk to me about reading the faxes, I will certainly pick out the bits that they should be very conscious of. If they want to come in here and talk about the rights of the individual to negotiate, they have to make sure that the individual is able to negotiate from a position of equal power and equal ability. This does not happen with individual enterprise bargaining or master-servant relationships.

As has been said previously, the master-servant relationship is very similar to the master-slave relationship. I will tell those people who do not agree with me—and who do not want to agree with me—of the sorts of things that people are telling me when they come into my electorate office. They are not in unions. Why are they not in unions? Because their boss forbids it. What is the boss doing to them?

I currently have one case in my office where a whole series of employees are being paid $5 an hour. That is the allegation. There are also allegations of two sets of books and things like that. These are the sorts of things that one has to be very conscious of. Whilst opposition senators have said that all evil things belong to the unions and accuse us of saying that all evil things belong to the employers, I think it is very important to say that the bulk of the unions are good and the bulk of the employers are good, but let no-one come in here and tell me that there are no bosses who want to rip off their people.

These are the sorts of things that are happening now. These people have no ability to negotiate an individual contract because they have been given one of $5 of an hour. If they do not like it, they are out the front door. How do I know they are out the front door? Because I have them coming into my office and they have not even been given a separation certificate by their bosses. They cannot even do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done about it?

—I have done plenty. They have also had wrongful dismissals. These are the sorts of things that can happen in a situation that is laissez faire; a situation where individuals have to look after themselves. It is for these very reasons that I think this bill is of the utmost importance. I do not support individual enterprise bargaining because the individual who is having to do the bargaining as the employee does not have the same power and the same abilities as the employer.

PARA.TAB: When talking about the ability to enter into individual negotiations and bargaining, let us look at those disadvantaged groups. We heard Senator Knowles talk a lot about migrants—the people with non-English speaking backgrounds. How can we expect people who have difficulties with the English language to be able to negotiate through the fine details of what an unscrupulous boss might want to put in a contract? They do not have that ability.

What about women re-entering the work force after a number of years away? Their self-confidence will be much lower than that of their peers who have not left the work force. These women find coming back into the work force quite difficult. It is not traumatic, but it is certainly a time when they feel that their confidence levels are not at their greatest. They are unsure of themselves because things in the work force will have changed a lot in the last 10 years. These women do not feel that they are in the same equal position as their employer to be able to negotiate on a one-to-one basis and an equal basis. What about young people who have not developed the negotiating skills? Opposition senators tell us, `These people are fine. Let them go. It doesn't matter what happens to them'. This legislation will not let that happen. That is why I have great pride in supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that quip?
—It is not you, Senator West.

—I should think not. We need to look at what we would be debating if the roles were reversed and we were on the other side—if that ever happened. We would be debating the abolition of Worksafe. What is Worksafe? Worksafe is the organisation that provides for occupational health and safety standards and the work done in relation to them in this country. It is of vital importance to maintain standards, to do research, to maintain statistics and to generally help employers who need assistance with any Worksafe problems that might occur. But it is also a very important policy area for the government. Worksafe provided half the funding for Farmsafe, the organisation which is very involved with safety on farms. Occupations in the farming industry are the third most dangerous occupations following those in the mining industry and timber industry. These occupations have accident rates way above the national average.
—It is way above public servants sitting inside comfortable buildings; that's for sure.

—It is still more dangerous than all other occupations except two, and Senator Panizza well knows that with his farming background. He also knows that a lot of farmers turn up to the seminars, conferences and workshops run by Farmsafe, an organisation of vital importance to the farming industry of this country. It is important to the people who work in the area and to productivity in this country that we have a high standard of occupational health and safety. If the roles were reversed—and, as I said, we would have been debating the Industrial Relations Reform Bill irrespective of what happened in March—we would certainly be very concerned about what was going to happen. Fortunately, that will not happen. We are maintaining that.

PARA.TAB: I keep being told that this bill has been brought in with secrecy. I have never heard such a load of rubbish in all my life. It was one of the key debates in the election campaign, but some of the groups that are opposed to this do not vote, so maybe they did not take any notice of what was happening.

In conclusion, this bill provides a safety net. The unions provide a watchdog to make sure that the safety net—the awards and conditions and that type of thing—for workers is not being eroded. It is vitally important. I am a unionist. I am proud to be a unionist. I also come from a background that has paid the bills for the employees; I come from a background where the employees probably did get more money than the employer. I have no problems with saying that. So I do understand both sides of the argument. But I also come from a family where the employees of our businesses were union members and proud of it. In fact, the boss was a union member as well. I guess that also comes from my background.

This is an important piece of legislation which I am proud to be involved with. I think it is important that we uphold the rights of people to make sure that they get a decent day's wages for a decent day's work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —How hollow that speech sounded when one thinks that just three or four weeks ago two housekeepers at the Lodge were sacked without any notice by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country. These housekeepers just wanted one thing: they wanted to clear their names and they wanted the Senate to further investigate this issue. Not one of these new Labor types stood up for two decent working class women. For Sue West to get up and lecture us, and sob all over the chamber about her particular concern for working women, rings very hollow to my ears and, I am sure, to the ears of those two housekeepers.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Reform Bill is, as many of my colleagues have said, a pay-off to the trade unions for the support that they gave Labor during the election. It is not about reform, labour market flexibility, tackling the problem of one million unemployed in this country or increasing productivity. It is about none of those things. It is about entrenching union power and privilege and enabling unions to further interfere in proper arrangements between employers and employees. It is also about ensuring that the trade unions and governments decide industrial relations questions, not independent tribunals.

The bill will bring large sections of the private sector work force within the ambit of the federal industrial relations machinery by allowing the AIRC to prescribe minimum conditions for all employees. The bill also serves to undermine the independence of state systems. There is no question that it attempts to severely limit the capacity of democratically elected state governments—Victoria and Western Australia, in particular—to implement their mandates. This legislation singles out and discriminates against those state governments which have elected to pursue a different path to industrial relations reform from that sanctioned by the federal government and its ACTU mates.

Senator West sneered at the faxes that so many of us have received from large numbers of people in small business. I do not demean those people. They are putting up their capital, their homes, their whole futures and their businesses and they are creating jobs. They are quite entitled to bring their views to the attention of senators without being demeaned by Labor parliamentarians. They have pointed out that this bill will cause major problems. It will lead to further interference by trade unions and their business. In some areas it will make it very difficult for them to manage their business and it will certainly inhibit investment. I am delighted that those people brought their views to my attention and have called my office to apprise me of their thoughts. Above all, small employers are greatly concerned about the possibilities of union intimidation as the secondary boycott provisions, which existed for so long in the Trade Practices Act, are gutted.

This bill will pass the Senate only because of the support given to it by the Australian Democrats and the Greens. In the first 10 years of their existence, the Australian Democrats strongly opposed any measure to increase the power and privilege of big unions. Don Chipp's slogans attacked big unions and big business. That rang a pretty strong chord in many sections of the Australian public. The Australian Democrats strongly supported the secondary boycott provisions on many occasions in this parliament. In 1984 they voted against the government's legislation which would have repealed these sections.

It is no secret that the ACTU and some trades and labour councils in the states have actively courted the Australian Democrats for a number of years. I believe that this lobbying effort, as far as the unions are concerned, has been very fruitful. As far as the Democrats are concerned, it is a tragedy that they have thrown over their traditions and positioned themselves so closely to the Bill Keltys and Martin Fergusons of this world.
Honourable senators may have seen what the founder of the Democrats, Don Chipp, said in the press some weeks ago about the legislation we are now debating and about the

SPEECH.PARA: attitude of the Australian Democrats to it. He said:
If they vote for it, I will have to conclude sadly that it is a different party from the one I helped form to support small business in 1977.

That was a very important statement by Don Chipp. I hope that Senator Kernot and Senator Spindler, when they consider this bill, will consider the traditions of their party, which have always been to defend small business. I hope that they will reconsider their position, throw over their new mates—the Bill Keltys, the Martin Fergusons and the John Halfpennys—and return to their source, because there are hundreds of thousands of people in small business who are waiting anxiously for their vote to defend them.

PARA.TAB: My colleagues have extensively canvassed the reasons why the coalition will be strongly opposing this bill. I wish to touch on two aspects: firstly, the bill invites the High Court to subvert the constitution and proper democratic processes through adventurous and inappropriate uses of ILO conventions; and, secondly, I believe this bill undermines proper independent tribunals in the labour market area.

This bill is profoundly undemocratic in its basis. The Commonwealth is acquiring new powers, not through the democratic process of constitutional amendment but by misusing international treaties, ILO conventions and so-called customary international law. In taking this course, the Commonwealth is arrogating to itself powers which the Australian public has denied to it on at least six occasions since 1901. The regulation of industrial relations was a highly controversial topic at the turn of the century. The power conferred upon the Commonwealth government with respect to private sector employees was extremely limited. The limits the constitutional founders placed on the Commonwealth's power over industrial relations has been, and will be, totally subverted by international treaties. These treaties can be signed by the executive without any involvement of parliament, state or federal, and without proper consultation with the interested parties.

To show how absurd this position is, one clause of the bill relates to terminations. It depends on ILO convention No. 158. The termination provisions are hugely onerous and will make any employer think twice before putting on new staff. No-one suggests that employees should not be treated fairly, unlike the summary dismissal of the two housekeepers by Mr Keating at the Lodge.

This legislation will make the dismissal of incompetent, lazy or trouble making employees a legal nightmare. Under proposed section 334A one cannot dismiss someone for taking industrial action. This gives, in effect, a blank cheque for rogue behaviour by union officials. Strikes are legal in the negotiating phase but, interestingly, this bill makes it impossible to sack a person on strike outside this legal period. In fact, some people suggest that one may not even be able to stop pay.

The ILO convention on termination of employment was ratified during the government's caretaker period, on 26 February 1993, just two weeks before the election. No announcement was made at the time of what the government had done. This was a major international agreement which would provide a constitutional head of power and no announcement was made at the time. No press release was issued. There was no meaningful consultation with the states and no meaningful consultation with employers. No state government agreed to the ratification. My advice is that no Australian jurisdiction currently complies with the terms of that convention.

This is quite contrary to normal practice in the ratification of ILO conventions, whereby conventions are not ratified until after proper consultation with the states. The Commonwealth is able to assure the ILO that domestic law and practice conform with the terms of the convention. In short, this is an extraordinary state of affairs—unprecedented—and it may lead the High Court to conclude that the convention was merely entered into as a device for attracting power to the Commonwealth to enact legislation which it could not otherwise be able to validly implement.

This convention has been ratified by only some 17 countries. The reason for this is pretty clear. Most developed countries have not ratified this convention because they are unwilling to load the private sector with additional costs and restrictions.
Indeed, they rely on the decency and fairness of their own industrial laws. I seek leave

SPEECH.PARA: to incorporate in Hansard a document outlining the 17 other countries that have ratified the Termination of Employment Convention.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The countries that Australia has followed include Cameroon, Cyprus, Gabon, Malawi, Niger, Slovenia, Uganda, Venezuela, the Yemen Republic, Yugoslavia, Zaire and Zambia. There are two or three other countries, which are countries with which we commonly compare ourselves, including France, Sweden and perhaps Spain. But the majority of the industrial world has not signed this convention and the countries with which we are trying to compete have not signed this convention. It shows just how far this government will go to trade off the international interests of this country to protect its own mates. In short, this bill represents a massive disincentive for employers to hire new staff.

PARA.TAB: The ILO Termination of Employment Convention shows the absurdity of our current constitutional arrangements. The executive government merely has to sign a convention. The government acquires, as a result of the present High Court's generous interpretation of the external affairs power, the right to legislate on the termination of employment, overriding all state prerogatives. The federal government's aggressive use of ILO conventions, allied with the external affairs power, demonstrates the way in which it can impose its policies on the states.

Overall, some six ILO conventions are relied on by the government to give it the constitutional basis for this legislation. In other words, the conventions provide the major underpinning for the more controversial aspects of the bill which the Senate is now considering. This legislation allows the federal government to legislate directly in relation to terms and conditions of employment. It sharply curtails flexibility by limiting the matters over which employers and employees may bargain.

One other area that is perhaps worth bringing to the attention of the Senate is the issue of the right to strike. The government is very uncertain of its powers in this area. From reading the covering memorandum to the bill, one sees that the government has thrown every available ILO convention and international instrument—as well as what it claims to be international customary law—into the bill in the hope that one or other of these devices will provide a legal foundation for its legislation on the right to strike.

It may come as a bit of a surprise to many observers that there is no right to strike under ILO conventions. There is some jurisprudence which suggests that such a right may exist in limited circumstances. But a definitive opinion by the International Court of Justice—the only body which can rule on such matters—has never been made.

It is interesting that the government wants to confine the right to strike to unionists. A close reading of section 170P(a)(ii) tells us that the strike activity leading up to a certified agreement by union members is protected from civil action. Strike activity leading up to an enterprise flexibility non-union agreement is not protected. I believe that no such law is needed in this country. Australians have long exercised a right to strike. We believe that, in certain circumstances, it is justified. But there is no doubt that this agreement will probably lead to more intimidation of employers.

The final point I wish to make relates to how the federal government is undermining the independence and authority of our own arbitral bodies. It is really the politics of revenge. The arrogant Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his mate Bill Kelty will simply not tolerate views different from their own. The commission has made the mistake of bucking such views and it is now to pay the price. When the commission rejected the accord, Mr Keating said—it is a quite famous quote—in the Sunday Age on 5 May 1991, `Put in the parlance of the Gulf War, it will take some collateral damage'. Since then the commission has been taking damage. This bill is the culmination of this process of punishment for the commission. Furthermore, it will make sure that we never again have a commission with any semblance of real independence. This legislation will put the ACTU into the driver's seat.

Proposed section 170QC of the legislation allows the Governor-General to assign a member of the commission to the bargaining division. As we all know—unlike Senator Evans's UN committees—the Governor-General acts on the advice of Australian ministers, and we all know what sort of person the minister recommends. How would honourable senators feel if they were an employer going up against an ACTU person before a member of the commission whose job depends on pleasing the ACTU? This goes to the heart of independence and being able to judge a case on its merits.

The bill also represents a malicious attack on the powers of the president of the commission. Proposed section 170QD makes it quite clear that when these people pick the new vice-president they want to run the bargaining division of the commission, that person will be able to tell the president what to do.

There are other examples of how the government and the ACTU have been at pains to destroy those who exercise independence of mind. It had already stacked the senior levels of the current commission with ACTU officials in order to ensure that the president could not create a full bench without the ACTU having a major say. However, even this was not good enough for the government and the ACTU. The remote control devices on a number of commissioners were obviously not working properly, thus the proposal for an industrial court of Australia—a labour court in the most perverse sense of the word, in that organised labour will be the only group to have any real say. It will be very interesting to see who is actually appointed to this body.

The Law Council of Australia has added weight to a number of these points. It has observed that there is no reason for creating a specialist labour court, and it has stated very clearly that there are substantive reasons why this is the case.

It will be particularly interesting to see whether this new court will come within the ministerial purview of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) or the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). At the moment a battle royal is occurring between the two ministers on this issue. I am opposed to the creation of this court. If it comes within the ambit of the Minister for Industrial Relations, the chance of this court achieving any standing and credibility amongst employers will be zero. This bill can be summed up in the following terms: it is a bill of the unions, by the unions, and for the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. My colleague Senator Robert Bell, who has direct portfolio responsibility for industrial relations, has already put on record the basic position of the Australian Democrats on the main provisions of this bill.

PARA.TAB: In answer to some of the comments that Senator Kemp has made, the Australian Democrats realise and support the objective of greater flexibility in the industrial relations area to enable our industries to increase productivity and become more competitive in international markets. However, we are firmly of the view that this increased productivity will not be achieved by exploiting workers.

We basically support this bill, but we have a substantial number of amendments. In the continuous negotiation to improve the legislation, Senator Bell has pursued the objective of ensuring that Australian workers will not be exploited under the pretext of achieving greater flexibility and productivity in Australian industry.

I believe it is also true to say that we have been constrained to ensure that small business is not jeopardised in this process. I believe that the balance that has been achieved in this bill will benefit small business to a very great extent. Small business, just like large business, is dependent on a stable, just and predictable industrial relations environment together with a degree of flexibility, as I have mentioned. But small business will not benefit from a situation where employees are exploited for the gain of unscrupulous employers. We must guard against this in our society or we will rue the day and pay for it with not only social but also economic disadvantage.

I wish to confine my comments tonight to particular areas of the bill where I will be moving amendments. This bill is a welcome opportunity to advance the cause of basic equality in employment situations and the issue of equal rights generally. My comments will be confined to the two areas where I have already foreshadowed the moving of amendments.

Firstly, I will be moving to remove discrimination on the grounds of sexuality, age or disability in an employment situation and to prohibit these areas as grounds for dismissal. Secondly, I will include in the Democrats' amendments a range of provisions to establish unpaid leave entitlements for workers caring for members of their immediate families who have fallen ill. In particular, my amendments will seek to ensure that the definition of an employee's immediate family includes the employee's spouse or de facto spouse irrespective of whether that person is of the same or opposite sex.

The central question on the discrimination issue is whether decisions relating to a person's employment should be made on the employee's capacity to carry out a particular job, and the person's conduct in the employment situation, or whether they should be made, all other things being equal, on the basis of a person's disability, age or sexuality. Even at a time when there is little or no legal redress available to people with disabilities, the Victorian Disability Employment Action Centre has dealt with 24 cases during the last 12 months in which it was claimed that individuals were wrongfully dismissed. The number of cases brought to the centre's industrial advocate would clearly be much higher if information on possible courses of action and greater recourse to the law were available to people with disabilities in employment situations.

Complaints to the disability discrimination commissioner totalled 120, of which more than 50 per cent related to redundancy and dismissal. Refusal to hire, accessibility and appropriateness of training and other workplace issues also constituted a number of complaints to the commissioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Refusal to hire.

—Senator Panizza may think that people with disabilities should not have any jobs and should not be considered for work. I am saying that people with disabilities should be treated, in an employment situation, just like any other person.

PARA.TAB: Elizabeth Hastings, the federal disability discrimination commissioner, has identified that discrimination in employment—particularly in the employment and dismissal of people with disabilities—is a key issue of human rights on which much more action is needed. The commission is currently putting together a manual on employment and disability discrimination issues which will complement the move to legislate against dismissal and discrimination on disability grounds, which my amendments will seek to do.

It is also time that our society paid some attention to the treatment that people receive on the basis of age. Upper age limits in the employment area seem now to have dropped to something like 35 to 40 years plus for women and 45 years plus for men. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that the number of job seekers between 45 and 54 years rose by 19 per cent between 1975 and 1981. In the 55 to 64 age bracket, the number of job seekers has risen by 142 per cent.

The latest ABS statistics illustrate that included in the 145,600 discouraged job seekers who have totally opted out of participation in the labour market are 32,200 individuals between 45 and 54 years and 32,800 individuals in the 55 to 64 age bracket. Clearly, age has become a major factor in inaccessibility to the labour market.

The other end of the scale—youth—also deserves some attention. The Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition asserts that the sole use of age as a determinant of wages is the most serious form of discrimination in employment related to age. The coalition supports moves towards competency based wage fixing whereby experience, skill and overall employability are the determinants of rewards and not just the arbitrarily ascribed characteristic of an individual's age.

For young Australians, access to employment can be extremely difficult. Any moves that seek to address the discrimination faced by young people when seeking employment would, I submit, be moves in the right direction. Of the 400,000 Australians who are the very long-term unemployed—that is, those who are out of the labour force for 12 months or more—40 per cent are between 16 and 25 years of age. We should note this figure and realise that we are mortgaging the future of today's young generation.

Inquiries to the Victorian Equal Opportunity Commission on age related discrimination issues are certainly on the increase. For the period from July 1991 to June 1992, 340 inquiries relating to age discrimination in employment were taken by the commission. For the period from July 1992 to June 1993, 429 inquiries were received. It is envisaged that, if the commission were empowered to act on these complaints, the number of inquiries would increase markedly, as is the case in areas such as sex and race discrimination, in which the commission has power to intervene.

I will now turn to the area of sexuality. Inquiries to the Victorian commissioner for equal opportunity on discrimination in employment in relation to sexuality have also been significant. From July 1991 to June 1992, the commission received 70 inquiries relating to sexuality discrimination. From July 1992 to June 1993, the inquiries had risen to 76. Statistics available for the period from July to October 1993 show that the commission received a record number of 51 inquiries for that four-month period. A research project conducted by the Melbourne group GLAD—Gay men and Lesbians Against Discrimination—based on a comprehensive survey of over 1,000 gay men and lesbians in Victoria, reported that lesbians and gay men in Victoria face considerable discrimination, harassment and violence solely due to their sexuality.

In particular the survey notes the problems relating to employment. Some 45 per cent of lesbians and 45 per cent of gay men reported some form of discrimination or harassment, including loss of jobs, and they experienced this as a result of their sexuality. Clearly better community knowledge of the legal right to take action under ILO convention 111, which the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission has control of, would increase the number of complaints that would be lodged. We need to consider whether we, as a civilised society, want to discriminate against a group of people in our society in the area of employment for no reason other than that they belong to a group that has a particular form of sexuality.

I will briefly turn to the other amendments which seek to ensure that carers, who care for members of their immediate family who have fallen ill, should include people who are not just from the traditional form of family. That concept should be expanded to include a de facto partner even where that person is not of the opposite sex.

The principle that we need to look at is the very nature of the family and what family means to us. Should it be a traditional construct that says that a family is nothing but a husband, a wife and 2.2 children behind the white picket fence, or are we looking at the family as basically the caring unit of our community?

Recently we have had occasion to look at surveys that have been carried out in relation to the nature of the family, and it is there for all to see that the traditional structure of the family has changed substantially. That traditional structure is in the minority when we compare it with people who live either singularly or in households which have only one parent or in households which have a configuration of people of different sexualities.

I am not suggesting that this is a desirable trend. I am simply putting it forward as an observable fact. I am challenging this chamber as well as the community generally to take account of that and to ensure that we treat human beings as human beings, irrespective of the structure in which they happen to live. I believe they are entitled to know that the family that they have chosen—in most cases this is beyond their control—should give them the same nurturing and the same caring that other people expect from a traditional family structure. I believe that this society will be judged on the degree to which it can claim to be a civilised society and the degree to which it can fulfil that obligation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. But in so doing, I cannot let Senator Spindler's comments pass. I am absolutely appalled by the debasement of the notion of the family that we have heard from Senator Spindler. He described the family as nothing more than `the caring unit of our community'. By that definition, the family is reduced to an absolute nothing and has no quality or value whatsoever. The family in Australia overwhelming consists of a man and a woman and their children. That is what a family is all about. The primary purpose of a family is the care and nurture of children. The Democrats are jumping into bed with the government in the total debasement of the notion of family in the Australian community. I am absolutely appalled to hear that reinforced today.

PARA.TAB: I oppose this bill because it appears to have been prepared totally in an ACTU inspired vacuum. It is almost as though there is no Australian economic problem, no massive foreign debt and no government deficit and we are in the balmy days of the 1950s when this country had a strong economy and was growing well.

The fact is that we are not in a vacuum. We are in an absolute crisis of unemployment. This is the worst unemployment problem that we have had for 60 years. We have 11 per cent unemployment and one million Australians cannot get a job. I am reminded of that fact every time I fly into Adelaide, which is a city of one million people. When one flies over that city and recalls that the population of that city equates to the total number of people in this country who cannot get a job, it is appalling to think that this government has produced a bill which takes no account of that problem whatsoever.

This bill deals with the operation of the labour market. Yet the government is prepared to continue as though the problem of unemployment, a labour market problem, does not exist. It is a sad reflection on this government that the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), as far as I can tell, made absolutely no reference to the problem of unemployment. Again, there is no evidence that the government knows that this problem exists.

I cannot find any publicly available assessment by the government of the impact of this bill on the level of unemployment. In my view, just about every piece of government legislation should be subject to an employment impact test. This bill should certainly be subject to such a test. I wonder whether the government has internally prepared such an assessment. Has it found out what the effect of this legislation will be on our disastrous level of unemployment? Either it has not done so, because it really does not care, or it has and the results are so appalling that it is frightened to expose them.

This bill of all bills should be designed to deal with this massive problem of unemployment. If we examine the details of the bill and the effect it will have on business, it is pretty clear that it is likely to increase unemployment by making it more expensive and more difficult for business to employ people. I remind the government that it is business that generates jobs. The government's answer to unemployment is to float the idea of yet another tax on working Australians. It creates the problem, it brings in another industrial relations bill that exacerbates the problem and then it talks about another tax which will only increase unemployment.

This bill really does expose the ACTU-ALP conspiracy against the unemployed in this country. The government's senior Treasury officer, Ted Evans, put the spotlight firmly on this conspiracy when he said a while ago that our 11 per cent unemployment rate was `a matter of choice'. In other words, the senior Treasury officer of this country is saying that we are in a position where we can choose a lower level of unemployment and, therefore, a lower level of poverty. He said to the government, `It is up to you. You can choose a lower level of unemployment.' The government's senior Treasury adviser told it that.

What has happened? The ACTU-ALP government—and that is what it is—has chosen a high level of unemployment. This bill entrenches the status quo and thus entrenches the policy prescription which has sustained and produced this high level of unemployment.

This bill is nothing more than a union based, over-award bargaining system. It is nothing more than that. It leaves us with a rigid, inflexible centralised system which fails miserably to ensure that everyone who wants a job can get a job. If there was something that emerged out of the depression that this country went through 60 years ago, it was a consensus between the parties that the objective of policy should be that everyone who can get a job should be able to get a job. This bill does not do anything to address that policy objective.

Everything the government does should be aimed at promoting economic growth through encouraging investment. That will produce jobs. The government in its lighter moments would admit that. It admits that the answer is to produce growth through investment.

But what does this bill do? Businesses have reacted with horror to this bill. They are absolutely amazed that the government could in one breath say that it wants to encourage investment and in the next breath say that it wants to bring in such a bill. By definition, if business is horrified by this bill, investment will not be encouraged by this bill and business will start looking overseas more and more for business and investment opportunities. This bill will encourage the employment of people in other countries but not in this country.

The irony is that this government, to its credit, has done quite a bit to open up the Australian economy. It has encouraged businesses to export and to think in world terms. They sure are going to think in world terms after they see this bill. They are going to think in terms of investing around the world. This bill will drive investment overseas and, therefore, drive jobs overseas.

It is regrettably a very silly and short-sighted sell-out to the ACTU and the union movement. It is very hard for those of us on this side who went through the last federal election campaign to escape the conclusion that this is the great payback for what the unions did for the ALP in that last election campaign. Those of us who were in the trenches saw the union movement rally behind this government by allocating a union to every federal seat that was in trouble and investing vast sums of hardworking union members' dues into the most filthy campaign against this side of the house; thus it returned this government. Here we see the price for that campaign.

One of the really insidious aspects of this bill is its reliance on the International Labour Organisation. My colleague Senator Kemp has spoken eloquently about that most insidious aspect of this legislation. An independent commentator, Max Walsh, said of this particular aspect in the Sydney Morning Herald recently:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the bill makes our labour market hostage to the deliberations of the International Labour Organisation.
He went on to say:
Australia is issuing an invitation to the ILO to use our economy as a social laboratory for its ideas.

Under Labor, our obligations to the ILO, which has quite rightly been described as an international alliance of the Left, are apparently much more important than Australia's obligations to the one million people who cannot get jobs. Not only has Max Walsh condemned this bill but also many other independent commentators have rightly condemned it. In relation to this bill, Syntec, the independent economic forecasting group, has said:

The greatest threat to Australia fulfilling the potential offered by a Pacific economic community is the ascendancy over Australian Governments established by the Australian unions in the new industrial relations package.

Of course, Syntec did not know what Mr Keating was going to say about Malaysia, which is now the other great threat to Australia fulfilling its potential in the Asia-Pacific. On 30 October, an editorial in the Australian stated:
The Federal Government's measures to move towards enterprise bargaining are modest in ambition, preserve the old rigidities and union privileges and could even lead to higher unemployment.

On 25 October, the Australian Financial Review spoke of the government and the ACTU ramming their version of labour market reform down the throats of employers and the Industrial Relations Commission. The Financial Review said:

. . . it is clear that greater flexibility of both average and relative real wages would make Australian industry more competitive, promote increased productivity, and assist disadvantaged groups such as the long-term unemployed.
On 16 November, Alan Wood addressed this very fundamental issue of the effect of this bill on unemployment in the Australian. He said:

High unemployment will persist much longer than necessary because the existing labour market arrangements, with their complex system of awards governing wages and conditions of employment, are a barrier to job creation.
This is something the government just fails to understand or acknowledge.

PARA.TAB: This bill, as I said before, really is the great payback. We were all encouraged on this side of the house by Paul Keating's speech—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! `Mr Keating', thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I say `Paul'? I withdraw it. Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, encouraged us by referring to his industrial relations reform agenda in a speech in April which gave us great heart. We thought perhaps the Prime Minister, having to his credit freed up many aspects of the Australian economy, would at last address the one remaining area of socialist rigidity in the Australian economy, the labour market. But no. By October we have before us a bill which does nothing more than entrench all the rigidities which make this labour market dysfunctional and which has produced one million unemployed. Union support for the Labor Party in the 1993 election had a very high price, and that price is being paid by all the Australians who cannot get a job under this government.

PARA.TAB: It is regrettable that this bill really does expose the hypocrisy of the Labor government. It mouths all the rhetoric of a more open market oriented economy, of freeing up the economy so that we can compete on world markets. What does the government do when it addresses the most fundamental area that is in need of reform, the labour market? It does absolutely nothing. This bill should be condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Industrial Relations Reform Bill and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill and they have been described again and again by speakers in this debate. The government has received much criticism about them. The last speaker said this bill is going to drive investors overseas because—as I understand the argument—they have to pay workers a certain amount of money and give them certain conditions. The inference is that it is a bad thing to give workers too much pay and to make their conditions too healthy.

PARA.TAB: I can understand that this bill would be criticised because it makes things too good here compared with overseas. I do not agree with that; nevertheless, I can understand that argument. I was adjusting my thoughts to that particular concept when Senator Minchin made the next criticism. He said the other thing this bill does is give Australian workers the sorts of standards that operate overseas. He criticises the fact that much of this bill is based on overseas conventions, and that is so. I can understand an argument that this bill adopts overseas standards set out in the ILO conventions and that is too generous.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very basic.

—Yes. I can understand an argument saying that that is too generous, but I cannot understand an argument that says that people in Australia are getting wages and conditions that are too good, and that they should be reduced because investors are going overseas where things are better; and yet in the next breath condemns conditions under which people may work overseas because they are too good.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has to make up its mind. Are those opposite condemning this bill because the conditions and the wages that Australian workers get are, in their opinion, too good; or are they condemning this bill because it incorporates ILO conventions which set international standards which are seen in their argument to be too good? What is the position? Are those opposite saying that conditions here are superior to what they are overseas and, therefore, should be reduced; or are they saying that overseas conditions set out in the convention are too good and therefore should be excised from the act?

TALK.START.PARA: —We can set our own standards.
—Senator Minchin gives the answer. He says that we have to set our own standards and that is what those opposite are on about. They do not want decent conditions for workers.
—They don't want any standards.

—That is right. They do not want any standards. They do not want overseas standards because they are too good, and they do not want the standards here because they are too good. And Senator Minchin, in his very honest way, representing what goes on in the opposition, has told us directly, fairly and candidly what the opposition is on about; the opposition is about there being no standards at all.

PARA.TAB: I listened to Senator Minchin and at no stage in his very eloquent, well-considered and studied address did he say what the minimum standards should be. At no stage did he say what the minimum wages ought to be. I ask him to search the speech tomorrow in the Hansard to look for one part which said, `We, on the opposition side, think there ought to be minimums, and there ought to be decent standards'.

They throw out the international convention. Those conventions which countries all around the world think are reasonable as the minimum standards are no good, they have to go, and the wages and conditions we have developed here have to go. To be replaced by what? There is silence from the other side, but the inference is that the minimum standards would be so low and so reduced as to leave people with all sorts of dreadful conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—If that is nonsense, in the speeches that came before mine, why was there not a discussion of what the minimum wage and the minimum standards ought to be? What does this bill, which is so strongly resisted by the other side, do? The Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 makes very substantial amendments to the Industrial Relations Act of 1988.

PARA.TAB: These are things that have been opposed and condemned by the other side. Part VIA deals with minimum entitlements to employees. That is to go—the coalition is resisting that. Subdivision B of part VIA deals with the requirement for lawful termination of employment. There is a provision that employees are to have an opportunity to respond to allegations.
