That is resisted by the other side. The inference is that, if a person is unjustly dismissed from employment, he or she is to have no right, according to those opposite—who resist this act—to respond to the allegation.

Here is another thing that those opposite resist. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to search anything that has been said by those opposite to date where they have addressed their minds to proposed section 170DE, which deals with harsh, unjust or unreasonable termination. There is no indication from the other side as to what they are going to do about that, but they resist this bill, which sets out provisions about remedies in respect of unlawful terminations.

Part 5 talks about promoting bargaining and facilitating agreements. A scheme is set out whereby bargaining between employers and employees can be carried on to the betterment of both. This bill is not anti-employer; it is pro-employer and pro-employee.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can it be both?

—I take that interjection from Senator Boswell—another person I greatly admire; a person who has done great things for small business—because in that interjection we see the attitude of the other side. He is the Leader—and a very distinguished leader—of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, and he is representing the position of the coalition. What does he say about it? He is saying—and we all heard him—that it is impossible for a workplace to be conducted with cooperation between employer and employee.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. That is not what I said at all. I did not say that I did not believe people could work in cooperation. I ran a business for 18 years—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Senator Boswell, you have been here long enough to know that that is not a point of order. Resume your seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to hear from Senator Boswell, but that is the inference I have to take from what he said. What I said is that this bill is both pro-employer and pro-employee. Senator Boswell said that it cannot be both. It must follow from that that he is saying that there cannot be a relationship between employer and employee that can be fair to both. This legislation aims at doing just that.

PARA.TAB: I can understand somebody saying, `This piece of legislation should be amended. Things should be put in it to make it better than it presently is in terms of getting a good relationship between employer and employee', but I cannot understand an outright resistance to this sort of legislation or the statement that follows—that this piece of legislation, whether as it is now or as amended, cannot in any way help to establish good relationships between employers and employees. Not only does it promote bargaining—as the table of provisions says it does—and facilitate agreements; it also sets out a code of conduct when there is a secondary boycott.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Senator Sherry knows all about this.
—We need a code of conduct.

—That is right. I put on the record that Senator Sherry has said that there ought to be a code of conduct. That is absolutely right. If we are going to have good relationships between employers and employees—and look how this government over the last 10 years has established good relationships between employers and employees—
—Strikes have gone down dramatically.

—Strikes have gone down most dramatically. If a situation arises where there may be a boycott, where a boycott is threatened or even where a boycott is taken—and we on this side admit that boycotts can sow very deep seeds of division between employer and employee—this legislation says, `Look, let's not act while the blood is in the head, while nasty things may be said which we might regret saying later on. Let's not move for three days. Let everybody calm down. Let's cool things down. Let's see if we can establish things by direct relationship between employer and employee', which is what I thought the other side wanted. We could almost call that the coalition provision.

PARA.TAB: The secondary boycott provisions set down in part 6 are far-sighted, visionary provisions to enable employers and employees to work together well. On those rare occasions—becoming rarer under this government—when an unhappy relationship develops and, as a result of that, when there may be an attempt to carry out a secondary boycott, when tempers are high, this provides a breathing space whereby people can get back, as Senator Boswell would want, to talking to each other without rushing off to the courts. Part 7 of this bill details the establishment of a new Industrial Relations Court of Australia.

If we look at the scheme of these provisions, we see a continuation of the past. When that great liberal in Australian history Sir Alfred Deakin set up the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1904, I think he foresaw the sorts of things that the Labor government is now doing. I would think that perhaps he would be disappointed that the people who take their soul and their origins from him—coalition members—have not done this. But they have failed to do it, and we have had to step in and follow the great traditions of that great liberal, Sir Alfred Deakin.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 1904 that he set it up. Another great thinker of that time was Mr Justice Higgins, whose Harvester judgment set down the sorts of conditions that are set out in this legislation. This bill is historic, in the sense that it continues the traditions of the past, and it is also modern.

—As I was saying before the suspension for dinner, this bill marries the best of the old with the best of the new. The award system, set up through the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which was established by that great Liberal, Alfred Deakin, is retained in the bill. Part 3 of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 provides a floor below which workers cannot sink.

PARA.TAB: Part VIA of the bill talks about the minimum entitlements of employees. Part 5 refers to promoting bargaining and facilitating agreements. Reference is also made in part VIB to promoting bargaining and facilitating agreements. Part 5 and part VIB achieve that purpose and provide the flexibility that people think should be present in the workplace. That is the new part of the scheme. The old part—the award system—and this new part are married. It is no good going in for radical and revolutionary methods when a slow but gentle and effective change is what is needed.

It is said we should adopt a system of direct bargaining between employers and employees. What happens with that system is that the employer, quite properly from his, her or its point of view, establishes sets of conditions and wages which the employee can either accept or not accept. A great illustration of that, I suppose, is the case that dealt with contracting and subcontracting outside the wage system—the Building Workers' Industrial Union of Australia and Others v. ODCO Pty Ltd, better known as the troubleshooters case.

I will read a passage from the judgment of the court of appeal, consisting of Messrs Justices Wilcox, Burchett and Ryan. The judge on the case being appealed was Mr Justice Woodward. They are all great judges. In the first instance, the full court referred to Mr Justice Woodward. The judges said:

SPEECH.PARA: His Honour also found that the rates of pay offered to its workers were adjusted unilaterally each year by Troubleshooters without consultation with the workers who were nevertheless advised of each adjustment shortly before or immediately after it occurred. He noted as well that the written contract between Troubleshooters and its workers set out above did not include the whole of the terms of engagement because it contained no reference to wet weather allowance, the six hours minimum payment or overtime provisions.

The point I want to make is that if we go ahead with a system that does not take into account the Industrial Relations Commission, the award system and the part the union movement plays in that, we will get a system in which there will be negotiations, but negotiations on the terms set by employers. We cannot blame the employers for wanting to do that, but we can blame the parliament if it does not set up a system, such as is contained in this bill, to prevent that happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, which we are debating tonight, should be a landmark in the essential reform of Australia's outdated, rigid, inflexible and very costly industrial relations system, and should reduce the iron-like grip of the trade union movement over our industrial relations structure. The government had a golden opportunity, perhaps a once in a lifetime opportunity, to promote major reform. It had the support of the Australian public; it had the support of that 71 per cent of all private sector employees who have chosen not to belong to a trade union; it had the support of small and large employers and employer associations; it had the support of not a few of the more responsible trade union leaders; and it had the support of the coalition, which has long seen meaningful, sweeping reform of our industrial relations system as arguably the most important and serious challenge and opportunity facing our nation. That sweeping reform is essential is undeniable.

PARA.TAB: If we want to reduce the present cruel, intolerable and unacceptable level of a million Australians unemployed, if we want to encourage new investment and so increase our productivity to improve our international competitiveness, both in our domestic markets and in overseas markets, and thereby increase job creation, reduce unemployment, give hope to our people and raise the living standards of all Australians, then we must remove the inhibitions and roadblocks that our antiquated industrial relations system places in the way of achieving these fundamental objectives.

We have seen today in the report of the Industry Commission, which follows a plethora of reports from government and other agencies, that industrial relations reform is quite crucial to the future of our nation. That is what was needed with this legislation. That is what we hoped the government might provide. Indeed, our hopes were buoyed shortly after the March election when, on 21 April, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in an important speech—we hope it was an important speech; he thought it was an important speech—that there were not enough genuine enterprise bargains, that the agreements that did exist were insufficiently comprehensive and that too often they were merely add-ons to awards when they should be full substitutes for awards.

At that time the new Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, grandly echoed these noble sentiments, both in Australia and overseas. They were aspirations that had the full support of the Liberal and National parties because, in large part, they reflected the key objectives of the coalition's own industrial relations policy. But what happened? In a nutshell, the fact is that the government, the Prime Minister, his industrial relations minister, and the caucus in the end, never had any intention of following through on their fine rhetoric. Why not? Simply because the trade union movement demanded, as it always has, a payback for the massive support that it gave the Keating government during the federal election campaign in March of this year.

Lest there be any doubt at all, let me just quote from the public debate which occurred between the ACTU Vice President, Jennie George, and Bryan Noakes of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, ACCI, on the contents of the bill now before us. In that debate Ms George said openly, frankly, blatantly and unashamedly:

SPEECH.PARA: What employers have to understand is that we won the election in March and this bill is a payback for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of that election campaign.

As my colleague Senator Parer, I think, said in his remarks yesterday, I do not recall Jennie George or the ACTU actually standing for election in March of this year. But so close is the relationship between the ACTU, the whole of the trade union movement, and the Labor Party that she, the Vice-President of the ACTU, could not draw a distinction between the two. So there we have it from the horse's mouth, from the Vice President of the ACTU herself.

PARA.TAB: What we have before us now is not an Industrial Relations Reform Bill, which is the title of the bill, in any meaningful sense whatsoever. Rather, as my colleague John Howard said so accurately in the other place recently, what we have is a trade union payback bill. It is, at best, a Clayton's industrial relations bill and, at worst, a bill that in the most damaging manner sets back the essential course of reform of our industrial relations system. At the same time, it entrenches still further the power of the trade union movement in this country, despite the fact that the majority of workers in Australia have chosen not to be part of the union movement, have chosen not to join a trade union. As I said, 71 per cent of all employees in the private sector have chosen not to belong to a union.

Many of my colleagues have already made significant contributions to this second reading debate, and we will be pursuing many further and more detailed issues during the committee stage of these bills. I do not propose to reiterate much of what has already been said, but I do now want to summarise very briefly what I see as some of the more fundamental weaknesses and dangers in these bills before the Senate.

However, before doing that, I would place on the public record my appreciation for the work done on these bills by several of my Senate colleagues. In particular I mention Senator Winston Crane and Senator Grant Chapman. Their dissenting report to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which inquired into these bills should be required reading for anyone who is interested in these matters.

Before going to the content of the bill, let me also digress just briefly to comment on a couple of points that were made previously by a couple of government speakers. Before diner tonight, Senator West claimed that all the faxes we have all received about the urgency and problems of the bills before us are—so Senator West claimed—something to do with a master-servant relationship; indeed, she went on to talk, I think, about a master-slave relationship.

What absolute nonsense that is. It is a complete lie because, in fact, very few, a handful, less than 10 of the many hundreds of faxes that most of us have received have made any mention at all of a master-servant relationship or anything vaguely relating to it. Rather, the faxes reveal the full extent of the huge concern felt throughout the community, and particularly throughout small business—the backbone of this nation, the very important sector of this nation without which we will never prosper and thrive and go on to higher living standards, job creation and reduced unemployment—about the grave dangers inherent in this legislation. That is what the faxes I have been receiving are all about; that is what the faxes that my colleagues have been receiving are all about. Quite frankly, the comments made by Senator West before dinner tonight were just absolute nonsense and totally incorrect.

There are a couple of factors I would like to mention in relation to Senator Cooney's speech which preceded mine. He talked about this bill being a pro-employer and a pro-employee bill. I agree that we can have a bill which is a win-win; there is no doubt about that. If the government had got its act together and got it right, we would have had a win-win bill for employers, employees and Australia. But I believe that for Senator Cooney to say this is a bill which is pro-employer and pro-employee is just cloud-cuckoo land. He has obviously read a bill which is different from the one I have read, because everything in this bill is stacked against employers—and shortly I will come in some detail to my reasons for that statement.

Senator Cooney also, though, questioned why there had not been a discussion in this debate on what minimum standards should apply. So far as the coalition is concerned, that has all been set out and its policy is there and has been on the record for a long time for all to see. So far as terms and conditions of employment are concerned, there are minimum standards that should apply in this country; there is a safety net in any policy that the coalition has put forward; and to imply, as Senator Cooney has implied tonight, that opposition to the provisions of this bill somehow or other means opposition to having a set of minimum standards is, with due respect to my friend Senator Cooney, equal nonsense.

The bills suffer grievously from lack of involvement in their formulation by employer representatives. The consultations leading to this bill were supposed to be tripartite; they were supposed to involve the government, the unions and employers. But employers were almost totally shut out; it was a lock out, so far as they were concerned. For example, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry—which represents 30,000 Australian businesses of every size, shape and colour across the length and breadth of this nation—was not represented on the negotiating committee. It was not even provided with a copy of the final agreement which was struck between the government and the ACTU. One could only describe that as an act of vindictive, spiteful, petty and counterproductive retribution by a vengeful Prime Minister.

The lack of consultation and the unseemly haste involved in the drafting of this legislation was reflected in the government itself, when it went into the House of Representatives with its famous bill, having to produce no less than 177 amendments to its own bill. That is an absolute disgrace for a government which claims to be an efficient and competent manager. Not only that but, having gone through all that process, it comes into the Senate with the bill and in the last day circulates amongst us a whole raft of further amendments.

Quite contrary to the Prime Minister's post election rhetoric, these bills entrench the rigid award system as the basis for our wage fixing system. This inhibits the flexibility and labour mobility that is essential for increased job creation and improved productivity. This is the great lost opportunity—the opportunity to grasp the nettle and introduce a framework for an environment of dynamic, responsive human and industrial relations needed so desperately by this country.

The bill comprehensively advantages trade unions and, equally, it comprehensively disadvantages employers—and, I must say, many individual employees. The employers' rights of access to common law are restricted and disadvantaged by this bill; so also is employer redress against secondary boycotts significantly weakened in this bill.

This bill has a totally different philosophy from that which the government intimated, through the Prime Minister's speech back in April, that it would introduce. The philosophy behind this bill is that one should not move away from strict award provisions without considerable difficulty. What is needed in this country is a bill which encourages direct negotiations between employers and employees to achieve essential productivity gains needed to reduce unemployment and increase living standards.

The transfer of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act to the Industrial Relations Act removes employers' protection against political boycotts by rogue unions and others. The proposed changes mean that a business, organisation or individual will not have access to quick and effective relief against an irresponsible boycott action. Indeed, what happens under this bill is that it would take 72 hours before any action can take place; that is, before an employer can go to law and get injunctive relief. Lots of businesses, particularly small businesses in the climate that we have in Australia today, can go broke in 72 hours. Yet this bill prevents them from taking any action of an injunctive or any other nature to solve that problem.

Because the bill reinforces and extends the reach of the federal award system, it reinforces and extends the reach of trade unions. Unions are given extraordinary standing, even in the case of agreements for non-unionised workplaces. The bill allows preference to be given to unionists over non-unionists when an agreement is being negotiated. That is a problem of very significant measure so far as employees who choose not to join a trade union are concerned.

But a preference clause the other way—that is, in favour of a non-unionist—is prohibited under this bill; in other words, in effect we have a proposal that leads us to the closed shop and to compulsory unionism. That is just like the familiar `no ticket, no start' demand that we have had in this country for far too long. Unions should not be able to demand preference and employers should not be able to trade on it.

The bill also relies on the use of the external affairs power of the constitution to create minimum standards based on ILO conventions and recommendations and to impose them on traditional state jurisdictions. In my view, that is simply not on in a democratic country such as ours. First of all, there is the use of the external affairs power at all for these measures, but even worse than that is the selective use that the government has made of the external affairs power in this legislation. That is a use that my colleagues Senator Crane and Senator Chapman, in their dissenting report on the inquiry into this matter, described very accurately as obnoxious.

The bill will not facilitate access to enterprise agreements by non-union workplaces. Indeed, the bill will deter most, if not all, non-unionised workplaces from seeking access to an enterprise flexibility agreement. We on this side of the chamber believe that when striking an enterprise flexibility agreement there should be no requirement either for a dispute to exist or for a trade union to be able to participate in the approval process by right. Sure, a trade union can participate if all parties want it to participate, but it should not be there to participate by right.

The Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993 establishes an Industrial Relations Court of Australia. There is no valid reason at all that has been given for that. It was rejected by this government in 1988. There has been no evidence as to why that situation should change. There are many other provisions in the bill which are equally objectionable and questionable, but time does not permit us to go into them.

In conclusion, this legislation is worse than a lost opportunity; it is a massive sacrifice of our nation's competitive future, the hopes of the unemployed and underemployed and the prospects for employers and employees alike to work together to achieve success in this very important area of industrial relations. For all of those reasons, I join with my other coalition colleagues in flatly rejecting this bill, hoping that the government will withdraw it, go back to the drawing board and start again. That is the only thing that can satisfactorily conclude this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate there has been a lot of hyperbole but we have just heard it lifted to an art form. It was an argument so overstated and overblown as to be almost a parody of itself.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 is an important bill that warrants an important debate. I welcome the fact that there has been such an extensive debate; in both houses of parliament there have been more than 50 speakers. That is an indication of the interest in the bill, of the substance of the bill and of the significant differences about the issues raised by the bill.

From the government's point of view, this is a bill which makes a very important contribution to labour market reform in Australia. Notwithstanding the strength of difference of views about how such reform should be pursued, I think there is an agreed concern that we need to lift competitiveness and efficiency in Australia. What we need to focus on in considering this bill—and what the public needs to focus on in making its decisions about the merits of the arguments put forward, as the public concentrated on the issues in contention with regard to this bill during the course of the election—is the different approaches to achieve the reform that we all agree is required.

During the course of the election, in the development of this bill, in the bill and in the debate about the bill, the government has consistently said that there are twin themes: flexibility and fairness. We hear a lot said about flexibility. I do not want to underestimate its significance but sometimes in the debate people have been mute about fairness; that is, about being fair to those who are, in many instances, the weaker party in the contract negotiations in the industrial relations arena.

Because the government is very concerned about fairness, we made it an important issue in the election. We reiterated it in the debate leading up to this bill. It is in the bill on the basis of very strong worker protection with a secure and relevant award safety net. These are not only important in social terms, in terms of the rights of the individuals who are affected; they are also vital to the success of labour market reform. When there is a secure safety net, the possibility exists for constructive workplace flexibility and for negotiations without fear of a major loss of conditions and entitlements, because the underpinning exists. So a basis exists for mutually confident negotiations that can lead to workplace flexibility and dynamic productivity growth.

Throughout the decade the government has had a commitment to a cooperative approach to industrial relations, to recognising the importance of protecting and advancing the interests of working men and women in Australia, but it has done so in a cooperative, agreed fashion. As part of that process the bill before us has been developed on the basis of an extensive consultation process. There has been a lot of talk, including in the most recent contribution, about there not being significant consultation, and I will detail that in just a moment. But the first thing to remember about the consultative approach in a democracy is that the government's basic approach to industrial relations reform was well established and known before the last election. It was an important issue in the last election and the people made their choice on that, amongst other factors.

Since the election the proposed legislation has been subject to an intensive consultative process. Let me give a few figures. Since April the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) has had 36 face-to-face meetings with employer organisations and individual business leaders; he has had 28 meetings with trade unions; he has delivered 14 major speeches outlining progress with the bill's development; he has had two meetings of the tripartite National Labour Consultative Council; he has convened two meetings of Labor ministers, that is, with his state and territory colleagues; and he has had numerous meetings with interest groups. In the course of that consultation, the minister has visited all states, most of them on two or more occasions. As honourable senators would know, but perhaps not anybody else, the legislation has also been the subject of two Senate committee inquiries.

As I said in my opening remarks, in the House of Representatives and the Senate combined we have had more than 50 speakers on the bill. There has been very widespread consultation and opportunity to participate in and contribute to the debate. Notwithstanding the widespread consultation, there is no agreement, and that is not surprising. No legislative package could ever hope to satisfy all the competing groups with an interest in industrial relations. It may well be that this is a bill—from the government's point of view, it is, but it is a matter for debate—that is broadly in the interests of employers, employees, the society as a whole and the economy as a whole. But it does not meet everybody's expectations; no bill ever will. So it is not surprising that we do not have consensus, notwithstanding the broad base of consultation.

There are some important matters laid down in this legislation. They are matters that need to be recognised, acknowledged and given due weight in consideration of the bill itself and any amendments to it. I will not deal with the amendments in this speech because that is for the committee stage of the debate.

I will outline the key principles underlying the bill. It is important to remember that the government's proposals put the onus on the industrial parties to take responsibility for their own industrial relations. It is another step away from the traditional approach in the early part of this century which assumed that there was, through an arbitral process, the capacity to resolve all problems through a centralised system. The proposals give greater access to formal enterprise bargaining through, on the one hand, certified agreements and, on the other hand, enterprise flexibility agreements. The scope for innovation through these mechanisms is already being shown through certified agreements under the existing legislation which are generating an impressive range of productivity measures. These will now be supplemented by enterprise flexibility agreements.

There has been concern that in some way the safeguards built into the process will deter employers from using these processes. But the safeguards protecting workers' wages and conditions do not seem to me, to the government or to the majority of Australians to be onerous. They are protections that will not cause any problem where any employer reaches an enterprise flexibility agreement which is fair. Nobody in those circumstances should face any difficulty in having agreements approved. Rather than impeding flexibility, the protections will ensure that negotiations can focus on sustainable productivity improvements and not the mere consideration of one-off cuts to wages and conditions and the inevitable conflict that arises from attempts so to do.

It is important to reiterate the underlying reasons why trade unions responsible to the relevant award and members at the workplace have a right to be involved in the negotiation of agreements. It seems only fair in the circumstance when they are parties to the matter which is under discussion and when members of the organisation are at that workplace. It is very unusual to argue that a party to a matter under consideration should not have rights to participate in the reconsideration of that award or agreement.

If unions do not have any members, then their right is limited to being heard before the Industrial Relations Commission during the approval process to argue whether the agreement meets the legislative requirements. But in those circumstances there is no union veto. It is for the Industrial Relations Commission to determine and apply the no disadvantage test. But the government regards the no disadvantage test as a very important principle. It does allow for agreed reductions if these are judged not to be against the public interest—for example, as part of a strategy for dealing with a short-term crisis and revival.

The government has unashamedly—in fact, quite proudly—underpinned its industrial relations reform with firm worker protections. It has done so in recognition of the sorts of concerns that have been raised, amongst others, by senators from the Greens, the Australian Democrats and members of the government.

The key safeguards provided in the bill are about the effective award safety net, the no disadvantage test, the framework for fair and effective bargaining and protection for workers against discrimination. The bill's protective provisions will be complemented by other government measures, including an annual survey to monitor developments with enterprise bargaining and particularly its impact on disadvantaged groups. The design and analysis of this survey will be developed in conjunction with the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. The government will also meet its commitment to establish work in women's centres to advise women on enterprise bargaining and other work-related pay and conditions matters. Overall the government considers that the proposals strike the right balance between enhancing flexibility and ensuring an adequate safety net of employee protection.

The Democrats have raised with the government the issue of special carers' leave for workers to look after sick dependants. The government will be giving consideration to future legislation to extend the minimum entitlements provisions, giving effect to ILO convention 156 on workers with family responsibilities, to provide for such leave. This would be pursued subject to the outcome of a test case conducted before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on application from the ACTU seeking the setting of an appropriate standard. Adopting this approach, rather than legislating now for the leave, is seen as the preferable way to go, given the absence of existing community standards on this matter and the accepted role of the commission in setting such standards.

Although this is a very important bill, I do not want to unduly delay consideration of it. In conclusion, the bill before the Senate is a balanced package. It does not pursue narrow, ideologically inspired, quick fix deregulationist approaches. Rather it is looking, with a sense of reality, towards a constructive way forward—not something prescribed in a first-year economic textbook or a theoretical model, but a practical, on the ground way of achieving what have the potential to be important reforms if the Senate passes them in the form sought by the government. It provides ample opportunities for flexibility and cooperative approaches to lift competitiveness and productivity. It also ensures that the interests of workers are protected. Its combination of flexibility and fairness is the only way to achieve the sustainable improvements that Australia needs.

There is a lot more that can be said, but we have already had 50 speeches in the two houses in consideration of this bill. Therefore, I will not seek in any way to reiterate all the arguments put for the bills or rebut all those against them. I think it is a question of going over the major themes and putting down some issues that have not been put on behalf of the government that needed to be put on the record. I commend the bills to the Senate.
Question put:
That the bills be now read a second time
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to raise a matter of concern.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gather that the Democrats have a series of amendments but are yet to circulate them. I understand that the Greens have just circulated a series of amendments. It really does seem intolerable to be debating this stage of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 in those circumstances. In other words, the committee is being asked to debate issues that are not even before the chamber, let alone receive the attention that they deserve.
—The result of that in the past has been faulty legislation. Senator Burns might not care about that, but this chamber has a responsibility as a house of review to try to do its job properly.
—Can't you think on your feet?

—I am a better thinker on my feet than Senator Burns. If amendments are going to be introduced at this stage in the middle of the debate, that is not a satisfactory legislative process. Senator Burns ought to know that and his government ought to know that. We are ready to do this job tonight. We are prepared, but if others are not, it should not go on in this way.

PARA.TAB: I am suggesting to the government that it might like to consider that what I am about to put to it is sound and that it should agree to it. I suggest we adjourn at this stage, go on with other legislation tonight and proceed with this committee stage debate tomorrow. I invite the government's consideration of that proposition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to respond to those comments.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody is concerned to have a reasonable and considered debate. This is a very important bill.
—I should hope so.

—I thank Senator Archer. There are 76 of us concerned about that. It is therefore a matter that I have asked the office of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) to consider and I have raised it with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner).
—Is the minister somewhere else?

—No. There is a problem, I suspect, for all parties involved in that I do not think anybody is ready to proceed. Senator Watson asked me not to proceed to the next bill on the Notice Paper because he cannot be here today. So we will all have to do a quick rethink. But I am not trying to resist. I am just getting a brief on all the amendments that have been made available. I have some, but I am not sure that they have all been distributed to everybody.
—They haven't.

—I am not disputing Senator Ferguson's word. The Chairman quite legitimately raised this concern with me earlier and said that I cannot schedule the consideration of this matter in the way that I would wish because I do not have all the amendments. I would like to get some clarification from Senator Bell and Senator Margetts as to whether all the amendments which they proposed are available to be distributed. While they are doing that, I will try to run my eye over the sequence to make sure that adequate notice has been given of the early matters that we have to deal with. If they have not, I will not challenge Senator Hill's proposal that we should not proceed with this. If the material before us—that which is distributed late—does not relate to things that will be before us first, then I think the situation is different. So if Senator Bell and Senator Margetts can give some indication as to whether all the amendments they intend to propose—
—This one is yours.
—I thank Senator Archer for his helpful contribution. I actually know that. What I am trying to find out—
—Why are you trying to brush it off on to someone else?
—Well—
—Order! Senator McMullan, feel free to address your remarks to me.

—I would like to do that, but you are looking in the wrong direction if you are trying to make that comment, Mr Chairman. Senator Hill raised with me a concern—and other of Senator Archer's colleagues by terribly disorderly interjection—that the Democrat amendments had not been distributed. That is why I am asking for clarification from Senator Bell. Also, a comment was made about whether all Senator Margetts's amendments have been distributed. Once we get that clarified, we will have the facts on the table and we will be able to make an informed judgment. That is the reason I made that comment.
—I seek leave to contribute to this discussion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the criticism of not having our amendments final and distributed before the chamber. There are a couple of reasons for that, one of which is that, in common with other honourable senators, I received several dozen faxes today, yesterday, and the day before—I can quote from a dozen or 15 of those faxes—appealing that this legislation not be steamrolled through the chamber and suggesting that this matter should receive full discussion. There have been some suggested amendments in those communications, about which I have communicated with the shadow minister for industrial relations, Mr Howard. He has raised some matters to which we are giving favourable consideration. That has meant that mark 6 or mark 7 of our amendments has been discussed with Mr Howard and also with the minister.

PARA.TAB: In trying to accommodate the request for full discussion, and to facilitate the moving of the suggested amendments—whether they be suggested amendments from the coalition or from people who speak after having been inspired to speak by the coalition—we have had some difficulty in arriving at what could be described as a final format of amendments. In taking that course, we are doing exactly what this chamber is supposed to be doing. It is certainly not a situation that has been brought about just by the Democrats. This situation has been contributed to by all parties involved in this matter, all parties who want to see a full discussion.

We have just this instant received a further supplementary explanatory memorandum from the government. I support and accept the criticisms and I think the suggestion by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate should be supported—that the progress of this bill be adjourned—simply for those reasons. If we are sensible and mature about this, we will achieve a better result than we would if we tried to score cheap political points by criticising each other for not being prepared at this moment.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill implements an important wine agreement reached between the European Community and Australia last year. The agreement, which followed five years of negotiations, is a milestone for our export oriented wine industry—an industry which exported $293 million worth of wine last financial year. Almost half of that, or $144 million, went to the European Community, despite strong objections to Australia using wine names based on wine growing regions in Europe.

PARA.TAB: The wine agreement means that Australia will phase out European names and protect a list of thousands of EC geographical names which are of no commercial significance to Australia. Little used names, such as frascati and white bordeaux, will be phased out by the end of the year, while the next group of names, including chianti and madeira, will be phased out by December 1997. No date has been set for the commercially important names, such as claret, chablis, burgundy and champagne, but negotiations on a phase-out date are due to conclude by 31 December 1997.

Importantly, the wine agreement will enable Australia to enter other international agreements; improve access to the European market by reducing the number of analyses required by the EC from eight to three; and allow Australian sweet wine into the EC for the first time. Under the agreement, each party will recognise each other's regions and winemaking practices and standards. In light of that, I am pleased that our winemakers have already starting replacing European names with varietal and brand names. Once protection comes into effect, European and Australian geographical names will only be used to indicate the true place of origin of the wine. In fact, the bill creates several new offences, including the false or misleading use of geographical names and traditional expressions for wine.

The bill also establishes a Geographical Indications Committee to determine Australian boundaries for geographical identification purposes. For example, if a wine is labelled Hunter River wine, the grapes must come from the Hunter River region. The committee will compromise nominees of the Winemakers Federation of Australia, the Wine Grape Growers Council of Australia and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. It will publish proposed determinations and seek submissions from winemakers, grape growers and their organisations on the boundaries of Australian winegrowing regions. There will also be appeal rights to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court.

The bill establishes the position of registrar of geographical indications and traditional expressions, who will be employed by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The registrar will keep a list of protected EC names and inform other countries of Australia's protected names.

The National Food Authority has been asked to modernise the Australian food standards covering wine and bring them more closely, but not entirely, into line with EC standards. Naturally, Australian industry does not want to have to adopt all EC standards.

The bill also authorises the importation of wine from the EC, which conforms with the compositional requirements set down in the agreement and allows for these standards to be varied from time to time. However, EC wine will still have to comply in all other respects with Australian standards, including labelling and alcoholic content.

The bill allows regulations to be made concerning blending rules for wine and the composition of export wine. However, these regulations will not be activated until there has been further consultation with the industry, the Wine and Brandy Corporation and the National Food Authority. The corporation will be able to prescribe the grape varieties which may be used in winemaking. This will prevent the use of hybrid grape varieties in export wine, which is a concern in some export markets.

My colleague the shadow minister for primary industries, Mr John Anderson, recently told the other place that government support for the wine industry had vanished like cheap chardonnay at a caucus picnic. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is deeply regrettable that the wine industry, as is the case with so many other agricultural industries in this country, finds that—because of its apparent success—it is simply targeted for further cost increases imposed by a government that just does not seem to understand the need for sound, far-reaching structural tax reform delivered in the interests of all Australians.

Unlike Australia, no successful European winemaking country has pushed for tax equity between the way that beer and spirits are taxed and the way that wine is taxed. When the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) made this point, he said:

They have recognised, as the government should recognise, that the wine industry is quite different from the beer or spirits industries in lead times in the planting of grapes and the maturation of wine, and in the investment required in both capital and jobs. So, a tax on the domestic industry becomes a tax on the export industry . . .

Despite the heavy-handed actions of the federal Labor government, the wine industry hopes to lift exports to $1 billion a year by the year 2000. The federal coalition wishes the industry well and places on record its support for this legislation, which will remove technical trade barriers to the EC market via the wine agreement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this legislation on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1993 implements the December 1992 wine agreement reached between Australia and the European Community. Most importantly, the agreement delivers European acknowledgment of the winemaking practices of the Australian wine industry.

PARA.TAB: The wine industry believes this is a very significant occasion as it confirms Australia's status as a quality wine producer of international standard. The agreement and the legislation will also give Australian winemakers a significant head start on many of their major competitors, as many other winemaking nations appear to be a long way off reaching similar agreements.

The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation hopes the European Community agreement can be finalised before Christmas. It must go before the parliaments of the individual European nations for ratification. However, the corporation believes this is just a formality.

When ratified, the agreement will do the following: improve European access for Australian wine; provide mutual recognition by Australia and the EC of each other's winemaking practices and standards; restrict the use of geographical names and indicators; phase out the Australian use of European geographical indications; allow the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation to set up a Geographical Indications Committee, which will define the names and boundaries of the Australian wine regions; and establish a register of geographical indications.

Improved access to European markets is a vital part of the Australian wine industry's strategy to reach its billion dollar export target by the year 2000. The Wine and Brandy Corporation believes that as long as Australian winemakers conform to the new regulations and standards, there is no reason to believe that Australians will be denied access to European markets. With the agreement providing official confirmation of our winemaking status, exports to Europe should be significantly boosted from the 1992-93 level of about $150 million.

The restrictions on the use of geographical names and indications and the phasing out of Australia's use of European names is scheduled to begin by 31 December this year for some infrequently used names, such as beaujolais and frascati. Other groups of names, including chianti and madeira, are due to be phased out by 31 December 1997. The phasing out of more frequently used names, such as chablis, champagne, claret, port, sherry and white burgundy, is still to be negotiated. Australian winemakers have retained the right to use the terms hermitage, lambrusco and riesling, pending the determination of the phase-out period.

The Wine and Brandy Corporation believes that some sections of the media have sensationalised the European names element of this agreement by suggesting that Australian winemakers must stop using European names and indications altogether by 1997. The proposal states that agreement on a phasing out period must be reached by 1997, possibly giving Australian winemakers many years to come up with alternatives to those frequently used European names.

In some cases, particularly with products such as port and sherry, finding suitable alternative names could well be difficult. However, winemakers realise they cannot afford to paint themselves into a corner and are prepared to search for alternatives. My discussions with winemakers in the Coonawarra region of South Australia suggest the process of phasing out European names is already well under way. No doubt this applies to other winemaking regions as well. With proper marketing, it will not take Australian consumers of wine and port long to learn that their favourite beverage is now sold under a new name.

In return for the phasing out of European names and indications, the EC has offered Australian winemakers a number of important concessions. These concessions cover issues as varied as sparkling wines, show awards and blending. Perhaps the most important concession relates to certificate requirements. Australian wines will now undergo only three alcohol and acidity analyses instead of the current eight. The EC has also promised to register expanded lists of grape varieties and geographical indications, while there will be annual consultations to resolve issues affecting the wine trade between Australia and the EC.

I have some concerns over the boundaries aspect of this bill. The bill gives the Wine and Brandy Corporation the authority, through a new geographical indications committee, to define the names and boundaries of Australia's wine making regions. The corporation says it has fully consulted the industry and individual regions about this matter, and there is certainly no reason to doubt that. Winemakers have expressed to me that they support the definition of boundaries as it protects the high prices that they often paid for their land.

However, to again use the Coonawarra as an example, there is already one challenge to the boundary that has been drawn around this region. Clearly the drawing of boundaries is a very difficult task and there will be winners and losers.

The legislation provides a mechanism for hearing grievances. Once the initial determination of the geographical indications committee is published, those affected will have one month to make a submission to the committee. The committee's final determination will then be published, and if there are still objections, the affected parties have the right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The tribunal's rulings will be final.

The Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill provides enormous advantages for the rapidly expanding Australian wine industry. The bill is widely supported, certainly by the winemakers I have spoken to, along with the Winemakers Federation. This piece of wine legislation makes a refreshing change to the turmoil and chaos created by the wine tax legislation before the Senate a few weeks ago.

The bill is central to the bilateral wine agreement with the European Community, and puts Australia at the forefront of wine trade with Europe. As I have said, it will also provide a significant boost to the wine industry's target of $1 billion in exports by the year 2000. Under these circumstances the Democrats are pleased to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. Coming from the Hunter, Australia's premier wine growing region, I naturally feel that this bill before the Senate tonight is very important. The purpose of the bill is to provide for the protection of Australian and foreign country wine names and descriptions.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments before the Senate are intended to give effect to a recent agreement between Australia and the European union aimed at developing and promoting the trade in wine, and this is welcomed. Because these amendments are supported by the industry and will assist the industry to increase its trade, the coalition will be supporting the bill.

The agreement which this bill implements is a result of negotiations between the European union and Australia which began in 1988. The agreement provides for the mutual recognition of each other's winemaking practices and standards, affords mutual protection for each party's geographic names, allows Australian winemakers greater market access with respect to different varieties, specific regional wine blends and certain sweet wines, and the gradual phase out of the Australian use of European union geographical names.

The wine agreement has the support of the Winemakers Federation of Australia and the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. Both of these organisations consider the agreement to be a platform from which Australia can expand its wine exports into the EC.

It is with this point in mind that one expresses some surprise at the government's position on the bill because everything else it has done in recent times in this industry seems aimed at destroying its export potential. I refer to the appalling proposal in the budget to increase the wine sales tax to 31 per cent. This is a measure described by the Chief Executive of the Orlando Wyndham Group as `cutting industry off at the knees'.

The current ALP government certainly did not consider the export potential of the Australian wine industry as significant enough to propose that idiotic measure. Fortunately, due to the firm stance taken by the coalition, the government's tax measure was not able to go ahead and the government was forced into a compromise. It had to lower the tax rate. The gradual changes that it has been forced into gives this industry, with its tremendous export potential, some hope of surviving and prospering. Any increase in tax we felt was unwarranted and something for which the government had absolutely no mandate. Fortunately, due to the actions of this parliament, it was forced to compromise.

It is interesting to note the speech given by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) in the other place. Contrary to the evidence of the last budget, Mr Fitzgibbon actually tried to claim that the Labor government had been working to help the industry to increase its profit margins. He quoted Mr Brian Croser, the President of the Winemakers Federation of Australia, who stated last year:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian wine industry can only be judged as an outstanding success in all but its profit margins, and there it is turning a corner.

The extraordinary irony of this is that Mr Fitzgibbon acknowledged that the only problem with the wine industry is its low profit margin. He then supported an increase in wine sales tax which will reduce sales and cut the profit margins even further. One would wonder about the logic of an honourable member who advocates that. It is absolutely extraordinary when he comes from a major wine growing area. There was a need for him and the government to realise that the tax impost they were proposing would damage the industry. It would do that by undermining the domestic sales base. We cannot build the expertise and the profit reserves necessary to continue our work in the export market unless we have that domestic base.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the government, the coalition understands the needs of the wine industry and has shown throughout its opposition to increase tax imposts on this industry. Unlike the government, the coalition has been consistent in its support for the wine industry and that is why we are very happy to support this bill tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1993. This bill gives effect to the EC-Australia wine agreement reached back in December last year after more than five years of negotiations. I am particularly concerned to put on the record, because some honourable senators may not know, that we have a small but very important wine industry in Queensland. It is based in Stanthorpe and Roma.

PARA.TAB: Given that the European Community is currently our largest wine export market, with a massive 44 million litres of wine worth over $140 million exported to that continent in the last financial year, the importance of this agreement ought to be obvious. This is particularly true given the wine industry's stated desire to see the value of wine exports reach an annual target of $750 million by 1996-97 and a billion dollars by the year 2000. The great thing about those figures is that they are achievable and probably will be reached. We certainly give three cheers for that.

This agreement will greatly enhance access to the European Community for Australian wines, firstly, by reducing the paperwork and the number of analyses the Europeans require our wines to be subjected to and, secondly, by allowing the export of our sweet wines to the European market for the first time. The agreement also provides for a mutual acceptance of the wine making practices and standards of each of the parties and does so without compromising the health or labelling standards applicable in Australia.

Perhaps the most visible aspect of this agreement from a consumer's point of view will be that it provides for the restriction of the use of geographical names and indications in the wine industry. Other speakers have also mentioned this fact.

We agree with the commitment given by Australia to move towards the phasing out of the use of various European regional names to describe our wines. It is certainly a sign of our maturity. The fact that we are getting over our cultural cringe means that we are able to affirm this strongly.

The speed of this phase-out will be based on the commercial importance of the individual name being used and will allow time for consumers to become accustomed to the new names. Clearly, given that the use of the European names has gone on for over a century and our wines are now so readily identified by those names, the readjustment to new varietal and brand names will take some time and, I suspect, a fairly concerted marketing effort on the part of the wine industry. But it will be achieved.

However, the replacement of the European names with names representative of Australian varieties and brands is an important part of Australian winemakers differentiating our wines on world markets as the superior quality and distinctive wines that they are. Given the quality and purity of our wines, I am confident that the new names will establish themselves quickly. I would like to predict that Queensland names will be there. I would suggest that some imaginative names might be `Roma Red', `Warwick White' and `Stanthorpe Sweetener'. We look forward to what the industry will come up with.

To follow up this phasing out of geographical names the bill provides for the establishment of the geographical indications committee to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and a register of clearly defined geographical indications. Finally, and most importantly, the agreement ensures that the Europeans will not impose additional certification requirements on our exported wines and, of course, the converse is also true.

This bill has the full support of the Winemakers Federation of Australia and in my home state it also has the support of the Wine Industry Council of Queensland. The overall thrust of the bill will be to facilitate the wine trade between Australia and the European Community. I, for one, certainly hope that this piece of legislation and the agreement that it enacts plays a part in ensuring that our wine industry reaches the export targets it has set itself.

Of course, as my colleague Senator Lees has said, a further measure that the Democrats have called for for many years now, and one that will be essential if the industry is to reach these targets, is the establishment of a specific industry plan for our wine industry. As with any industry, the changes governments impose need to be framed within an overall strategy for that industry.

This was one of the reasons the Democrats were so strongly opposed to the 55 per cent increase in sales tax as it was originally proposed within this year's budget. The move was a revenue raiser pure and simple and it was made in isolation of any specific separate wine industry policy. The absence of such a policy was a factor in our consistent opposition to the sales tax increases on wine back in 1984 and again in 1986.

When talking of providing assistance to the wine industry it is instructive for us to look at page 17 of the recently released annual report of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, which shows that over the past four years the level of wine exports from Australia has more than doubled from 41,654 kilolitres in 1989-90 to over 100,000 kilolitres in 1992-93. At the same time, however, the figures also show that our wine imports have gradually decreased year after year over that same period. This is exactly the sort of industry we ought to be protecting and encouraging, one with rapidly increasing exports and declining imports. Would it not be great if we could describe every Australian industry in that way!

We believe that the sales tax increase of 55 per cent, as proposed, would have had a severely negative impact on all sections of the wine industry, including the export sector. In particular, the sudden effect that such an increase would have had on those wineries and vineyards in the smaller wine regions such as Stanthorpe in my home state would have been devastating. And let us not forget that wine is predominantly produced by small local businesses, from the grape grower right through to the winery. While the size of the crush in Queensland is not as great as that in other states, as Senator Lees has reminded me, the potential of the Queensland industry is enormous.

When we are looking at the Stanthorpe region, as with other wine producing areas, we do not only see the wineries themselves but also the level of tourism those wineries and vineyards generate and the many hotels, motels, restaurants and other facilities the area provides to service those tourists. To have imposed a huge taxation increase would have not only put at risk the livelihoods of those involved in the production of wine in the region but also put at risk many associated industries and, ultimately, the very existence of that great region itself.

It is these sorts of factors that need to be considered before imposing a change of the magnitude proposed in the budget, and it is these sorts of factors that a specific industry plan would be able to take into account. Such a plan, combined with the agreement enacted by the legislation before us today, will be essential ingredients for our wine industry to increase its exports into the huge European market and to reach its target of $1 billion worth of exports by the year 2000. I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill, legislating an agreement made between Australia and the European Parliament, signifies that the Australian wine industry has come of age. In essence, it provides for the recognition by both the European Community and Australia of each other's winemaking practices and standards; it recognises each other's geographic names; and, most importantly, it allows Australian access to the very lucrative wine markets of Europe. Of course, my colleague Senator Calvert has recently been studying the industry in the south of France.

PARA.TAB: When the agreement was first announced there was a mad scramble in Australia because, in effect, it meant that Australian wines could not be called champagne, burgundy, chianti, madeira and frontignac. But there are three stages for the dropping of geographical names. The first stage is a list of thousands of geographical names which are not used commercially. The second stage, which comes into effect on 31 December this year, precludes the use of such terms as beaujolais, frascati and white bordeaux. The third stage, which is supposed to take effect by 1997, precludes us from using the terms champagne, claret, chablis, burgundy, moselle, sauterne, sherry, white burgundy, port and champagne.

TALK.START.PARA: —We still have our Sherry!
—I had noted the irony!

—I do not know why any wine was ever named after Senator Sherry; obviously, he was named after the wine. However, this list is yet to be agreed to by the 14 European wine producing nations. So it may well be the next century by the time that approval process has been completed. In the meantime, the expansion of the Australian wine industry has proceeded with enormous pace and what we call our wines has had little impact on their popularity in Europe.

PARA.TAB: When I was recently in Europe I had the opportunity to talk with people involved in trade and I found the success of Australian wines is much commented on. Indeed, Australia is now the fourth biggest exporter of wines to the United Kingdom following France, Germany and Italy, and we have already displaced Spain. Australian wine sales in Britain have increased by 80 per cent to 100 per cent each year since the late 1980s. In 1989, Britons were buying 7.3 million litres and that has now jumped to 36.2 million litres. I would definitely say that the Poms are getting right into our wines and enjoying them. We are doing a great job.

Might I add a rider to that? My experience in the United Kingdom just recently was that the New Zealanders are starting to get under our neck. And we should not forget South Africa and other countries which are competing with our wines in that market. So we cannot rest on our laurels.

The French are particularly nervous because Australia produces high quality wines in the mid-price range, just like France. The export of wines into Germany is still in its infancy with only exported one million litres to Germany, but we are improving there as well. We might be exporting coals to Newcastle, but we are doing very well in that area.

Only a few weeks ago, I was in the Young, Cowra and Wagga districts talking with winegrowers. At the Charles Sturt University winery, I was told—and it was confirmed by local winemaker Ken Helm—that Australia is a world leader in wine technology. Indeed, staff from the Charles Sturt University are in Portugal teaching the Portuguese how to process their grapes. I have a personal reservation about exporting our expertise and technology, but that is another issue.

We are ahead of the areas that Senator Calvert recently studied in that in Australia we have a completely automated industry. Harvesting of the grape is done very quickly by commercial harvesters. The grape is put into bins very quickly and crushed so there is no fermentation at the bottom of the baskets, which happens in France. We are leading the world in quality. I take my hat off to the Australian industry for doing that.

The only trouble is that we are exporting that technology. It will not be easy for winemakers in Europe to change because they have small vineyards and they do not have such long runs for their harvesters, and that sort of thing. Exporting our winemaking ability will obviously create a bit more competition for us, but I suppose that if we did not export it, somebody else would work out what was happening, anyway.

The industry is essentially in two or three parts. We have the big and medium wineries and myriad smaller wineries, which I call the petite boutique wineries. They are the ones that add to tourism. They produce special quality wines. They might not even do the crushing in their own winery, but they do the growing of the grapes and they make a big contribution to the industry.

The big four players in the export drive will be responsible for some $1 billion worth of exports by the year 2000, which Senator Woodley alluded to just a moment ago. The 600 small wineries might produce only 10 per cent of the Australian wine production, but they play an important part in the industry, and also in the tourist industry. Last year, wineries were voted one of the most visited tourist places in Australia. It is interesting that at the trade export awards, which I attended last week as the guest of Senator Cook, Orlando, selling its Jacobs Creek wines, received the award for the top exporter from Australia. I take my hat off to Orlando because it has done a fantastic job competing in the European market with other wines.

The federal government recently demonstrated its total lack of understanding of the industry with the proposed imposition of a 55 per cent increase in wine tax. Why the hell it was trying to do that—kill the goose that lays the golden egg, or crush the grape that produces the enjoyment, pleasure and export income for Australia—I would not know, but it tried to do it. That would have hurt the industry a great deal. Why this government tries to tax people who start to make money for Australia, heaven knows, but it tried to do it. Of course, that failed—and the government failed to appreciate the unique structure of this industry which, as I have explained, is divided into two or three distinct categories.

The smaller wineries will play no part in Australia's export drive, but the success of Australia on the export scene has quite significant implications for them as well. If we do not keep up our export sales, the wine produced by the big companies will flow back onto the domestic market. This will adversely affect prices, and smaller and boutique wineries will be forced to close. I do not think we all realise the problems associated with this issue.

This wonderful country of ours is almost unique in its diversity of grape growing regions. From Queensland, which Senator Woodley mentioned earlier, through to Tasmania, where my colleague Senator Calvert comes from—and he is a connoisseur and a great supporter of the wine industry in Tasmania—on the east coast, and right across Australia to the west coast, Australia produces an enormously diverse range of quality wines.

It is interesting that the slopes of the Canobolas, in the central west of New South Wales, and Cowra, Young and those areas, will be the top areas of winegrowing in the future. Maybe the Hunter Valley, which I live just outside of and which I have had a lot to do with, will be the producer of the wine but not the grower of the grape in the future. Only time will tell.

We need to ensure that the diversity and the viability of the industry remains. The French have realised our potential and have now invested in our industry. That is exactly what I would say Senator Calvert will talk about in his speech tonight, as well as how we have invested in the wine industry in France. It has long ceased to be a small industry—when we talk about the $1 billion export drive, it is an important export earner. In 1992-93 we exported almost $300 million worth, with almost half going to the EC countries. Here at home, Australians bought 311,000 kilolitres of wine, and imported wines were only a very small part of that.

We are at last recognising that the home product is a quality one. New South Wales wine is amongst the best in Australia, if not the world. Being a senator for New South Wales, I have to say that. Those from Tasmania might differ, those from Western Australia might differ, those from Victoria might differ and those from Queensland might differ, but I would say that the New South Wales wines would be amongst the best in the world. We are at last recognising that the home product is a quality one.

This legislation puts the industry truly into the world league and is a recognition of the expansion and development that has occurred. I believe the wine industry in Australia is dynamic. It is conscious of developing a quality product and it is aggressive in its marketing, both here and overseas. Whether our wines are labelled bordeaux, chardonnay, champagne or Australian white will matter little; it is the drinking of it and the enjoyment of it that will count. It is what is in the bottle that matters. Increasingly, the world is learning that with our wine, as with our beef, Australia means a quality product anywhere it is sold in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the haste with which the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill was brought on, I had not prepared myself to make a speech of any length, and I will not. But because of the invitations given to me, by Senator Brownhill in particular, I thought it may be advisable to say at least a few words about my experiences recently in France.

PARA.TAB: I took the opportunity to visit two Australian winemakers who are pioneering our technology in France, each for entirely different reasons. James Herrick and his company, Global Vineyards, sponsored by Robert Hesketh in South Australia, are using Australian technology to make wine in the southern part of France to export, particularly into the UK. They are concentrating on white wines—chardonnays—and they are doing a great job at the moment using Australian technology.

Bill Hardy, Sir James's brother, is using the French grapes available in the Languedoc-Roussillon area to produce red wines—merlots, cabernets and blends—and also white wines, and is exporting into the English market, or so he thought at the time. Because of the quality of the wines his company is making and the contacts they have here in Australia, they are finding—in the initial stages, anyway—that a fair amount of their wine is coming back to Australia. Both wine producers are having a very significant impact on the wine scene in France.

The bill we are debating tonight seeks to rationalise the naming of wines. As Senator Brownhill said, it does not really matter what you call it; it is the quality and the effect that it has on the market that counts.

James Herrick and Bill Hardy have placed advertisements in the local French press. One that comes to mind is, `Try French chardonnay made the Australian way'. That is the kind of impact these two Australian winemakers are having on the winemaking industry in France.

The southern part of France, the `Doc' area as it is called, is not looked upon as one of the best wine producing areas in France, probably because the winemaking abilities of the people have not moved with the times. It is a very old area. In fact, the place in which we were staying, owned by a Tasmanian friend of mine, was a 16th century house with an 11th century barn. I think that is typical of the area. Things have not changed much—the wine technology certainly has not—and the advent of Australians with their technology has had an effect. I must admit that all the stainless steel tanks, the filters and most of the machinery that is being used in the wineries is all of French and Italian origin; nevertheless, the techniques are Australian. I foresee, given the changes that will come to pass with the GATT agreements, somewhat of a change in winemaking in southern France.

Scorn has been poured upon `Doc' wines, not because of the quality of the grapes but because of the quality of the winemaking. Bill Hardy has used local grapes to produce top quality wines that have won prizes right across France.James Herrick is producing chardonnay wines. One can drive past stunted vineyards that have existed for hundreds of years and then suddenly come across a vineyard with trellises and grapes being grown the Australian way. One knows that one is looking at an Australian vineyard. Unfortunately, the restrictions placed on these Australian winemakers by French authorities limit the amount of grapes grown per hectare. I see this as a problem because up until now the French have not wanted to see efficiencies in the industry.

I was very interested to hear Senator Woodley's comments about the wine industry. He mentioned Stanthorpe. I have a very good friend in Stanthorpe who was involved in the apple industry, not the wine industry. It is interesting that wine is being produced from as far north as Darwin in Senator Tambling's area, to Alice Springs and south of where I am in Tasmania. In fact, just the other night I was watching a program which showed wines being produced at Lake Barrington, which, as Senator Sherry would know, is our world-class rowing area. Wines are being produced even in very cold areas such as Mt Roland and Mt Barrington.

It is fair to say that all types of wines are being produced in Australia. But at the present time, not enough is being produced. The other day I attended a wine show in Canberra. Representatives of the wine industry told me that they were importing wine juice from Tasmania. Who would have thought five or 10 years ago that manufacturers such as Penfolds would be importing wine juice from Tasmania? I think that shows how big our industry is growing and how desperate the industry is for grapes.
