If there is going to be any problem for the wine industry, it will be the supply of raw materials to satisfy the world demand for Australian wines.

The most popular wine in the UK is Jacobs Creek, which sells for about #8 a bottle. Tonight we were talking about Orlando wines. The French are very quick off the mark. They realise the potential of the wine industry in Australia and it is no surprise that Pernod Richard has purchased the Orlando and Wyndham vineyards in Australia. It is no surprise that Moet et Chandon has established one of the largest sparkling wine vineyards in Tasmania because of that state's cool climate. And it is no surprise that sparkling white produced in Tasmania has won international acclaim. That is what we are talking about tonight.

I was surprised at one remark made by Senator Woodley during his contribution to this debate. The wine industry is a small industry in Tasmania and, I presume, that is also the case in Queensland. After hearing the Democrats' contribution today to the debate on the industrial relations legislation, I wonder what Senator Woodley is going to say to his winegrowers about the way his party will vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you do not understand industrial relations.
—Of course I do.
—Get back to wine.

—Of course Senator Sherry would want to get back to wine. It is a much more pleasant topic than the industrial relations legislation that the government is going to foist upon small business in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Without getting too flustered, I must say that Australian technology is leading the world. We have all heard about good vintages and bad vintages. The point is that, by using Australian technology—cooling the juice before it is fermented, cutting down the risks by being hygienic, using modern techniques with stainless steel and whatever—we never really get a bad vintage. We might get bad grapes, but we can always produce a good wine. That is why Australia is in the forefront. I take my hat off to our winegrowing industry for its wonderful innovation.

I am pleased to see that we have moved in the direction we have for international reasons. France has decided that its famous names, such as champagne and whatever, cannot be used. I do not think it matters a fig what a wine is called. It is in the drinking that counts. Australia can hold its head high in the world because of the wine we are producing. As Senator Woodley has pointed out, we will be exporting $1 billion worth of wine by the year 2000—this will occur as long as the government does not overtax the industry. Australian technology is making a marvellous contribution to the world. I fully support my colleagues who have spoken on this bill tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues have explained very clearly the Liberal and National parties' attitude to and support for the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1993. I associate myself with all of the things that have been said by my colleagues. I find it an honour in this debate to follow a connoisseur of Senator Calvert's standing. I agree with all of my colleagues that one does not really get a bad bottle of Australian wine. Personally, I drink only red wine—I have tasted quite a few over time with many of my colleagues. Australian red wine really is a pleasure to drink and is easily the best in the world.

PARA.TAB: Surprisingly enough, perhaps for the first time ever, I also agree with something Senator Woodley has said—and that, of course, is the very fulsome praise he gave to the Queensland wine industry. It is only a very young industry by wine industry standards, but it is certainly growing, carving a niche for itself in the market and will become an even better wine producing area as it goes ahead.

If that was all I intended to say, I might as well not have wasted the time of the Senate in rising to speak. But while working in my office, I heard Senator Woodley speaking. I half listened and heard this warm, fuzzy speech about Queensland and Australian wine industries and I thought, `How very nice'. Then it occurred to me—the absolute hypocrisy yet again of the arguments of the Australian Democrats.

It was not too long ago that in this chamber we spent a long time debating the sales tax on wine. Initially, the Democrats—and I suspect it was more because the state election was coming up in South Australia and they needed a few votes, and they needed them fairly desperately, as I understand, from the way the polls are going at the moment in South Australia—took this position—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Gilfillan has suggested a hundred thousand bucks, too.

—Yes, I take Senator O'Chee's interjection. We had the Democrats posturing on how they would save the Australian wine industry; they would oppose this increase to the tax on the wine industry from 20 per cent to 30 and 31 per cent. So it looked like we could defeat this iniquitous tax of the Labor Party, the big taxing party. For once we would win in the Senate. We, the majority party in the Senate, would join together with the minor parties and, with their help, would stop that very regressive and damaging tax on one of Australia's most progressive industries. So things were looking good.

PARA.TAB: But what happened? We went through the same scene that we have seen so often in this chamber where the Democrats and the Labor Party get together in a huddle. Why they do not sit together to save the carpet from all the government's walking back and forth when proposing different things to them, I do not know. But we had the government and the Democrats getting together with this new deal coming out—or supposedly it was a new deal. I suspect that the parts of this bill that are favourable to the industry were always intended to be enacted by the Labor Party in any case. But, for some reason, the Democrats rolled over yet again—yet again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industry agreed to it.

—Senator Murphy says that the industry agreed. He knows that as well as I do—I have given up on those on the other side—but what disturbs me more is that the Democrats also knew that the government was holding the wine industry to ransom. It had a gun at the head of the wine industry and the Democrats knew it. Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins, the great bullyboys of politics, knew that; they knew that the wine industry could not put up with the uncertainty. We got the same sort of calls that everyone else got: the wine industry merchants saying to us, `For goodness sake, get some certainty into this because this tax and the uncertainty over it are causing an enormous problem to our sales and our immediate revenue'.

PARA.TAB: But we had promised those in the industry all along that we would not agree to that tax because it was detrimental to that very progressive industry—and the Democrats had initially agreed with us. Then the deals were done and the Democrats again rolled over. We did not get the 31 per cent but we got a 26 per cent.

All that is now past history. But it disturbs me greatly to sit in this chamber or in my office watching the monitor and hear the sanctimonious claptrap and humbug from the Australian Democrats promoting the wine industry and pretending they are the saviours of yet another rural industry. As my colleague Senator Calvert said, how can the Australian Democrats pretend that they are the farmer's friend and the wine industry's friend when not only did they agree to that sales tax, which will have long-term repercussions on the wine industry but also, as Senator Calvert says, today they will cave in on industrial relations. See what that does to small business. See the enormous effect that will have.

If that is not bad enough, the Democrats then want to put on a jobs levy. Great, sounds beaut, a jobs levy! But who pays the jobs levy? It is little business, small business, businesses like the winegrowers of Stanthorpe. I hope, when Senator Woodley sends out his speech to the winegrowers of Stanthorpe, he will also send out mine, which will remind them of the enormous impact that his party's policies are having on them when they have to pay more for a jobs levy. That is what the Democrats want to put on the winegrowers of Stanthorpe, the winegrowers of Roma and the winegrowers of Warwick. Wherever there are winegrowers in Queensland, they will have to pay the jobs levy. Those winegrowers are now paying the increased sales tax on fuel, which I think Senator Woodley's party not only agreed to but also criticised as being too small; they wanted it to be more than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixteen cents a litre.
—Sixteen cents a litre. I thank Senator O'Chee. That was in the document which I think was called `the alternative budget'. They wanted to put it up to 16c a litre.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The accusation has been made many times by Senator Macdonald about the getting to work policy, and he misrepresents it every time.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Senator Woodley, if you have a point of order, you raise a point of order. That is not a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Woodley should know that that is not a point of order. It just indicates how sensitive the Australian Democrats are when the truth about their policies for rural Queensland becomes known. As Senator Woodley was not in the parliament then, I will send him a copy of what I think was called `the alternative budget'. Senator Kemp is the expert on this.
—I should still have one.

—Senator Panizza still has one. If I am wrong, I will apologise, but the Democrats wanted to add 15c, 16c or 17c to the price of a litre of petrol. They wanted to make petrol a dollar a litre. How would the grape growers of Stanthorpe deal with that? I think that document also suggested a wealth tax, death duties or something like that.
—Half a truth is a lie.
—That is not correct?
—An inheritance tax.
—An inheritance tax. Again, I thank Senator O'Chee. It was not death duties; it was an inheritance tax. So there is a big difference!

PARA.TAB: I do not want to take up the Senate's time any longer but, as I say, I cannot sit by and listen to the Democrats making that sort of speech—`We are the great friends of winegrowers; we are the great friends of the rural people of Queensland'—when today they are siding with the Labor Party on industrial relations policies that will ruin many small businesses, including those in rural areas. They want inheritance taxes. When they have supported the fuel tax. They supported the increase in the sales tax on wine not so long ago. All of these things have to be made known.

Whilst I appreciate that Senator Woodley is no doubt a committed Queenslander and proud of the wine industry, as we all are in Queensland, to go on with that type of speech with those sorts of claims, when all along the Australian Democrats join every time with the Australian Labor Party in doing everything they can to downgrade and put imposts and great taxes on small business—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to sit here listening to this sort of stuff day after day.

—I see that Senator Kernot has come into the chamber. Is that not great—another Queensland senator! I expect that Senator Kernot will get up and explain to the small businessmen and the winegrowers of Queensland why she agreed to increase the sales tax. Senator Kernot should not tell me she is giving them something back with this bill, because she knows better than I that what they are getting back out of this package they were going to get anyhow, but it is only a fraction of what has been taken away from them as a result of the sales tax.
—Order! The chair has been rather accommodating, but I think it might be better to talk about the bill we have in front of us.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Unfortunately, that will probably mean that Senator Kernot cannot speak after me, as no doubt you will make the same ruling when she wanders.
—I think there will be someone else in the chair by then.

—As I have said, we support this bill. I am very proud of the Queensland wine industry, but I do fear for the Queensland wine industry when it has to pay increased fuel taxes. Senator Kernot will no doubt explain to the winegrowers why her party supported those increases. The jobs levy also will impact very heavily on winegrowers in the Stanthorpe region, and no doubt Senator Kernot will explain to them how they will overcome that. No doubt she will also explain just what impact this industrial relations proposal will have on winegrowers in the Stanthorpe area. It will be interesting to see how she explains to the winegrowers just how that will benefit them. Most importantly, I wait with bated breath to hear how increasing the sales tax on wine has been good for the winegrowers of the Stanthorpe region. In conclusion, I reiterate my support for the bill and for the arguments that my colleagues raised on the bill. I wish the bill a speedy passage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In concluding this debate for the government, I would like to respond to a number of points. The government in a Christmas spirit—frankly, I think Senator Ian Macdonald might have been indulging in something more than that tonight judging by his contribution—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, in Christmas spirit, went out of its way to adjourn the industrial relations debate tonight in consideration of the fact that the amendments had not been circulated. Then Senator Ian Macdonald came in and gave us a diatribe about industrial relations tax measures but did not deal with the issues contained in this legislation which is before the Senate. No wonder we will be sitting here late at night next week when we hear contributions like that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald will have an opportunity to speak on the industrial relations legislation either later on tonight or on another day. So when he comes down here, he should take into consideration the goodwill that the government has offered in respect of the debate, and also probably the concern that some of his own colleagues have when he makes ridiculous contributions such as the one he has just made. The only successful grasp of policy that he has been able to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It was not a ridiculous contribution that Senator Ian Macdonald made. He made a very learned and considered contribution.
—What is your point of order?
—The point of order is that I think Senator Sherry has maligned my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald by saying that he did not make a good contribution to the debate.
—That is no point of order.

—I was about to make the point that the only successful grasp of policy that Senator Ian Macdonald has got across during his time in this chamber is called `How to bash the Australian Democrats'. He ought to grow up.

PARA.TAB: Let us return to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill. I want to respond to an issue that was raised by Senator Lees concerning the Geographical Indications Committee and the process that that committee will follow when determining the boundaries for names. She raised some concerns on this issue. The provisions within the legislation provide for the committee to publish some interim determinations on the boundaries issue. There will then be 28 days for people who do not agree with the determinations to complain to the committee. The committee will further consider the complaints, if there are any, and then publish its final determination. Those final determinations may be subject to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I believe that that process does cover the concerns outlined by Senator Lees.

I would like to thank the rest of the members of the opposition, with the exception of Senator Ian Macdonald, for their contribution to the debate. While their speeches did range far and wide they were generally relevant to the future of the wine industry. It was good to hear their contributions. Senator Calvert informed us about his experiences in the French wine industry and the contribution that the Australian industry is making to that industry. He quite rightly drew our attention to the fact that whilst we are leading the world in many areas of technology in the wine industry, we have to pay significant regard to the competition that we face from such countries as South Africa, New Zealand and Chile. We need to ensure that we keep that competitive edge.

Senator Calvert touched on a critical issue, not just in wine industry policy but in agricultural policy in general, when he quite rightly criticised not only the attitude of the French and the way in which they operate and control their wine industry. He quite aptly drew the Senate's attention to the fact that the winery he visited was centred in a 16th century house and a 11th century barn. That typifies the French agricultural industry and all it represents. If the French cannot modernise and adapt to modern techniques, they are about adopting high tariff walls to keep the rest of the world out, and in particular Australian producers.

This legislation, as other senators have indicated, is significant because it indicates the maturity of the Australian wine industry. It will be able to stand on its own two feet. It will be able to enter into Europe under its own name brands, which will be a very significant advance, with a minimum of bureaucratic restraint by the Europeans, and particularly the French.

A number of dates are contained in this legislation. By 31 December this year the bill provides for the phasing out of some names such as beaujolais, cava, frascati, sancerre, St Emilion and a number of others. By 31 December 1997 it provides for the phasing out of chianti, hock, madeira and malaga. If I may make a correction to a comment that I think Senator Brownhill made, there are no agreed dates to this point in time for the phasing out of the use of a number of other names such as burgundy, chablis, and champagne. We do not have agreed dates on the phase-out of those particular names.

In concluding the debate, I thank the opposition, the Democrats and, I assume, the Greens for their support. Senator Calvert pointed out that I bear the name `sherry'. It is of Spanish-Irish origin, and has its origins in the Jerez region of Spain. The only trepidation and concern I have is what will replace the name `sherry' when it is phased out sometime after 1997.

This legislation enjoys the unanimous support of the Senate. It is a hallmark of the coming of age of the Australian wine industry. It is a great industry. Whilst we might argue, depending on which particular state or region we come from, about how good our particular wine is—obviously, coming from Tasmania I have a particular view about Tasmanian wine being at least equal to the rest of the wine in Australia—there is one point of agreement that I would hope we will end on: that is, that Australian wine is the best in the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I move:

PARA.TAB: That standing order 64 be suspended to enable new business to be conducted after the question for the adjournment is first put this day.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 makes housekeeping amendments to 13 acts within the primary industries and energy portfolio. The first relates to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988. The National Registration Authority will be required to release a summary of its evaluation of a chemical product before making a determination to allow public involvement. The authority will be able to conduct public and private hearings to obtain comment on chemical products and will be required to publicise those hearings in daily newspapers throughout Australia. Such a move is important to rural Australia, particularly in light of the access our overseas competitors have to newer types of chemicals.

PARA.TAB: The authority can also seek the advice of particular organisations or persons by releasing confidential commercial information to assist in its evaluation of applications. Precautions will be taken to safeguard trade secrets and information subject to possible commercial exploitation. The authority's directors and staff are exempt from being sued for refusal to grant a clearance of a chemical product and the amendments will extend this exemption to the authority itself.

The next part of the legislation relates to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992. These amendments allow the authority to progressively determine conditions of service for staff transferred from the Public Service. Other initiatives include removing the age limit of 65 and introducing a more efficient system of issuing receipts.

I now turn to amendments to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987. The federal government wants to incorporate ecologically sustainable development principles and priorities into government decision making and administration. Such objectives mean that expertise in ecosystems management and conservation as well as economic and social factors will be essential when selecting people for research and development corporation boards. The boards will be required to consider ESD principles when determining priorities for allocation of funds. Annual reports will detail ESD related research as well as report on progress in achieving corporation objectives. Again, the maximum age for board members is removed.

Similar amendments are to be incorporated in the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984, the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987, the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

The Dairy Produce Act 1986 will also be amended. The major amendments remove uncertainty about the arrangements under which manufacturers of exported dairy products receive market support payments financed by a milk levy, that is, a levy raised by the industry on its own people on the production of all milk. This market support scheme, administered by the Australian Dairy Corporation on behalf of the Commonwealth, assists exporters to compete in world markets, some of which are highly corrupted.

It is important to note that this is not a protection scheme. There are no tariffs on dairy exports coming into Australia and there is no anti-dumping protection from New Zealand product. Under the guidelines for the payment of money from the fund, exporters must deduct the amount they import of a like product from what they export. They are then supported on the net export amount. This is to prevent dairy companies receiving market support payments on export product which would otherwise be sold on the domestic market and then importing the same type of product for domestic sale. If this arrangement is not enforceable, the Australian Dairy Corporation will be required to make back payments on the gap between net and total exports. In recent years this would have reduced the effectiveness of the scheme by some $2 million a year.

The scheme has operated since 1987 and every year since then the Australian Dairy Corporation has sent forms to all manufacturers seeking the amount of product exported and the amount imported. The market support payment has then been paid on the balance. Normally, the Dairy Corporation would have paid out on the 1991-92 year in August of this year, but has not done so because of uncertainty about the 1986 legislation. This amendment removes the uncertainty and allows the corporation to apply the arrangement from 1991-92 and 1992-93 until the scheme ceases in 1999. The Australian Dairy Industry Council, the policy body which represents dairy farmers and manufacturers, and the Australian Dairy Products Federation, which represents manufacturers, both support these changes.

I now turn to the Fisheries Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Act 1991. When the 1991 fisheries legislation was passed, it was anticipated that arrangements with the states and the Northern Territory on the offshore constitutional settlement would be completed by 3 February 1994. The timetable has been delayed, so a further 12 months will be granted.

The Fisheries Management Act 1991 is to be amended to reflect the original intention that seasonal and other closures may be authorised under a management plan. Basically, the amendments allow greater flexibility and will permit a fisherman to hold a number of statutory fishing rights as a discrete package of rights authorising a particular fishing activity. An example might be a combination of quotas to take various species of fish or specified combinations of fishing gear or boat characteristics, such as size of engines and characteristics of nets.

The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 will be amended in a way consequential to the establishment of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation. They reflect a changed funding arrangement, with the Commonwealth providing $1 for every $2 spent by industry, rather than dollar for dollar with the other rural industries. This is because half of the forest and wood industry is deemed to be a manufacturing industry rather than a primary industry. The amendments propose that moneys raised from charges under the Forest Industry Research Import Charge Act 1993 be directed to research and development relevant to the timber importing industry. Amendments to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 will allow for the collection of the levies.

Finally, amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 will correct an anomaly in the act. The aim is to provide the constitutional power for the states to allow the Wheat Board to conduct intrastate trade in grain and grain products. While the states have passed legislation to allow the Wheat Board to trade intrastate in grain and grain products, there is doubt as to whether Commonwealth legislation gives this power for grains other than wheat. In order to validate the board's operations, these amendments will operate retrospectively. Other amendments will allow the board more flexibility in pool return payments to allow adjustments for variety, quality, transport, storage and handling costs, et cetera, to ensure that growers within the pool are treated fairly. The federal coalition will not stand in the way of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that it is almost 20 past 10 and that the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill proceeded to the second reading stage after 10 o'clock this evening. That is frequently the case with primary industry legislation. We on this side of the chamber have become used to that sort of thing. It is quite a shame that the decisions that were made by both parties in relation to this bill were made some months ago and that the bill has been held up and seems to have been considered unimportant.

PARA.TAB: I know that the government understands that we are not opposing the bill, but I think that, perhaps in the scheduling of the legislation for consideration by this Senate chamber, we should not, as a matter of routine, get into the habit of scheduling primary industry legislation for the end of the session in the belief that nobody cares about it. Primary industry legislation is very important.

These amendments are not just inconsequential amendments to the people who are affected by them. They are important amendments. In a number of cases—I wish to discuss some of those cases—they cause a certain degree of heartache. It is not satisfactory for this parliament to say, `Because it is primary industry legislation, we will slot it in at the end of the session. It doesn't matter when it gets passed; it doesn't matter when it takes effect'. These matters have to be dealt with more expeditiously. The Senate ought to have that in mind when it looks at the legislative program during the next session.

Senator Tambling has very adequately laid out on behalf of the coalition—both the National Party and the Liberal Party—our attitude to each of the amendments to the legislation. I support Senator Tambling in saying that we will not oppose them. I wish to address three principal matters. The first relates to the amendments made in relation to the market support payments for the export of dairy produce. The coalition supports those amendments. This caused a lot of heartache in my area of North Queensland. I want to make a few comments so that people understand the basis on which the coalition is making this decision to support this part of the bill, lest there be any misunderstanding. I make these comments as somebody who worked almost non-stop for two days on the particular concerns of the Atherton Tableland Cooperative Dairy Corporation. The amendments in relation to the market support payments, which are funded out of the all milk levy, were aimed principally at that dairy cooperative. I do not want anybody to think that the coalition disregarded the concerns of the people at Malanda, because that is certainly not the case.

The problem with the market support payment arose because the legislation was defective in the first place. The legislation had a hole in it. The dairy cooperative in question took the view that it would utilise those provisions to claim all of the market support payment for the gross amount that it exported, not the net amount when account is taken of the countervailing imports. As a result, it has been in dispute in relation to the amount of market support payment to which it is entitled. This bill deals with that and eliminates the problem.

If the legislation had been dealt with in the proper fashion in the first place, it would not have been necessary to make this amendment. The amendment was made several years after the defect in the legislation became apparent. At the time it was dealt with by means of a number of guidelines that were issued annually. The then minister for primary industries should have had the legislation rectified at that point. That would have eliminated any possibility of people getting false expectations.

The basis on which those of us in the coalition support this bill—we are unanimously supporting this; every single member of the National and Liberal parties is supporting it—is that at the end of the day the Australian dairy industry said to us that this bill had to pass. I remember distinctly discussing it on the telephone with Mr Pat Rowley, the head of the dairy industry in this country. He said, `Irrespective of the concerns that individuals may have, we do have to get this rectified and the dairy industry as a whole is of the view that this amendment should be allowed to pass, notwithstanding the fact that there made be particular local concerns'.

When I look at my responsibilities as a senator—one who lives in Cairns and who is very close to the producers who make up the Atherton Tableland Cooperative Dairy Corporation—it is incumbent on me to look at the big picture; to look at my responsibilities to the local producers but also to recognise that I have responsibilities to every other dairy farmer in the state of Queensland and every other dairy cooperative, and there are many others. I think that those obligations, particularly in view of the comments that have been made by the head of the dairy industry in Australia—who is a Queenslander—force me to support this amendment contained in this bill.

As I said, the support for that amendment is unanimous in the coalition. I wanted to make that particular comment in relation to that amendment, lest anybody thought there was any division in the coalition or lest anybody misconstrued the basis upon which we support the amendment. We believe that in primary industry matters it is best if the industry can work as a whole, move as a whole and speak as a whole. That has been the great strength of Australian primary industries over a long period—that primary industry generally and primary producers individually have recognised the need at times to accommodate the rest of the industry so that we as a whole in Australia can work together to maximise our opportunities.

As I said, these amendments have caused a certain degree of heartache. At the end of the day, the particular primary producers in question on the Atherton Tableland will become even better exporters than they are at the moment. They will overcome any particular problems that may arise from this bill. They have already made substantial headway in terms of exporting to markets in South-East Asia and I am sure they will continue to do that. That is the basis upon which the coalition supports the measure. As I said, our support is unanimous.

I move to two other amendments that are made in this bill. The first is the consequential amendments to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act to permit the collection of charges which follow changes made by this parliament earlier to the forest industry research levy. As I said before, it is important that we have a degree of research into the forest industries in this country so that we can maximise the opportunities for a sustainable resource. One of the concerns that I have is that, when we get this sort of legislation and these consequential amendments are held up for long periods, it raises doubts about the government's commitment to following it through. There is always a concern on the part of those who are affected that until all of the legislation gets through they really cannot count on anything. Everybody in the chamber would have to recognise that.

When we get amendments like this which are designed to support other changes in government policy that have been made, the amendments should be made expeditiously. The enabling legislation should not be delayed. Whilst we in this parliament say, `We passed legislation to give effect to this forest industry research levy', out there in the community where the people are affected they say, `Until the legislation gets through, it doesn't matter whether you have made the in-principle decision; unless the mechanics are in place, we cannot take benefit from it'. We have to improve our act in that respect.

Finally, I support the changes that we are making to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act. One of the difficulties for Australian primary industry is that chemicals have been very expensive in this country and remain very expensive compared to our neighbours overseas. Nothing in this bill will change the cost of chemicals. It will improve access to chemicals and it will therefore assist in the development of better agricultural practices.

Too many times we have heard primary industry saying, `We can do a better job, but we need to have access to the latest technology'—not that I am saying that primary industry is not doing a good job at the moment. Perhaps 20 or 30 years ago the attitude of some primary producers was different. It was, `Look, we will continue going in the fashion in which we have gone before'. Now the attitude of primary producers is very simple: `We want to be on the cutting edge of technology and on the cutting edge of changes in agriculture so that we can get a better return for ourselves and for the country'.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! it being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, primary industry wants to be on the cutting edge of technology. It wants to be able to improve yields as much as possible, and that requires the ability to source chemicals as soon as they are available, or as soon as practical after they are available—after they have been tested and examined. This will make that possible.

PARA.TAB: However, the government has to address the main problem, which is why chemicals are so expensive in this country compared with the cost of chemicals in other countries. When we consider the cost of a drum of `Round Up' or any of the other commonly used chemicals in Australia, Australian primary producers have the raw end of the deal because they are being asked to pay so much more. They do not get the subsidies that apply in other countries. As a consequence, primary producers are faced with two options: either they have to fork out large amounts of money for chemicals and therefore suffer a disadvantage in terms of the cost of production, or they have to be willing to forgo those chemicals and suffer lower yields, and I do not think that is satisfactory.

We support this measure, but the government should be placed on notice that there is much more that needs to be done. Accordingly, I would hope, as many primary producers around this country would hope, that the government will get its act together in terms of the cost of the chemicals and solve that problem as well.

TALK.START.PARA: The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 is an omnibus bill amending a total of something like 13 different acts. I wish to make a few comments on the amendments relating to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987, the Dairy Produce Act 1986, and the Wheat Marketing Act 1989. Other sections of this bill, in our opinion, are not contentious, and I will not comment on these sections.

PARA.TAB: The bill proposes to amend the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 to remove the 65-year age limit on both the managing director and members of the corporation, as well as on members of the corporation selection committee. It has been part of the Australian Democrats employment policy for many years to remove any age discrimination and to ensure against the compulsory retirement of persons because of their age. As such, the Democrats support this amendment.

The first amendment to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 is non-contentious in that it simply provides the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) with the power to release funds from the dairy industry fund to be used to cover the cost of hosting the International Dairy Federation's world congress in Australia next year. I am informed that there has been an agreement between the government and the industry for some time now that this money would be made available and, indeed, it is expected that the money released from the fund will be recouped from income gained through the congress.

A second amendment to the Dairy Produce Act seeks to clarify the legislative framework under which the import offset arrangement of the Australian Dairy Corporation operates. At present, the ADC provides market support payments to manufacturers of exported dairy products. These payments are financed by a levy on all milk production and are designed to make returns to Australian manufacturers from exporting somewhat greater in the face of large government subsidies by other countries. This has the dual benefit of increasing our exports and reducing the amount of dairy product that is available on our domestic market.

As honourable senators will be aware, since 1987 the corporation has operated an import offset arrangement to ensure that these market support payments are reduced when a firm imports and exports the same type of product. This arrangement is designed to prevent companies from receiving a market support payment on an exported product, then importing the same product for sale on the domestic market.

In the recent past there has been some dispute over the operation of this arrangement, and there have been some allegations of abuse of the scheme. This bill seeks to close off that possibility by ensuring that market support payments are reduced by the amount payable on dairy produce of the same kind which has been imported by the manufacturer.

Because of the uncertainty surrounding payments to be made under the offset scheme, the ADC has not sought offset payments since 1991-92 until there is some clarification of the legislation. These amendments provide that clarification and will allow the ADC to apply the arrangements to payments going back to 1 July 1991. There is a certain retrospective aspect to the amendment. However, I think we all accept that this situation needs to be addressed—at least I believe that that is what Senator O'Chee was saying—and that these amendments are the best way to achieve this. The Democrats therefore support the amendments.

Finally, amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act are also non-contentious. As the minister said in his second reading speech, firstly, they will ensure the constitutional power of the states to confer functions and powers on the Australian Wheat Board to allow it to conduct intrastate trade in grain and grain products. Secondly, they will allow the AWB to conduct research into grain and grain products. We certainly support further research in the primary industry area and would want to see further funds allocated for this purpose in the next budget. Thirdly, they will allow the chairperson or the managing director to delegate their powers to an employee of the AWB. Therefore, these amendments are supported by the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: I rise to support the remarks made by my colleagues Senator Tambling and Senator O'Chee in relation to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill and to indicate my support for the bill. I will confine my remarks to the amendments to the Dairy Produce Act.

PARA.TAB: My concern about amendments to the Dairy Produce Act were first aroused by a report from the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee with regard to a suggested retrospective element of the bill. At about the same time as the Senate committee report came out I, as well as most other Queensland senators, was contacted by the Atherton Tableland Cooperative Dairy Association—a very good and progressive business operating in the Atherton Tableland of North Queensland.

I was concerned by the matters raised with me and the matters raised by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I discussed this matter at some length with Senator Tambling who was in charge of it and he very kindly arranged, in conjunction with Senator Sherry, for briefings in relation to these matters. We had quite a number of meetings with departmental officials in Senator Sherry's office. I acknowledge the cooperation of Senator Sherry and his officers and the departmental officials in relation to the matter. The coalition has taken a unanimous view on the whole bill and I understand that, in respect of the broader industry, it was essential that support be given to this bill.

It was a disappointment to me that something could not be done to assist the Atherton Tablelands cooperative in the dilemma in which it found itself. But in spite of our discussions with the department and Senator Sherry's office, there appeared to be no way that its particular situation could be properly addressed. I do not want to go into the details about it at this hour of the night. Suffice it to say that I did have some concern.

Senator Sherry and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy should in the future be very careful about any possible retrospective elements in the legislation they bring forward—matters which could act to people's detriment after they have acted on the basis of legislation that was then in force. As I say, I do not want to go into the details at any great length at this time. I simply wish to conclude by indicating again my support for the approach adopted by the Liberal and National parties which was so well put by my colleague Senator Tambling.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I only wish to respond very briefly. I acknowledge and thank the opposition, particularly Senator Tambling, and Senator Woodley from the Australian Democrats. I acknowledge the suggestion of Senator Ian Macdonald. In fact, I understand that he initially raised these concerns in our Thursday lunchtime debate when I was in the chamber.
—It was on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report.
—I am aware of that. I know the Department of Primary Industries and Energy conducted some extensive briefs. I understand Senator Macdonald's concerns and his position on that matter.

PARA.TAB: I want to comment on only one other matter. Senator O'Chee referred to the hold-up of this omnibus legislation. I have my own concerns about hold-ups of legislation. Three or four weeks ago we were on the brink of dealing with this package, but unfortunately other matters came on and we did not get to deal with it. That is as frustrating for me in handling this legislation as it is for the opposition. It is not meant to reflect on any low priority given to primary industries and energy legislation; it was simply a matter of the other legislation carrying higher priority. I thank the Senate for its cooperation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993DIESEL FUEL (EXCISE DUTY REBATE) ADMINISTRATION CHARGE BILL 1993DIESEL FUEL (CUSTOMS DUTY REBATE) ADMINISTRATION CHARGE BILL 1993EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Collins:
That the bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the government's attempt to impose an administration fee on the diesel fuel rebate scheme through this package of customs and excise bills. Under this scheme, off-road users of diesel fuel, such as miners, primary producers, hospitals, and nursing homes in some cases, receive a full or partial rebate of the excise they pay on diesel fuel because diesel fuel excise is supposed to be collected specifically for the purpose of road funding and maintenance.

PARA.TAB: It has long been recognised that, for example, nursing homes using diesel fuel for heating should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance; and farmers using diesel fuel in farm machinery which never travels on our roads should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance. Therefore, they can claim a rebate for some or all of the excise they pay.

As I have outlined several times in this chamber, it has now been established during the Senate estimates process that this administration fee is not a true user pays fee which reflects only the administrative costs of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Instead, it is a tax which has been introduced into this chamber in two bills: the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993.

This tax will equal one per cent of the total amount rebated to miners, farmers, hospitals and other off-road users. In 1993-94, the total amount to be rebated is estimated to be about $1 billion. Therefore, this new tax will equal about $10 million a year in income to the government.

These rebates are paid mainly to the mining industry and the primary industries sector; 54 per cent of total rebates paid go to the mining sector and 44 per cent go to the rural sector. By introducing a tax of one per cent, the government will effectively be reducing the rebate to miners and farmers by one per cent. For instance, farmers who are entitled to a full 100 per cent rebate will effectively only get 99 per cent of it. This is a sneaky, back-door way of reducing the rebate. It is something that the government well knows that the rural and mining sectors are completely opposed to.

Diesel fuel excise is collected to contribute to road maintenance. People in businesses which use diesel fuel for off-road purposes such as running farm machinery, mining equipment and heaters in hospitals should not have to pay the excise or contribute to road maintenance.

However, this is not the only reason the tax should be rejected. Just as importantly, it is completely wrong to set a precedent where people pay a tax to get a rebate. Imagine what would happen if people were charged a one per cent tax on their personal income tax rebates. First they pay thousands of dollars a year in income tax and at the end of the financial year, if they work out that they have paid too much income tax, the tax office owes them a refund, but the tax office says, `If you want to get your refund, you have to pay another tax to get it back.'. Quite frankly, I cannot imagine that the tax office is too enamoured of the concept of people paying taxes to get their rebates. Imagine how popular it would be if it started charging taxes on all the other refunds that it hands back to people. In fact, I have heard along the grapevine that the tax office is opposed to this one per cent tax on the diesel fuel rebate scheme for precisely the reasons I have outlined.

I believe that the introduction of this tax would take the user pays principle too far. If the government owes a person or a business a refund because too much tax has been paid in the first place, a further tax should not under any circumstances be deducted from that refund. It is not the fault of the miners, the farmers, the nursing homes and the hospitals that they have to pay the diesel fuel excise when they buy their diesel. It is not by choice that these people pay too much for diesel and then have to seek a refund.

Surely it is manifestly evident that they are only claiming a rebate of moneys they should not have paid to the government in the first place. Speaking on behalf of primary producers who are entitled to a 100 per cent rebate, I am sure they would all prefer to return to the system where they quoted their exemption certificate number and simply did not pay the excise in the first place. After all, this is a system that currently applies to sales tax. If it is good enough for sales tax, I am not sure why it is not good enough for diesel excise. Then the inland revenue division of customs would have far less work to do because farmers who make 44 per cent of all the claims for diesel fuel rebates would not have to make claims any more. I guess that there are people in customs who would not want to be talking themselves out of jobs.

The other strong argument against this tax is that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), through Senator McMullan, admitted on 30 September, in an answer to my question without notice, that the amount of tax paid will be deductible for income tax purposes to the extent that the tax is paid on diesel fuel used for producing assessable income. In other words, primary producers can claim a tax deduction for this one per cent tax. If we were just looking at farmers and primary producers who claim 44 per cent of the refund, even if only half of them pay tax—and in today's climate it is quite possible that only half of them do—and can claim a deduction, this would amount to a collective tax deduction of some $2.2 million. That is not counting the deductions claimed by mining companies, nursing homes, private hospitals and other users of off-road diesel. It does not make sense.

Does the government really want the Australian Customs Service to go to all the trouble of collecting the $10 million in tax on diesel fuel rebates off road users, only for a significant proportion of it to be claimed as a legitimate tax deduction? How much paperwork, time and extra effort is wasted on this?

TALK.START.PARA: —One per cent is only the thin edge of the wedge.

—I agree with Senator Boswell that it is only the thin edge of the wedge, but it is the start and it is the principle that counts. How much paperwork and time and effort would be wasted on administering this rebate? I wonder whether the tax office thinks it is worth it. I do not think that it would be too happy with the idea nor do I think the Australian taxpayers would be too happy with the idea.

PARA.TAB: After all, we are not talking about a true user-pays charge. Despite what has been said—and will be said—in the Senate estimates process, this tax is not a user-pays charge or fee or any other name the government uses to avoid using the word tax. If it were a user-pays charge, as the government claims, it would not have to be introduced as a tax. It is as simple as that. If the government thought it could get away with introducing this as a charge or fee, it would.

TALK.START.PARA: —It tried that.

—It tried that and it was found out. I am sure that is what the government tried to do. Perhaps unluckily for the government the Australian Customs Service realised that this one per cent fee is a tax. As everybody knows, the real difference between a tax and a fee is that an administration fee recovers actual administration costs, whereas a tax does not have to bear any relationship to those administration costs, either because the tax is more than the cost or because it is set as a percentage and cannot move to reflect the actual cost.

PARA.TAB: As honourable senators may be aware, right from the beginning, when I read about this so-called administration fee in the 1993-94 budget papers, I suspected that it did not relate to the actual costs of administration and therefore it was unconstitutional. I asked questions in the estimates committee hearings on 26 August, 2 September and 4 November on this basis. I also asked two questions without notice on this issue, on 31 August and 29 September. All of these questions were designed not only to ascertain whether this fee was really a tax, but also to discover when exactly it was decided to introduce this tax.

During all the questioning that took place on this issue, including when Estimates Committee E was especially reopened on 2 September so Senator Schacht could correct some answers he had given at the initial hearing on 31 August, the government tried to justify charging a $10 million administration fee. It is funny how the government can reopen an estimates committee when it wants to, when one of its ministers gives some incorrect information to the committee that he wants to correct, but when the opposition wants that same committee reopened to examine an issue like sports rorts, that is not possible. I digress.

This administration fee, which Senator Schacht repeatedly argued was a true user-pays fee, included one-off and establishment items like plant and equipment, furniture and fittings, personal computers and uniforms. Even if these items could be included in the first year, once they have been paid for by the users of this diesel fuel, what happens the second year the tax is charged? I noticed there was no suggestion from the government that the fee be reduced in the second year. Presumably, then, the miners and farmers keep paying customs for these one-off costs, which is a very nice little windfall for the government.

I also note with some astonishment that performance based pay is included as one of the administration costs of the rebate scheme. Being an ex-farmer, I think every Australian farmer would be absolutely horrified—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ex-farmer!
—Yes, an ex-farmer, Senator Burns.
—You don't have a property anymore?
—It does not matter whether anyone is earning an income off a farm. I am not. Being an ex-farmer, I think that every Australian farmer would be sickened to think—
—You are still a farmer.
—Senator Burns cannot understand a simple answer. He wants a simple answer.
—You are still a farmer.

—I will debate that with Senator Burns at a later stage. Every Australian farmer would be sickened to think that public servants earning more than $43,000 a year not only get several thousand dollars a year in performance based pay but that farmers have to cover this cost through their one per cent tax.

PARA.TAB: If anyone deserves performance based pay it is our farmers and miners. In particular, I refer to some farmers who work incredibly long hours in very trying conditions for very little or no reward. How can the government justify to these farmers earning negative incomes and who are struggling to pay for food and clothes for their children that they should pay the performance based bonuses of staff in the Australian Customs Service?

How moral is that? Personally, I would like to send someone from Customs out to the Eyre Peninsula or to far west Queensland—which Senator Burns ought to know something about—or to Western Australia where my colleagues Senator Panizza and Senator Crane come from, or any area affected by drought, and explain to farmers who are just about to lose their farms why farmers have to pay for performance based bonuses for Customs officers who would earn what would seem like an absolute fortune to farming families. I would be very interested to hear what the Democrats and the Green senators have to say. I would also like to hear what some Labor senators might have to say about this because there is no social justice in some of Australia's poorest families having to pay a user-pays fee which goes towards performance based pay for highly paid bureaucrats.

As Mr Prosser, one of my colleagues in the other house, pointed out, the government does not have a mandate to introduce this tax. It was not mentioned in the One Nation statement and the Treasurer did not mention it in his budget speech. The only mention came in the budget papers which obliquely referred to an administration fee as such. No mention was made that it was not related to the actual cost of administering the scheme. There was no mention that, because of this, it will have to be introduced as a tax. There was no mention that this could be the thin end of the wedge providing an easy means whereby the rebate can gradually be eroded to nothing or the percentage increased.

In one breath the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is saying that we will help business and we must improve exports while, on the other hand, he wants to collect more tax from those sectors which cannot afford it. I would like the Prime Minister or the Treasurer to explain how charging a tax on the diesel excise rebate will help farmers or miners or any other businesses to become more competitive. Of course, it cannot explain it because taxes are a cost not a boost to business.

My guess is that the government thought it could sneak this one through without much protest and without much media attention because after all it is only the miners and farmers and very few others who are getting upset about it. They are upset about it, and I have 2,000 signatures from South Australia to prove it. I also have a letter from the South East Local Government Association which relates to the diesel fuel rebate tax. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to your recent media release dated 25 November, concerning diesel fuel rebate tax which proved to be the subject of considerable discussion at a recent meeting of the South East Local Government Association.

The meeting wholeheartedly supported your opposition to the proposal which is considered to be a further unfair impost on those that currently cannot afford such a tax, particularly in the rural areas.

I would therefore be pleased if you would lodge the strongest possible objection to the proposal in the Senate, on behalf of Local Government Authorities and the Communities that they represent in this region.

In closing, I welcome the decision of the Democrats; I understand that the Democrats will be supporting our decision to oppose this tax. It is the only logical decision they could have arrived at. To support this tax is to harm our rural and mining sectors and give the government a mandate to deduct taxes from rebates.

PARA.TAB: I would certainly welcome the attendance of the Democrats at estimates committee hearings such as this where a lot of these departments can be questioned and some of these things can be brought to light which otherwise may not have been. To the best of my knowledge, not one Democrat senator attended any of the estimates committee hearings that I attended. This tax must be rejected, not only because of the burden it places on two of our most productive sectors but also because the principle of taxing rebates is anathemaand should be rejected on behalf of the Australian people as immoral.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly to pick up some of the remarks that Senator Ferguson has already made, and I thank him for recognising the sanity and logic of the Australian Democrats. We are always very sane and very logical.
—You are a bit slow to come to it sometimes.
—No. In fact, we announced quite early that this was our position.
—I thought I saw an announcement of Senator Woodley's only a week or two ago.

—Well, Senator Ferguson did not pick up some of our earlier announcements then. That is his fault, not ours. The situation is quite simply that one has in place a diesel rebate scheme which, I would agree with Senator Ferguson, would be much easier if, like sales tax, one did not pay the amount rebated in the first place.

PARA.TAB: I recall that a few years ago when I had a small farm that was exactly the situation. I had a certificate of which I quoted a number when I got my diesel for the tractor and that was it. The government has seen fit to operate a complex scheme—and, if this bill were passed, it would become even more complex—in which the tax would be paid, a rebate would be paid back, a charge would then be levied on the rebate and then the farmer could further claim that as a tax deduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like ping-pong.

—It is really like ping-pong, as Senator Boswell has said. It really is a crazy scheme with money passing back and forth about four times. The other quite iniquitous and quite dangerous thing about this is the precedent it creates. I believe that, once this principle were to be adopted, one might well see charges made by the tax office for normal income tax refunds and that sort of thing.

PARA.TAB: So we are opposed to this proposal to impose the rebate charge. It is something which should not be imposed and the mechanism, if anything, should be simplified rather than made more complex. While the amounts are not extremely large at this stage, we accept the argument that it may well be the thin end of the wedge. The amounts could easily be increased. The way in which the charge is made up could be disguised quite easily, false claims could be made for excessive charges and it could simply become a revenue raiser. But even though the amount over the whole community at this time might not be large, it is still a very considerable impost for particular individuals. So we will be opposing that.

One of our other concerns—and something that I mentioned before in debate on various aspects of this budget—is that we want to press the government very strongly toward implementing a scheme in which the fuel price paid by country people is no more than the fuel price paid by city people. I think in Canberra just in recent days one has seen the introduction of price wars which certainly will not be extended to country areas. We will see a continuation of a very substantial differential in the price paid by country people—and we are now talking about on-road use of both petrol and diesel. In our view that, in itself, is also iniquitous.

The inquiries which we understand are under way should lead to, and we will press for, the imposition of legislation which will guarantee to country people that they will not be paying a higher price for their fuel than city people because it is quite unfair and particularly hard on country people at this time when so many rural prices are so low. So we want to take this opportunity to repeat that undertaking to country people. That is our intention; that is what we will be pressing for. We know that the National Party and the opposition are also keen on that course of events.

My colleague Senator Woodley will be speaking on one other aspect of these two bills in relation to the diesel fuel customs duty rebate administration charge. I will leave him to deal with those other aspects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the collection of customs bills. I apologise for the fact that I have not had the opportunity to speak with Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats, the Greens or Senator Harradine on the amendments due to the kafuffles of arrangements that have been going on tonight. It just was not possible, but we will not be proceeding with this legislation beyond the second reading stage and I can discuss the amendments with them as necessary. But I apologise for my inability to observe the usual niceties of the situation.

PARA.TAB: The bills cover a combination of housekeeping matters and a couple of other substantial issues as well, as announced in the budget. Of the former, an important amendment concerns blended petroleum and crude oil products. At present, such blending takes place on licensed premises under customs control. The duty is paid on the full blend at a rate equal to either the diesel or the leaded petrol rate. The customs department is aware of blending that goes on by unlicensed operators such as service stations. They do not operate at the normal recognised standard, there is a level of safety risk and illegal blending leads to a loss of excise revenue as well.

The amendment that is being put forward requires that all blending occur on licensed premises; hence duty will be paid on the full value of blended substance at diesel or leaded petrol rate. The coalition supports this amendment as a necessary development, but there is an area where further clarification is necessary, and that is the responsibility question in relation to fuels that are blended—whether this falls back to the oil companies directly, the distributor, the service station proprietors or people even further on. It does not appear clear as to where the liability for this still rests. That will need to be tidied up.

The other adjustment to this legislation concerns the shale mined in Australia. One amendment removes the outdated provision giving gasoline and mineral turpentine produced from shale mined in Australia an exemption from duty. This was a World War II measure which is long since redundant. No shale is mined for gasoline, nor is any derivative produced from it in Australia today.

The other amendment involving shale oil is a new measure. It is designed to assist a joint venture planning to mine shale and produce naphtha in Gladstone, and it is based on new Canadian technology. It is a research and development project and, given the huge quantities of shale oil reserves that are known to exist in Australia, it does merit support.

To encourage this venture, the government has agreed to pay amounts in respect of the shale oil produced. This is based on the excise duty payable on the amount of unleaded petrol that can be obtained from the shale oil. Payments would be in the form of a bounty upon the production of naphtha from shale mined. This is not expected to have any financial impact before about 1996-97 and will terminate in 2005. The aim is that the payments be limited to 600,000 barrels of unleaded gasoline per year. The coalition supports these amendments relating to the shale oil.

The two issues in the legislation which concern the coalition relate to the diesel fuel rebate scheme and to micro-breweries. The amendment to the diesel fuel rebate scheme requires claims for diesel fuel rebate to be lodged within three years of purchase of the diesel fuel, introduces a new formula for indexation of the rebate and introduces an administrative charge for processing rebate applications—a charge of one per cent of the value of the rebate payable.

The rebate scheme commenced in 1982. Prior to that, all off-road users of diesel fuel could hold certificates of exemption from payment of excise on diesel fuel. There was no need for users to pay excise and then seek a rebate. The Commonwealth collected $2.65 billion in excise on diesel fuel in 1992-93 and estimates that it will collect $3.1 billion this financial year. Nearly $1 billion is expected to be rebated in 1993-94. The purpose of the rebate scheme and the prior exemption arrangement was to remove wholly, or largely, the requirement on off-road users such as primary producers, miners and certain other claimants—hospitals, nursing homes, residential and aged persons homes, et cetera—to pay the excise duty.

The aim of fully rebating duty for primary industry was a recognition of the need to avoid unnecessary costs on an efficient export oriented industry. Nobody on this side of the Senate can understand why the government sees fit now to try to slug yet again an industry that is not only export oriented but struggling for its very survival. The reason may be perfectly clear to somebody on the other side. If it is, I would like that person to explain it.

These new proposals are quite inconsistent with the intention of the scheme. They are clearly a new tax on these industries and organisations. While the requirement to lodge claims within three years will not affect most claimants, it could cause hardship in those cases where, for genuine reasons, claims are not or cannot be made within this time limit. No scope will exist for the minister to grant claims, even in those situations where he considers that the representations before him merit such action. It is an over-bureaucratic approach—an approach which, incidentally, the government considers will result in worthwhile savings.

The annual adjustment of rebate rates to reflect indexation, replacing the current six months moving average, will likewise disadvantage the rebate participants. Together with the proposal to limit the period of rebate applications to three years, the saving to the government—in other words, the loss to the recipients—is expected to be $3.9 million in 1993-94, $15.8 million in 1994-95 and $16.9 million in 1995-96. These are in addition to the savings, or the losses to the recipients, involved in the administration fee.

The proposal for an administration fee is quite outrageous. Apart from being inconsistent with the whole concept of the rebate scheme, it is a tax for which the government has no mandate. It is simply another unnecessary cost on business and another obstacle to higher employment levels. It is anomalous in that the business which will pay this one per cent administration fee receives an exemption for sales tax on business inputs without having to pay an administration fee. Will such a fee for sales tax be the next tax on business? It certainly opens the door for a new tax regime.

The amount collected by this fee will be around $10 million but, according to Senate Estimates Committee E, the scheme costs around $6 million to administer. If that turns out to be the case, it will be a ridiculous tax and certainly not worth the trouble that is involved, nor the cost that will be borne by the productive sector. Also, the imposition of a fee places no onus on the Australian Customs Service to improve its efficiency and to contain its costs. Quite clearly, all three measures in this legislation relating to the diesel fuel rebate scheme are inconsistent with the policy involved in the scheme, damaging to industry and grossly unfair to the others affected. They are, therefore, opposed by the coalition.

The remaining proposal of concern to the coalition in this legislation relates to micro-breweries or brew-on-premises shops. These shops provide a service to do-it-yourself home brewers. Customers purchase the ingredients, which are subject to sales tax, choose a recipe, rent the equipment and then make their own beer. Customers mix the ingredients, leave it for two weeks, come back and bottle the beer and take it home. This hobby-style activity was developed in Canada where, incidentally, brewing beer at home is not permitted. In Australia it is likely that much of the support for these shops will come from the home brewers, who in many cases are lower income earners and migrants.

The coalition does not believe that there are any grounds yet for distinguishing between beer brewed at home and beer produced at BOP shops. Nevertheless, the government has announced in the budget that BOP shops must be licensed and that the beer produced on their premises be subject to the payment of excise. It is likely that this action will kill these fledgling small businesses and that customers will simply brew their beer at home, as usual.

The government does not have a mandate for this tax. It was not hinted at during the election campaign. In October 1992, the Australian Customs Service informed BOP shops that it did not have any plans to impose excise on beer brewed in their shops. This tax is heavy-handed and unnecessary. It is opposed by the opposition. I move the following amendment to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993:
At the end of the motion, add:

", but the Senate while acknowledging the merit of the proposals the bill contains in relation to blended petroleum products and to naphtha producers, calls on the Government to abandon the iniquitous and unreasonable proposals which will curtail the diesel fuel rebate scheme and impose duties on beer brewed in micro-breweries".

SPEECH.PARA: I also move the following amendment to the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No.2) 1993:

PARA.TAB: At the end of the motion, add:

", but the Senate while acknowledging the worthwhile measures the bill contains in relation to blended petroleum products and gasoline and turpentine produced from shale, calls on the Government to abandon its ill conceived plans to impose duties on beer brewed in micro-breweries".

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address briefly the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No.2) 1993. This bill works in conjunction with the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 to effect amendments to the excise payable on the following products: firstly, the beer produced in brew-on-premises shops; secondly, blended petroleum products; and, thirdly, gasoline and mineral turpentine produced from oil shale mined in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Clause 6(a) of this bill redefines the definition of beer in order to catch beer produced using commercial facilities and equipment—that is, beer produced in brew-on-premises shops. In these shops, the customer arrives, buys the products, mixes the brew in kettles and equipment provided by the shop, and goes away. The proprietors of the shop store the beer and stir it possibly once during the intervening two weeks. The customer comes back, bottles the beer and walks away with it.

In regard to the definition of this process, the Australian Customs Service advised the entrepreneurs intent on establishing such shops, which are similar to shops established in Canada, that no excise would be payable. However, the government has now decided that the process that has been observed in Canada, where up to almost four per cent of beer produced is actually brewed in these shops, will in years to come heavily detract from the revenue.

While we share the government's concern about the loss of revenue from beer produced in these shops, we also are concerned about the fact that these people were advised by the government that, as long as they followed the formula that they had placed before customs, they would not be subject to excise. I believe that people in that position are entitled to rely on the government's undertaking and should not now be put out of business.

The government's amendments to this particular bill would ensure that beer produced in these brew-on-premises shops would attract the same excise as beer produced in large breweries. The imposition of the full excise and the flow-on taxes, the wholesale sales tax and state licence fees, would add $12.49 to the current shop price of $16 for 24 stubbies, amounting to $28.49. This compares with a price of $22 for 24 stubbies, purchased in a liquor shop, of beer brewed by breweries. Very clearly, the government's action would put these shops out of business after they have established their businesses relying on the government's undertaking.

At the same time, however, the Democrats are concerned about the possible drain to revenue and I foreshadow an amendment which proposes to apply excise at the rate of 15 per cent of that which would be applicable under the government's amendments. This rate has been calculated to enable brew-on-premises shops to offer a viable alternative to commercial beer at approximately the same cost that is now available in liquor shops. In effect, it would be a shot across the bows of these shops to indicate that the government and, I confirm, the Democrats would be concerned about the drain to revenue amounting to millions of dollars, some $30 million or so, if the brew-on-premises industry advances in the same way as the one in Canada did.

We believe that this is not sound public policy. There are other areas that we need to be concerned about and they are that the age limit in these shops is clearly enforced, that people under 18 are not admitted and also that health regulations are observed. We believe that these shops should be licensed under state law. Clearly, the main strategy to contain the growth of this particular industry in the way in which it has happened in Canada, and the resulting drain on government revenue, is in the level of excise which would be levied; hence, the amendment I foreshadow.

The bill also deals with blended petroleum products. Clause 5 of the bill stipulates the formulae for calculating the excise duty payable on various blended petroleum products; namely, those containing petrol or gasoline, those not containing petrol or gasoline which are payable at the diesel rate, those containing a blend of gasoline and ethanol where no duty is payable, and those said to be fuel oil at the fuel oil rate.

The third area of the bill relates to gasoline and mineral turpentine produced from Australian oil shale. Clauses 6(c) and 6(d) remove the excise exemption which was applicable to gasoline and mineral turpentine produced from Australian oil shale as a result of the new arrangements proposed by clause 16 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993, which provides payments to certain producers of naphtha-derived oil shale. The Australian Democrats will support these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)
